entry.title: Just Kids
entry.content:
One of my favorite Leonard Cohen songs begins with the lines,"I remember you well in the Chelsea Hotel/You were talking so brave and so free." Patti Smith's memoir of her coming-of-age with artist/photographer Robert Mapplethorpe is partially set in this hotel with its unique history and cast of characters.

How different was life in New York City in the late 60s! But first Patti had to get there. Patti, who loved the French symbolists poets--Verlaine, Baudelaire, Mallarmé and Rimbaud--knew her future had to be in New York. She had recently had a child out of wedlock and given the baby girl to a family who could afford to keep her. She worked for a few months and saved her money up. But when she reached Philly's Greyhound Station, she discovered the fare had just doubled. In frustration, she went into a phone booth, not knowing whether to weep or call her sister to come retrieve her. But there on the tiny ledge, lay a white patent leather purse with 30-odd bucks inside and a necklace. Patti helped herself to the money and returned the purse and jewelry to the counter. Destiny, she thought.

She had almost no money and one suitcase of her things. She first went to where friends from her town in New Jersey lived, but alas, they had moved on. The young man that answered the door did not know where they had gone but his roommate did. The stranger sent Patti into the room where Robert Mapplethorpe was sleeping; he reminded her of a sleeping angel with curls. He walked her to her friends' new place, but they did not return for a long time. So Patti took to the streets. An enlightened hippie (or so he seemed) taught her where to get free day old bread and wilted lettuce for sandwiches, showed her the best places to sleep. A few days later, she met a man who took her to dinner, but he was not her type. As they were debating what to do next, Mapplethorpe walked by without a shirt on wearing a lambskin vest. Patti ran to him, and begged him to pretend he was her boyfriend and rescue her. He did. And thus a long standing relationship began, both personal and artistic. They both wanted, in fact, knew they would become famous.

They supported each other, though in truth, Patti was often the only one with a regular job--in various book stores. She began as a visual artist and poet and eventually became a rock star, perhaps prefigured by one night's visit to the Chelsea's home restaurant, the El Quixote, where Patti noticed Grace Slick and the Jefferson Airplane, Country Joe and the Fish, Jimi Hendrix, and Janis Joplin--all in the same night--dining and drinking. Patti became Mapplethorpe's first model.

To each other they were muses, lovers, and friends, but after about a year, Mapplethorpe discovered or finally admitted to himself his homosexuality. In describing this part of their history, Patti remains uncharacteristically silent. She only mentions several times, how very sad she felt by the changes in their relationship.

In the early 80s, they moved apart--Patti to Detroit, and a marriage and family. Mapplethorpe remained in New York--he had patrons now, a big loft, his work was appearing in the best museums.

This incredible story narrates being young during interesting times. It also describes a deep friendship, and how through it, a talented pair learned how to become the artists they dreamed of being in a changing world. If you like this memoir you might also want to read another rock autobiography Life by Keith Richards. Also check out a bio of Mapplethorpe written by an ex-lover and first publisher, Mapplethorpe: Assault with a Deadly Camera. If you love Patti Smith's music and want to explore her poetry try Auguries of Innocence.

entry.title: The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate
entry.content:
I admit to being a streaky reader - looks like this time last year I was on a World War I fiction kick. And this winter I read three books in a row about the Johnstown Flood including both fiction and non-fiction titles - Three Rivers Rising, In Sunlight In a Beautiful Garden, and The Johnstown Flood. The latter is by David McCullough, a famous historian and two time Pulitzer Prize recipient who is from Pittsburgh near the area where the flood occurred.

Recently though it seems I am reading a lot of coming of age novels featuring girls as the main character. E. Lockhart has written some wonderful contemporary coming of age novels, but for something historical I also have recently fallen for The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate by Jacqueline Kelly.

Calpurnia - Callie Vee to her family - is the only girl in a large family living in rural Texas at the turn of the 20th century. Much to her mother's displeasure, Callie begins spending most of her time outdoors observing plants and animals. The traditional female pursuits of handicrafts, cooking and dress hold no interest for Callie. Instead she becomes intersted in Darwin's recently published The Evolution of Species - though a mean librarian won't lend it to her (curse mean librarian stereotypes!). Callie's quirky grandfather intervenes and eventually helps guide Callie with her curiosity and excitement for the natural world through the process of scientific observation. Callie dreams of becoming a naturalist and a scientist but even at the age of 12 feels pressure to concede to housewifery. Her future is unfortunately uncertain, but the humor and longing to follow your dreams are handled deftly with a tender hand. Kelly's first novel would make a wonderful multi-generational read. Options for young women certainly have changed since 1899, but the struggles of growing up and into your own skin may continue to exist.

entry.title: Newest Most Favoritist Young Adult Author
entry.content:
The teenage female protagonists of E. Lockhart's novels are funny, smart, interesting, questioning and underneath it all resilient and strong. They don't always make the best initial choices, but are willing to learn and adjust as they go. These coming-of-age novels feature a romance (or two), but not at the cost of ignoring other similar and frequently troublesome themes of any young life - parents, school, friendships and finding your niche.

The Boyfriend List is the first in the Ruby Oliver series that also includes The Boy Book, The Treasure Map of Boys, and Real Live Boyfriends. In the beginning of the series, Ruby is struggling as a scholarship student at Tate Prep after her boyfriend dumps her for her best friend and a public humiliation that sends her to having anxiety attacks. Ruby is nothing if not a survivor - and through humor (often wonderfully sarcastic humor) figures out (more or less) how to survive.

In Fly on the Wall, Gretchen Yee is having trouble negotiating her arts school, where her comic book style receives mostly criticism. Not only does she not fit in with the rest of the traditional artsy crowd at school, her parents are getting a divorce. When she wishes to be a fly on the wall, she never expects her dream to come true. In the end it is Gretchen's choices after the Kafkaesque event - and not the event itself - that really change her life.

Sadye dreams of life on Broadway. In Dramarama, she and her best friend Demi get the opportunity to attend a prestigious theater summer camp - and of course the drama follows. Demi becomes the star and falls in love, while Sadye finds it difficult to just go with the flow. Sadye challenges the instructors and system after being unhappy at being cast in smaller roles. Despite her stubbornness and strong opinions the ending shows Sadye's true character. Musical references abound and a suggested movie list is included at the end.

Frankie starts dating the most popular senior at her boarding school - but doesn't feel comfortable being the typical sophomore arm candy. She wonders why Matthew's friends become her friends and his activities become her interests, but not the other way around. Her ambition to stir up the school, and it's secret club might not be identifiable to every teenage girl, but how Frankie negotiates her relationship with Matthew and learns a thing or two about her self along the way make for both a fun and thought provoking read. The Disreputable History of Frankie Landau-Banks might be my favorite Lockhart novel. Frankie is truly one of a kind - in the most hard-headed lovable way. This book was also a finalist for both the National Book Award for Young People's Literature and the Michael L. Printz Award.

Most of these books have strong language and mature scenes, though usually in appropriate context. I would recommend this for many teen girls who are unsure of their place in the world. While serious issues are discussed, the humor and often blistering dialog make for some serious fun too.
And while you are at it, check out E. Lockhart's blog!

link.title: Newest Most Favoritist Young Adult Author

entry.title: Astrid & Veronika
entry.content:
This lovely book describes a friendship between a septuagenarian and a woman of 30. Veronika, the younger woman, has spent a lifetime moving, first accompanying her father to his foreign service assignments, then on her own to Stockholm and London before impetuously following a boyfriend to Auckland, New Zealand.

This slow paced character study is not for everyone. But those who enjoy psychological fiction and beautiful writing will love this novel. The author, Linda Olsson, wrote her first novel in her fifties, and has lived in many places around the world including the two countries described here. Although she wrote this in English, several readers were convinced that she captured the flavor of her native Swedish in her prose.

After a recent tragedy involving a surfing accident, Veronika moves to a remote Swedish village to write her second book. Across the field is a big house that does not appear to be lived in. After a day or two, Veronika believes that someone is inside, so she begins waving when she passes the house, never sure if anyone has seen her. A few days later, intuitively, the young woman senses that something is wrong. After knocking, she runs inside and finds Astrid who is very sick.

She nurses her back to health, and cooks for her. This begins their tradition of sharing a meal every few days. Soon they each share secrets about their pasts, usually sorrows. Astrid takes Veronika to her favorite places from when she was a young woman. Many of these are in natural settings, in deep woods, on mountainsides, next to the flowing river. Together, they gather food from the land: wild strawberries, lingonberries and mushrooms that bleed. The bleeding mushrooms seem symbolic of their friendship, bleeding the bad stories out. What I particularly liked about this novel is it's quiet celebration of village life. On holidays, the women link arms and share the traditional activities of the day. Linda Olsson's grandmother once told her, "If we were the same age, we would be such great friends." And Linda responded, "Grandmother, we already are." This book is a tribute to both her grandmothers.

For other books about friendships, see Walking Across Egypt, which describes a friendship between an older woman and a teenage boy. Also check out Jane Austen's Emma and Elisabeth Berg's Talk Before Sleep.

entry.title: From Book to Movie to Award Nomination
entry.content:
Where does Hollywood get many of their ideas? Comic books? Yes. TV shows from the 1970s? *Sigh* - yes. But also from books! Real books! This year's Academy Award nominations were announced this week, including 5 films for Best Adapted Screen Play - 4 of which are based on books. The fifth film, Toy Story 3 is based on a original treatment of the first movie (or something).

If you liked these movies - you might try the original too! I know I am adding several of these to my to-read list.

Between a Rock and a Hard Place by Aron Ralston
This memoir is the basis for Danny Boyle's film 127 Hours and tells the amazing true story of a hiker who had to make a terrible decision after being trapped and injured alone in the desert for over five days. As a sometimes solo hiker, I am intrigued by this story. Both movie and book are on my list.

The Accidental Billionaires by Ben Mezrich
Writer Aaron Skorkin transformed this "juicy, fast-paced, unputdownable" book (as quoted by Kevin Spacey) into The Social Network - a movie with dialogue that flew fast and furious. Mezrich's account may or may not be entirely true (same goes for the movie), but he is nothing if not a storyteller.

Winter's Bone by Daniel Woodrell
From billionaires to the poverty stricken Ozarks we go. Ree, 16, has learned that her father has put their house up as bond for his meth-related arrest and as the court date appears, is nowhere to be found. Despite caring for her younger brothers and ill mother, Rees tries to find her father even though it means encountering unhelpful and often dangerous family members. The novel portrays the bleakness of rural poverty and the harshness of a meth community, but is also filled with hope and promise.

True Grit by Charles Portis
I have seen both the 1969 version with John Wayne and the new Coen Brother's versions of this film, and it might be high time to put this western on my list too. With reviews like these, it would be a crime not to:
"An instant classic... Read it and have the most fun you've had reading a novel in years, maybe decades."--Newsday
"Skillfully constructed, a comic tour de force."--The New York Times Book Review
"Charles Portis details the savagery of the 1870s frontier through an astonishing narrative voice: that of the 14-year-old Mattie Ross, a flinty, skeptical, Bible-thumping scourge"--Wall Street Journal

So while many people are watching new movies before the Academy Awards in the spring, reading a few seems like a good idea too.

entry.title: Let's Take the Long Way Home
entry.content:
What an incredibly moving testament to women's friendship. Two Boston area writers who met at a reading but only came to know each other when they were raising puppies at the same time and their dog trainer suggested that they would hit it off.

Caroline was a rower and essayist; Gail, a swimmer and book critic. Both were determined, competitive, tough, and shy. One of Gail's friends nicknamed her "the gregarious hermit." Caroline's dog was a shepherd mix. Gail finally adopted the pristine white samoyed she had always longed for. Caroline stayed in the Cambridge area where she had grown up, while Gail had left her beloved high-country Texas although she still pined for it.

Their friendship began walking the woody fire trails and at ponds in and around Boston. They had a lot in common: each shared an alcoholic past, each were or had been smokers, each loved living alone (or at least most of the time), and for each, writing was a way of experiencing and interpreting the world.

At one point, early in their relationship, Gail yelled to her friend, "Oh no, I need you." Daily, they put up with each other's neuroses: Caroline's endless checking of her watch, Gail's bizarre fear that the dogs would run out on forming ice and drown. Humor became their balm. "Well," Caroline said after the thin-ice remark, "We're going to have to start walking with a rope and ax, aren't we?"

They taught each other many things. Caroline taught Gail how to scull, how to read the wind and the river, how to use her abdomen muscles against the current, and not to worry about what's behind you, only to go forward. Gail taught Caroline another stroke, swimmer's freestyle. From Caroline, Gail learned that whenever emotional difficulty stuck, it was better to race toward it rather than withdraw and avoid it.

They met soon after both of Caroline's parents had died, when she was promoting her book Drinking: a Love Story. For a long while, Gail did not share her alcoholic past with her friend.

When other people bugged them, they tagged them with annoying dog breed names. Vain, entitled folks were dispensed as "apricot poodles." A disloyal friend received the epithet "beagle." They christened each other as smarter, more loyal breeds--Caroline was a collie; Gail, a young female German Shepherd, super-intelligent, controlling all the other dogs. "That's why I made you a young female. To soften it," Caroline added.

Gail Caldwell's short memoir is not only about friendship but about the violence and fog of grief. It will convince you to appreciate more those close to you, encourage you hug them more often and share confidences more readily, to experience together the joys and challenges of daily life. For folks who want to explore another deep literary friendship try Ann Patchett's Truth and Beauty. And if you loved the dog-human bonds described here, read Caroline's own book about dogs Pack of Two: the Intricate Bond between People and Dogs. You might also enjoy Mark Doty's Dog Years: a Memoir, a book celebrating how much dogs add to our lives and how their sloppy presences can help assuage the pain of loss.

link.title: Let's Take the Long Way Home

entry.title: 2011 Michael L. Printz Award
entry.content:
Every year the Michael L. Printz award is given to recognize excellence in Young Adult Literature. The American Library Association's publication, Booklist, is the sponsor of the award which was announced two weeks ago. The announcement slipped my notice, but both the winner and several of the honored titles look too good to not pass along.

2011 Printz Winner:
Ship Breaker by Paolo Bacigalupi
In a futuristic world, teenaged Nailer scavenges copper wiring from grounded oil tankers for a living, but when he finds a beached clipper ship with a girl in the wreckage, he has to decide if he should strip the ship for its wealth or rescue the girl.

2011 Printz Honor Books:
Stolen by Lucy Christopher
Sixteen-year-old Gemma, a British city-dweller, is abducted while on vacation with her parents and taken to the Australian outback, where she soon realizes that escape attempts are futile, and in time she learns that her captor is not as despicable as she first believed.

Please Ignore Vera Dietz by A.S. King
When her best friend, whom she secretly loves, betrays her and then dies under mysterious circumstances, high school senior Vera Dietz struggles with secrets that could help clear his name.

Revolver by Marcus Sedgwick
Finland, 1910: Fifteen-year-old Sig is shocked to see a hole in the frozen lake outside his family's cabin and to find his father's corpse nearby. Why did Einar steer his dog sled across the lake instead of taking the safer land route? After Sig's sister and stepmother go for help, leaving Sig alone with Einar's body in the cabin, the situation turns even more chilling.

Nothing by Janne Teller
When thirteen-year-old Pierre Anthon leaves school to sit in a plum tree and train for becoming part of nothing, his seventh grade classmates set out on a desperate quest for the meaning of life.

entry.title: One Book One Bloomington 2011
entry.content:
Last night, the 2011 One Book, One Bloomington Community Read title was announced on WFHB's Interchange radio program.

This year, the community voted for Let the Great World Spin by Colum McCann.

Frank McCourt had this to say about this National Book Award winner, "trust me, this is the sort of book that you will take off your shelf over and over again as the years go along. It’s a story of the early 1970s, but it’s also the story of our present times. And it is, in many ways, a story of a moment of lasting redemption even in the face of all the evidence....I didn’t want to stop turning the pages. I’m really not sure what McCann will do after this, but this is a great New York book, not just for New Yorkers but for anyone who walks any sort of tightrope at all. And yes, it doesn’t surprise me that it takes an Irishman to capture the heart of the city." This novel captures the spirit of America in a time of transition, promise, and soon-to-be-ended innocence.

Please visit www.mcpl.info/onebook for information on public book discussions, a related film festival and additional resources about the book and author. Or listen to the podcast of last night's Interchange radio broadcast on the WFHB website.

Check out Let the Great World Spin today…join our Community Read this spring!

entry.title: Where the God of Love Hangs Out
entry.content:
Amy Bloom, who used to be a practicing psychotherapist, has won many awards for her short stories. Her latest collection Where the God of Love Hangs Out examines love in many aspects. Bloom shows how it’s possible to fall for an older man with a beer belly who suffers from gout and a life-threatening heart condition. The book features two sets of interrelated stories, the first about two couples—close, long-term friends—whose lives are broken apart and rearranged in new and unconventional ways. The second set of stories explores the lives of a jazz musician's widow and her young adult son, Lionel. These four stories reveal how grief makes some people emotionally vulnerable and susceptible to poor life choices.

The voice behind Bloom’s stories is accepting, forgiving and kind, no matter what havoc and pain her characters create for each other. Those years on the other side of the couch have given Bloom an empathetic brush to draw her characters. As she said in an interview, "I've spent a lot of time listening to people, and I am endlessly intrigued by relationships, particularly by the gap between what people say and what they truly feel, and the gap between what they do and what they really want."

One of my favorite stories, "Between Here and There" begins with the shocking statement, "I had always planned to kill my father." Allison, who is now grown up, thought that even as a young child. She now must care for her senile older dad. As you read on, you find that when her mother died, her father did not even give the children their mother’s jewelry to remember her by. The dad is also virulently anti-gay although his son has come out. The story shows how sometimes people can love their parents and at the same time dislike them immensely. Yet this dislike does not interfere with caretaking and yes, in the process brings moments of joy and tenderness.

Another story features an abused girl from the wrong side of the tracks who marries into a good family. Her husband and in-laws don’t have a clue about her past, or her present either, especially when her drug-dependent Mom comes by to bribe her for drug money. Yet, the young woman, now pregnant, forms a bond with her father-in-law that allows her to come to terms with her troubled and secret past.

This is a marvelous collection of stories that reveals our human weaknesses and strengths. Each story shows the necessity for connection and dialogue with others, both those we love and even those we don’t like at all. Amy Bloom writes with the wisdom of someone who has heard every heart-wrenching tale there is. As she said, "to know and engage with someone intimately is always a crossing of a border, always fraught…."

If you enjoy the short story form, try other collections by Alice Munro, especially Hateship, Friendship, Courtship, Loveship, Marriage. Munro, a Canadian, writes, in my view, the best short stories of anyone. If you'd prefer to explore love from another cultural perspective, read Yiyun Li's Gold Boy, Emerald Girl. And not for the faint of heart, Mary Gaitskill's stories (especially Bad Behavior) explore the dark side of love and relationships.

link.title: Where the God of Love Hangs Out

entry.title: The Writing Circle
entry.content:
This novel examines the writing process itself especially that nerve-wracking period when an author first shares her work with other people. Nancy writes for a medical newsletter for a living; how ironic, she often thinks, that a doctor's daughter researches articles about prostate health, skin cancer, even empty nest syndrome, and then makes pronouncements about them in the voice of a medical practitioner rather than her own. Her novel is a deeply personal story, one that imagines her father’s life beginning with the night he watched a couple say good-bye to their newborn daughter. Nancy has waited until after her father’s death to imagine his story. And as in all fiction, the bare biographical facts are merely a springboard to the tale, not its actual foundation.

A colleague invites Nancy to join the group which includes a biographer, a poet, a historian, a thriller writer, and a young man who is trying to find his true topic. The group is the very elitist sounding, Leopardi Circle, named after Giacomo Leopardi, the late author who was "tortured, pessimistic, and, above all, passionate." Passionate is the operative word here; quite a few of the members have had dalliances with each other. In fact, there is at least one unexpected affair between two group members during the course of the story. Another two members were once married.

One intriguing facet about the book is that the story is told through the point of view of all writing group members, but also of several of their children and significant others. The poet, Gillian turns out to be the most caustic member of the group, highly critical and unsympathatic despite the fact she is one of the most established and famous. Indeed this year--rumor has it--she is likely to win the Pulitzer.

Corinne Demas pokes sardonic fun at writers' egos, but also weaves an interesting story showing the interconnections between people in a New England town. And the book is replete with manuscripts in process, everything from poetry to a thriller to biographical vignettes, all done with much talent. When I read Demas's own publishing credits, this made sense, because she has written short stories, a memoir, children's books and poetry.

Other novels about writing groups include The Circle, a mystery set in Britain about an eccentric writers' circle, and The Savage Detectives that depicts two members of a Mexican literary movement travelling the globe and sharing all sorts of misadventures. If you prefer to look at other literary circles, how about The Jane Austen Book Club by Karen Joy Fowler and Mary Alice Monroe's The Book Club, both interesting takes on groups of people finding themselves and each other through books.

entry.title: Graphic Novels for The Afraid
entry.content:
I will come right out and say that I do not like superheroes (movie or print) and I didn’t read comic books as a kid, so I am not naturally drawn to the graphic novel format. Because I’m kind of a nerd, what I do like is big fat novels and dusty historical non-fiction. So color me surprised when recently I’ve been enjoying more graphic novels. Last night as I finished Mercury by Hope Larson I began to wonder and hope that the reason went beyond the fact that I can read on in a single sitting – though that is very satisfying too! My rationale is that I’ve been craving something different. I have read enough fiction to be somewhat bored with a traditional storyline. I want to think while I read – to be engaged! And picking up some graphic novels has been the way to do that recently. I’ve tried to compile a list of graphic novels for the hesitant – for anyone who thought that they weren’t interested. Give one a try, you might be pleasantly surprised.

Maus by Art Spiegelman
This classic graphic novel is on every “must read” list – and for good reason. This personal and moving tale is told through flashbacks of the author’s father, a Holocaust survivor. In 1992 this was the first graphic novel to win a Pulitzer Prize.

Stitches by David Small
A finalist for the 2009 National Book Award, this touching memoir tells the tale of Small’s childhood and examines the frightening possibility that his father caused his cancer through unnecessary and experimental radiation treatments.

The Arrival by Shaun Tan
This graphic novel tells the classic immigrant story – what it is like to leave loved ones and arrive in a seemingly alien world - all without words. Yep, without words. Amazing illustrations and a true story arc make up for the need of even a single letter of text.

Persepolis by Marjane Satrapi
Both immesely funny and serious, this is Satrapi’s memoir of growing up in Iran during the Revolution, starting at the age of nine.

Mercury by Hope Larson
Two young women in a rural area of Novia Scotia struggle with family obligations, relationships and growing up – over 100 years apart.

entry.title: New Year's Resolutions
entry.content:
Many resolutions fall into two categories: being healthier and organizing finances - or variations on these themes. What about you? Are you making New Year's Resolutions? Maybe the library can help!
Possible serious and not so serious resolutions:

1. Stop smoking - often at the top of many resolution lists.

2. Learn to fold a paper crane, and then make 1,000 of them.

3. Put all those tools in your basement to good use.

4. It's never to early to start your garden plans - grow better veggies.

5. Eat more veggies!

6. Can music make you happier, healthier and less stressed? Pick up a guitar, violin or harmonica today.

7. Take a volunteer vacation, or volunteer right here at home with the library's VITAL department.

8. Adopt a pet from the animal shelter - figure out a name and learn proper training techniques.

9. Finally read War and Peace, Seamus Heaney's translation of Beowulf, Victor Hugo's Les Miserables or maybe the entire works of Jane Austen.

10. Don't forget to document your success! Take better pictures and share them with friends and family.

entry.title: Snowstorms in a Hot Climate
entry.content:
Sarah Dunant writes historical novels set in sixteenth-century Italy; she also pens modern mysteries featuring feminist sleuth, Hannah Wolfe. This book is much closer to the latter in tone and subject.

The surface premise of this novel is two proper English women are enticed into the international drug trade, but on a deeper level this book examines the nature of truth. It also takes a stab at answering this question: who can you really trust in this world? Your best friend, homebody academic medievalist, Marla? Perhaps or perhaps not. What about blond-haired Lenny with elegant fingers and passions for historical nonfiction as well as high-grade cocaine? Or loner ex-coke dealer J.T. who really has no time for people, only for his chickens (of the poultry variety)? Or diminutive, world-traveler Elly who is beautiful, open, and perhaps too vulnerable?

Elly and Maya have been best friends forever—at least until Elly left for South America adventuring a couple of years before and never returned to England. Marla has borne life without her, but it’s become like a British winter, grey, bland, and lasting nearly forever when suddenly Elly writes to her from New York and asks her to come immediately to help. Marla flies across the Atlantic and finds a woman in very changed circumstances--half-owner of a Manhattan apartment and a Greenwich, Ct. estate. Elly has become rich and embroiled in a relationship with Lenny--a relationship now hitting the rocks.

The pair decide to visit J.T. in Santa Cruz where they can hash things out. J.T. gives them their own sun-blessed cottage there where they sunbathe on the deck and enjoy beautiful sunsets over the Pacific. But all is not fine in Paradise. The phone rings with malevolent callers and two men have a telescope trained at them in the woods. And J.T. goes from silent to gruff to mean, especially toward Marla.

Dunant is extraordinary good about showing the inequalities and power relationships in both friendships and love affairs. The book has elements of a thriller but veers more toward a psychological tale where the reader thinks she is on certain ground, but the ground keeps shifting. Dunant incorporates interesting travel color as well from: Colombia, South America, New York, California, London, Paris, and Scotland. This novel is a great read and one that would engender discussion because the questions it asks aren’t answered in any definitive way, but open for interpretation. Readers who enjoyed Zoe Heller's What Was She Doing?: Notes on a Scandal and S.J. Rozan's Absent Friends might enjoy this novel about women's friendship.

entry.title: Millard Fillmore
entry.content:
by Robert J. Raybach

This biography is great in the sense that it examines the nuts and bolts of party politics. Fillmore makes it to the top the hard way—building a party, placating inner-party opponents, finding the right man for the job—until he finally reached his level of his incompetence—the Presidency.

Of course he was in a nearly impossible position. The country needed a visionary leader, which was the last person the parties would willingly nominate for the position. (Zachery Taylor was an accident, nominated by a dying Whig Party because, like Jackson and Harrison, he was a war hero.)

Fillmore was equivalent to a Blue Dog Democrat today—always ready to compromise even to his own disadvantage. He struggled to isolate the radicals of both sides and encouraged the Union sympathizers of the North and the South to hold fast. Unfortunately, while he despised the hotheads of the North, he appeased those of the South. The more he gave in to the South, the more it alarmed the North, which stepped up its rhetoric, causing the South to feel less secure and hence demanding more. At least this is the Southern historians' position. I've yet to decide but it has made me far more sensitive to differences of opinion and inevitable author bias.

You expect an author to have sympathy for their subject, especially one as misunderstood as Fillmore, but by the end of the book I wanted to know more about the author, where he was coming from. He displays surprising little interest in the human cost of slavery. It's just a legal wrangle to him and to Fillmore. I apologize if I'm misunderstanding Dr. Rayback, but he seems to share in that pie-in-the-sky fantasy of early Americans from George Washington to James Buchanan that if left alone slavery would die off on its own.

One consistent trait of Fillmore's is that he made bad decisions throughout his career. (Like when he let Thurlow Weed and William Seward off the mat after he had them down.) Inexplicably, Fillmore decided against running for president in his own right, when he at least had a chance of winning and an opportunity to prove his policies right. Instead he presided over the dissolution of the Whig Party. Four years later he tried to rally the old Whigs one last time as the candidate of the "Know-Nothing" Party (anti-immigrant, anti-Catholic nativists), and although he polled a respectable 21%, it was clear that the middle ground was eroding away.

Fillmore was a steady man, a dependable man, a careful man, a man without the imagination needed to be President during an extraordinary time.

entry.title: True Tales of Winter Adventure
entry.content:
Bring on the snow and cold - I love winter! Winter officially started on December 21 and we've had snow on the ground here in southern Indiana for what seems like weeks already.
What a great time to read some winter adventure and science books - in this case sometimes the best stories are true stories.
One of the most well known adventure non-fiction writer is Jon Krakauer. If you haven't read any of his titles, Into Thin Air is one of his best and most well known. This book follows the author as he climbs Mt. Everest in the spring of 1996 - the year 8 climbers died. Mindless pursuit of the summit in the face of almost unimaginable conditions come under some fire by the author considering the shocking human and financial costs of many private expeditions.
In 1914 28 men led by Ernest Shackleton departed Europe on the Endurance with plans to land and cross the Antarctic continent on foot. Due to icy seas, they never reach the continent and spend over a year trapped thousands of miles from civilization - most of the time camping on ice floes after their ship was crushed by the heavy ice and sinks. After some harrowing small boat trips and having several close calls due to weather and hunger - every man survives. This story is amazing (and will make you appreciate a snuggly warm reading spot). I recently finished Endurance by Alfred Lansing, which was short and to the point, using many first person resources and interviews of survivors. But there are several other books about the Endurance and Ernest Shackleton.

Two books I've blogged about before are worth a mention in this post as well include Winter World: The Ingenuity of Animal Survival by Bernd Heinrich and Tiger: A True Story of Vengeance and Survival by John Vaillant.

Other tales of fascinating and frosty feats:
Seven Years in Tibet by Heinrich Harrer
Farthest North by Fridtjof Nansen
Alive by Piers Paul Read
The Worst Journey in the World by Apsley Cherry-Garrard
The Children's Blizzard by David Laskin

entry.title: Lives Like Loaded Guns
entry.content:
We’ve all heard the sweet fairy tales about the poet of Amherst being a recluse for thirty years, floating around her parents’ house and garden in a frilly white dress. Stories (even a play) about the hermit poet abound, but from the title page of this book, one senses that Lyndall Gordon blows these myths apart.

This biography describes Dickinson more accurately as a strong, modern woman who studied Emerson as a girl and took his words of Self-Reliance to heart. Gordan writes some of the best literary biographies. She’s won prizes for books on Virginia Woolf and Mary Wollstonecraft; she also composed excellent life studies of T.S. Eliot and Charlotte Bronte. Here Gordon uses evidence from letters, family archives, and poetry to debunk Emily’s wimpy wallflower status. By pluralizing guns in the title, Gordon also centers her history on other lives connected to Emily’s: none of which were staid and uninteresting. Gordon’s thesis is twofold that Emily’s illness affected her life in many ways, and that Emily and those around her including her brother, her sister-in-law Sue, her brother’s mistress, Mabel Loomis Todd, led lives full of passion and secrecy. What’s most intriguing is her argument that the great split in the family that eventually worked its way into the publishing and archiving of Dickinson’s poetry began with her brother’s love affair with Todd. This split lasted over a hundred years.

Gordon proves herself to be a detailed and intuitive researcher. I’ve read other biographies of E.D. and none offer such a rich detailing of the culture and milieu of the times. We learn about Emily’s relatives, especially her mother, and though Emily railed against her mother’s entrapment in marriage, Eleanor Norris was also a woman ahead of her times. She met her husband attending a college lecture—a chemistry lecture--when women were only allowed to attend college infrequently and only as guests. We learn about the respected Dickinson family: ED’s grandfather went into debt because he believed in education so much that he founded Amherst College. This decision forced him to move out west (to Ohio which was west in those days) to earn more money, leaving Emily’s father with the responsibility of cleaning up his father’s debts before getting married. We also learn about Austin, Emily’s brother, who falls in love with Mabel Loomis Todd, an astronomy professor’s life.

The rift between Sue, Austin’s wife, and Mabel Loomis Todd created a vast crevasse that all of the Dickinson family—most of whom lived next door—had to maneuver carefully around. And when Emily died, Sue and Mabel fought over her legacy. Todd succeeded in publishing some of Emily’s work—she was a writer and editor after all—but not in the form that Emily had written them. According to Gordon, Todd’s presentation of them “suppressed some of their originality," including the poet’s unique and iconic use of dashes. These were all excised. In 1896, the Dickinson family and Mabel divided Emily’s poems between the two families to comply with a lawsuit. For half of the 20th century, Emily’s work was presented but not as she wrote it.

This complicated biography about one of America’s best creative geniuses is riveting and deepened throughout with Emily’s words, her poems, presented in the way that she had envisioned them.

entry.title: Don't Let's Go to the Dogs Tonight
entry.content:
Alexandra Fuller's first book, a memoir, has the punch, intensity, and tension of a good novel. What I liked most about this book is Fuller's stark honesty about her family's racism and her mother's alcoholism. Bobo (her family's nickname for her) had a hard scrabble childhood growing up on several farms in what is now Zimbabwe during the 1970s and 1980s war for independence. Bobo, the youngest of two daughters, recalls her family’s poverty, the ex-pat lifestyle, and Africa’s hot climate. The family fought to survive, often renting their land. Many times they had almost no food and no luxuries except for the land itself and their dogs and horses. Droughts wrecked their crops, soldiers tore their land apart, and Bobo’s mother drank bottle after bottle to ease the pain of her loved ones’ deaths. Because not only were soldiers and innocent civilians dying, but the family lost several children.

Bobo's parents had high expectations for the girls. In one harrowing scene, Bobo must help her mom corral wild cattle back to the barn. She and her mother spend hours in the bush under a hot sun with no water or food. At one point, Bobo gives up and her mother tells her to ride home. But Bobo, still just a young girl, is afraid to go alone, so she sticks it out and finally returns home after successfully calling the cattle home.

Later, their father, tries to teach Bobo and Vanessa how to shoot a rifle. Vanessa, beautiful and artistic, wants no part of any violence, but her father insists. A day may come when both he and their mother may be shot or blown up by a landmine and the daughters must learn to protect themselves. Grudgingly, Vanessa comes over to the rifle. Ignoring all of her father’s instructions, she holds it the wrong way, yet manages to blow out the target’s painted heart. There are fun times too: camping on the beach under the stars, singing together as they ride a Jeep through the wild countryside where ibexes and leopards cross their path.

Fuller's coming of age story, besides being a memoir of a struggling family's history in a war-torn land, is also a paean to the beauty of Africa, its wildness, its animal life, its evocative smells, its people, both black and white, who in the end want the same things: a decent life full of family love, adventures, and stories. If you liked Beryl Markham’s West with the Night and Dinesen’s Out of Africa, this modern African story will transport to the tropics where anything can happen and often does.

link.title: Don't Let's Go to the Dogs Tonight

entry.content:

entry.title: OMG Zombies!!1!
entry.content:
Full disclosure: I don't really like zombie books. Graphic novels aren't my favorite, and I usually to stay far away from post-apocalyptic fiction.

What DO I like? The Walking Dead series! Defying all reason, this post-apocalyptic zombie graphic novel series has me simultaneously racing and savoring each volume. I usually read each volume twice - once to race through it to see what happens, and then a second time to go back and savor the stunning black and white illustrations.

In the first volume, Rick Grimes, a small town Kentucky cop is shot on the job and is in a coma during his recovery. The real nightmare begins when he wakes up alone (well sort of alone...) in the hospital weeks later. He makes it back to his neighborhood to discover his family gone and everyone either missing or turned into ZOMBIES! The heart of this series is in the survival of the unknown. This story won't change your life, and there are times of clunky dialogue - but the introspection into humanity and the motivations and dynamics of the survivors - in all their ugly glory is what keeps me coming back.

Warning! There is violence - both zombie and human that is pretty graphically portrayed. Therefore, I realize that these books aren't for everyone, but would continue to encourage someone who may not have picked up a graphic novel and doesn't mind a little zombie carnage to give these a try.

Oh yeah, you might have also heard of the AMC show based on this series. The show is also fantastic, but is really different than the graphic novels. Needless to say, if you like one, you might like the other.

entry.title: Zoo Story: Life in the Garden of Captives
entry.content:
This nonfiction book has it all: love, sex, death, human alpha posturing, caring, and lots of animal stories. French, a Pulitzer-Prize winning journalist, pulls you into the story with this opener: “Eleven elephants. One plane. Hurtling together across the sky.” The pilots were transporting elephants from their former home in Swaziland to the United States to be placed in zoos. Because they were still wild, no one knew whether the elephants could withstand the trip or whether they would freak out and break out of their cages at 20,000 feet.

Zoo Story has the emotional arc of fiction. The animals themselves become intriguing characters with their own histories and desires. The zoo has a king and a queen--the king being the chimp, Herman, a draw to the zoo for over thirty years--his animal number is 000001. Herman rules over the other chimps and has a strange fascination for blondes in tank tops. French tags Enshalla the queen of Tampa's Lowry Park Zoo, and he details the slow, arduous process of interesting her in mating with a powerful tiger.

What makes the book particularly interesting is that French recognizes animal traits in humans. There's a wonderful description of an after-hours Tampa Zoo dinner where French describes the "primate behavior" he observes in the park's CEO and the society folk attending the event.

Not only is this a story about zoos and their animals, but French also deals with issues of extinction and even questions our moral right to keep animals captive. He interviews and weaves in many zookeepers' stories, so it's a book equally about humans and animals. There's a funny story about the zoo's CEO who manages to lose his own private group of monkeys who make headlines in their escape across Florida.

Zoo aficionados can try Dr. Fisher's Life on the Ark, a book by a Chicago zookeeper who not only describes a nearby zoo but his travels around the world in search of animals. A vastly different book with a political and historical context is The Zookeeper's Wife by Diane Ackerman which describes a German zoo that provided a haven for Jews during the Holocaust.

link.title: Zoo Story: Life in the Garden of Captives

entry.title: 2010 National Book Award Winners
entry.content:
The National Book Award winners were announced this past week. The biggest surprise was Lord of Misrule by Jaimy Gordon - as the initial printing was only 2,000 copies from a small publisher. Gordon's novel about horse racing beat out some big literary names like Peter Carey and Nicole Krauss to win the best prize for fiction.

Patti Smith took home the best prize for non-fiction for her memoir, Just Kids, about her relationship with artist Robert Mapplethorpe - both before and after fame. Terrance Hayes took home the best prize for his collection of poetry, Lighthead, and Mockingbird by Kathryn Erskine was awarded the award for best Young Adult fiction.

See all nominations and listen to interviews at the National Book Awards website.

entry.title: Blind Descent: the Quest to Discover the Deepest Place on Earth
entry.content:
Blind Descent, written by James M. Tabor, takes readers into the thrilling world of supercaves- caves which descend thousands of feet. Tabor tells the true story of two teams and their quests to reach the deepest points on earth. While their goals are the same, the leaders of the teams could not be more different in personality or approach to their adventures. American Bill Stone is a driven type-A who lets nothing get in the way of his ambition. Ukranian Alexander Klimchouk is a firm but fair leader who is much-loved by his team and focuses on hard work and efficiency. The American expeditions explored vast cave systems in the Mexican highlands, while the Ukranians took on a nightmarish shaft in Georgia near the Black Sea.


These teams spent weeks underground in total darkness, frequently sleeping on dangerous ledges, all while hauling heavy equipment through crevices, and sometimes underwater. Rockfalls, hypothermia, exhaustion, lethal microbes, vampire bats, and giant spiders are just a few of the extreme dangers they encountered along the way. The physical and mental stresses of these expeditions pushed the cavers to their absolute limits, and not all made it out alive. Included in the book are some gorgeous photos taken within the depths of these caves giving readers a chance to see sights most will never have a chance to see. Reminiscent of Into Thin Air by Jon Krakauer and Shadow Divers by Robert Kurson this book is an exciting true adventure story that reads like ficiton.

link.title: Blind Descent: the Quest to Discover the Deepest Place on Earth

entry.title: Quilling Books
entry.content:
I learned how to do it - from A BOOK! Ha! I admit that my first destination for learning how to do something new is usually the internet. But when I held a library program last week on quilled cards - a craft that was new to me - I started with books from MCPL's collection.
Not that there aren't great quilling resources online - there are. There was also a lot to shuffle through. Books from our collection proved to be easy to learn from and had great examples - from fairly easy to more complex patterns.
Last week 17 enthusiastic women (including a family of 3 generations) participated in the library's quilled card program. The photos in this post were taken from completed cards made during the program. Everyone created something really different and unique. Aren't they beautiful?
Quilling supplies proved to be fairly inexpensive. A quilling tool and some pre-cut strips of paper are all you would have to purchase - provided you own a ruler, scissors and some plain ol' white school glue. Most local craft stores had these supplies.
If I can do it, you can too! Check out the library's collection of quilling books:

Popular Quilling by Helen Walter (my personal favorite - her Australian animals and flora are amazing!)
Paper Quilling: Beautiful Paper Filigree to Make in a Weekend by Malinda Johnston
Great Paper Quilling by Mickey Baskett
Paper Quilling for the First Time by Alli Bartkowski
Quilling for Scrapbooks & Cards by Susan Lowman

entry.title: The True Story of Hansel and Gretel
entry.content:
I had been in a reading slump for awhile, and I was unable to find a book that I could really get into or feel compelled to finish reading. A few weeks ago, however, I started reading The True Story of Hansel and Gretel by Louise Murphy, and I was hooked. I found this book as I was browsing our reading lists, specifically the Fairy Tales and Legends Retold list. I love fairy tales and retold fairy tales, and I was intrigued both by the choice of Hansel and Gretel and the setting of the story during World War II Poland.

Louise Murphy masterfully portrays not only all aspects and imagery of the original Hansel and Gretel fairy tale, but she also captures what life was like in Poland during World War II and the Nazi occupation. She includes different perspectives and aspects of life at this time through characters that are living in and around a rural village and living in the forest as partisans. The book also includes the dynamic of the Nazis and the Russians, as well as the Polish people who are caught in the middle. I find this book to be an accurate portrayal of what life was like in Poland during World War II, and even if specific events included in the book are fictional, they are believable.

The original Hansel and Gretel story is rather intense and gritty, addressing issues of abandonment and untrustworthy strangers, and it fits very well into the intense, life and death reality of wartime Poland. The story is gritty and raw, but it is well written and you become drawn into and attached to the characters, even though the end is somewhat predictable, given what one knows about the original tale. The stays very true to the original tale and incorporates all of the imagery mentioned in the original Grimms' fairy tale, molding it to fit the context of the setting and story.

There are disturbing scenes and acts of atrocity included in the story, but it adds to the reality of the time period and the evils of war and genocide. The book is intense, but I found it to be a wonderful, compelling read, and I highly recommend it.

If you would like to refamiliarize yourself with the original tale, the library has some copies of Grimms' Fairy Tales.

link.title: The True Story of Hansel and Gretel

entry.title: One Book One Bloomington - It's Time to Vote!
entry.content:
What if everyone in our local community all read and discussed the same book???

It's time to vote for your community read!

Between November 1 and November 30, you can cast your vote for one of four titles to be nominated for the 2011 One Book One Bloomington and Beyond community read. The winning title will be announced in January and book discussions and related programs will happen throughout the Spring of 2011. Read more and cast your vote on online and check out the nominated titles today!

Crescent by Diana Abu-Jaber
Set in Los Angeles and peopled by immigrants and Iraqi-Americans, the novel brings alive a vibrant community of exiled academics, immigrants on the make, and optimistic souls looking for love. As it follows the life and love of a thirty-nine-year-old, half-Arab chef, it effectively alters the one-dimensional image of Iraqis held by many Americans.
Published in 2004, 352 pages

The Girl Who Fell from the Sky by Heidi Durrow
The daughter of a black G.I. and a Danish mother is the sole survivor of a family tragedy. When she moves in with her African-American grandmother in a black community, she must confront her biracial identity in a world that sees in black and white.
Published in 2010, 256 pages

Let the Great World Spin by Colum McCann
In August 1974, a tightrope walker, suspended a quarter mile above the streets of Manhattan, dances his way between the Twin Towers. Below, the lives of ordinary people become entwined in extraordinary ways in this sweepingly radical social novel that captures the spirit of America in a time of transition, promise, and soon-to-be-ended innocence.
Published in 2009, 400 pages

The Help by Kathryn Stockett
A story of social awakening as seen from both sides of the racial divide, this novel explores the issue of the lines we abide by and those we don't. In a story filled with humor, poignancy and hope, three women start a movement that changes a town during the beginning of the Civil Rights Movement.
Published in 2009, 464 pages.

entry.title: November's Books Plus
entry.content:
After a lovely autumn, we're approaching the short, dark days of November. Because of the elections this year, medical care has been widely discussed. Our next Books Plus title, The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down, examines how medical practices and beliefs can differ between cultures. Eloquent writer Anne Fadiman reports what happens when a Hmong child is treated by American doctors. After Lia is diagnosed with epilepsy at only three months of age, her family and doctors want to cure her by different means. The Hmong believe that healing involves both body and soul; in fact, the entire universe plays a role while American practitioners concentrate almost solely on healing the body.

Join Wendy in an interesting discussion about intercultural communication and the nature of healing. For more details on this and other programs, please see below.

“This is Zora Hurston's third novel, again about her own people--and it is beautiful. It is about Negroes, and a good deal of it is written in dialect, but really it is about every one, or least every one who isn't so civilized that he has lost the capacity for glory. Indeed, from first to last this is a well nigh perfect story--a little sententious at the start, but the rest is simple and beautiful and shining with humor.” – New York Times Book Review (September, 1937)

entry.title: The Nobodies Album
entry.content:
How does a mother reconnect with her estranged grown-up son? Does his wealth and fame as a rock star make this harder? And what tore them apart in the first place? In Parkhurst's intriguing third novel, author Octavia Frost makes a New York City outing to deliver her latest manuscript to her agent. However, she never gets there because when a cabbie ferries her away from Times Square, she reads these words on the giant electronic screen, "Pareidolia singer Milo Frost arrested for the murder of girlfriend Bettina Moffett."

This is no ordinary mystery. It's more a literary tale about the bonds of family. It also examines how art--novels and songs--can bring people together and also drive them apart. Milo stopped visiting Octavia after reading her latest novel on an airplane to San Francisco.

This is where The Nobodies Album comes in. Octavia decides to rewrite the endings of all her earlier novels--she's changed after all, so why can't she rewrite the endings to more fully express the artist she is now? But what really drives her is that she might be able to reach out to her son with a new ending for her novel Tropospheric Scatter which is about a family very similar to their own that suffered a similar tragedy.

Although the novel centers on a grisly murder and early death, it's inviting style and extremely smart and captivating heroine, Octavia Frost, pull you in. Carolyn Parkhurst cleverly quilts in jacket copies for most of Octavia's books and both endings; the old and the new, though the new ones are mercifully short. This also builds tension for the main story.

A fun and compelling read, full of the texture of modern life. This book provides a sense of how complicated people really are, especially other family members. Another recent novel exploring the relationship between a mother and son and parents and children is That Old Cape Magic by Richard Russo.

entry.title: The Tiger!
entry.content:
This book reads like a murder mystery...page turning and thought provoking. But it is so much more than that too! The Tiger: A True Story of Vengeance and Survival by John Vaillant is filled with animal science, ecology, conservation efforts in Russia after perestroika, geography, psychology, umwelt theory, history and a whole bunch of tigers. In a land farther beyond Siberia, in the Russian Far East, Vaillant tells the true story of a tiger attack on a man in the late 90s. Reconstructing the crime scene, exploring motivations (man and beast) and the investigation and pursuit of the (possibly injured) tiger follow. All of this is done in 40 degree below temperatures in a place where roads don't exist, often with ancient guns and homemade bullets. In the Russian Far East, families have lived with tigers for centuries, often in a precarious balance. Sadly, often money becomes the greatest motivator. The Asian Black Market for tigers has increased poaching in the area and adds a dangerous element to communities already living on the edge.

The Tiger was one of Amazon's best books of August of this year, and was well reviewed in the Sunday Book Review. While this book isn't true crime in the strictest sense, fans of that non-fiction genre may also enjoy this book. This book could also be easy to recommend to readers of well-written action non-fiction similar to authors like Simon Winchester and Jon Krakauer.

I couldn't put this book down!

entry.title: Book Lust to Go
entry.content:
Nancy Pearl is probably the most famous librarian in America. She routinely appears on NPR's Morning Edition discussing books and started the "one book, one community" type reading initiatives while working as a librarian in Seattle. She even has her own action figure!
Pearl is also the author of several books about books. She published Book Lust: Recommended Reading for Every Mood, Moment and Reason in 2003 and followed up with More Book Lust and Book Crush (recommended readings for teens and children). Ok, I admit it. I haven't read any of these books. I am a librarian and spend my days reading about books anyway so my "to-read" list tends to be long without Nancy Pearl adding to it. But when I heard her newest book is called Book Lust to Go: Recommended Reading for Travelers, Vagabonds, and Dreamers, I knew it was for me. The book isn't something that necessarily is best read cover to cover, but used as a reference. Short 1-2 page paragraphs cover different geographic areas and she recommends for each fiction, non-fiction and memoirs - not just armchair travel books, but any book worthy of Pearl's critical eye that successfully evokes a strong sense of place - something I highly enjoy in a fiction book. Pearl is serious when necessary, but can also be lighthearted and funny too. She begins the chapter on Ireland, "let's not start with James Joyce and just say we did, okay?" Another beauty of this book is to skip around and read what intrigues you. I admit to totally skipping the Baltimore and Philadelphia chapters entirely - for me to skip whole chapters of a book is a big deal!
Nancy Pearl and I disagree on a few titles she recommends in this book, most notably Into Thick Air and Dark Star Safari (both of which I didn't care for)...but we agree on so much more. She and I apparently share a love for Simon Winchester, Peter Hessler (enough good things can't be said about River Town: Two Years on the Yangtze), Luis Alberto Urrea, Alan Paton, Edwige Danticat and David Benioff's City of Thieves - that I just have to trust her on making additional suggestions. A few titles I could not resist adding to my "to-read" list:

A Voyage for Madmen by Nichols
Chronicle in Stone by Kadare
Where Underpants Come From by Bennett
Doghead by Ramsland
Madonnas of Leningrad by Dean
The City and The City by Mieville
A Beautiful Place to Die by Malla Nunn

entry.title: Martin Van Buren: the Romantic Age of American Politics
entry.content:
by John Niven
Matty Van Buren, alleged illegitimate son of Aaron Burr (according to his enemies), perennial bottom dweller in the "best president of all time" polls, unknown guy from a little known time--why bother reading about him when I could be keeping up with the latest pop star jailbird, or stew about today's political outrage? The truth is that dwelling in the antebellum period of American history allows me to escape all that even if it has some oddly familiar parallels to today.

For instance, the economy was in the tank. Andrew Jackson had just busted the chops of the Bank of the United States but that really wasn't the problem. The problem was that during a real estate bubble the world economy went into the tank and took everything else with it. Poor old van Buren thought he had a handle on it by creating the first sub-treasury system (taking control of the flow of money from the private bankers) only to lose it all to a greater power. This book allowed me to get a different perspective on the antics of Jackson, Clay, Calhoun, and their many subordinates.

Van Buren was important. He built one of the first political machines (the Albany Regency) and was a "fixer" extraordinaire, then went on to become president but, like the first George Bush, he was a prisoner of the previous president's policies and paid the price for the collapse of the economy. He was more of a "nuts and bolts" kind of guy than a visionary like Jackson and probably should have stayed behind the scenes, or at least in the Senate. As it is he's best remembered for being unmemorable. Nevertheless, he was a very astute guy who had the nation's good foremost in his mind.

What I found most intriguing was his later run for the presidency with the "Free Soil" Party (disaffected Democrats who opposed slavery i.e., farmers who didn't want to compete against slavers). For a man whose first principle was loyalty to the party it seems inconsistent. But urged on by his son John he'd caught the wave that was carrying the nation into the Civil War. We can only hope it was on principle.

One of our greatest "Forgotten" presidents.

link.title: Martin Van Buren: the Romantic Age of American Politics

entry.title: Man Booker Winner 2010
entry.content:
The Finkler Question by Howard Jacobson tells the story of three men and follows their friendship as they tackle the most difficult subjects of aging, success, family and what it means to be Jewish in a 21st century world. Howard Jacobson beat out 2 time Man Booker winner Peter Carey, and one of the current it-books, Room by Emma Donoghue to win the 2010 Man Booker Prize.

“A terrifying and ambitious novel, full of dangerous shallows and dark, deep water. It takes in the mysteries of male friendship, the relentlessness of grief and the lure of emotional parasitism.” - The Guardian UK

The Man Booker Prize is awarded every year for a work of fiction written by a citizen of the Commonwealth or the Republic of Ireland.

entry.title: Eaarth: Making Life on a Tough New Planet
entry.content:
Environmentalist Bill McKibben's latest book should be read by everyone. Not only does it explain climatic change for the lay reader, but it shows why the author believes that we have irrevocably damaged our planet. Eaarth is no typo, McKibben reports that we have changed our world so much, especially in the last fifty years, that it is an entirely different planet. And even if we can lower our carbon dioxide output immediately, our planet will not be the same for our children's and even our grandchildren's lifetimes.

There are lots of numbers in this book, but you only need to remember one: 350 ppm. That's the maximum amount of parts per million of carbon dioxide that most scientists believe should be in the atmosphere to maintain a stable climate. Already we have exceeded that number, and we're rapidly barreling toward 400. McKibben details some stark changes that have already happened: megastorms and floods, huge changes in mountain snow patterns that will affect agriculture in California and much of Asia, a massive investation of pine beetles that threatens western forests, and devastating forest fires.

McKibben, an activist as well as environmental writer, offers in the final chapter a more hopeful section about what we can do to stabilize our climate and to lessen the environmental damage. He ardently thinks that we need to develop local agricultural and communication systems, work together and share ideas on the internet, and make many changes in our lives--both small and large--that can add up to big changes worldwide. At one point McKibben says that it is our fate to live at this point of crisis. Can we do what is necessary to save our vulnerable green planet? Two books on similar themes are: The Fate of Nature: Rediscovering our Ability to Rescue the Earth by Charles Wolforth and Collapse: How Societies Choose Whether to Fail or Succeed by Jared Diamond.

link.title: Eaarth: Making Life on a Tough New Planet

entry.title: The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake
entry.content:
Aimee Bender's second novel, bittersweet and lyrical, is an exploration into the burdens and gifts of family love. The Los Angeles Edelsteins are an odd bunch: the dad, a lawyer and seemingly the most normal, hates hospitals and never enters them even for the births of his children. The mom, Lane, can never settle on one interest. Joseph, the son, has a bizarre habit of totally disappearing, and Rose, the youngest, has a strange relationship to food: she can taste where each ingredient comes from and the emotional state of the cook who has combined the ingredients.

It's a coming of age novel, one with semi-magical properties, but with the LA world of busy streets, palm trees, joggers, and apartments around courtyards firmly drawn in. Bender writes achingly beautiful passages about family members almost connecting but not quite. There's a grandmother in Oregon who never visits but sends more and more of her worldly possessions to Rose's family in LA. Joseph is extremely scientific but will never live a normal life. And Rose's happiness is also in question. But she has an enquiring mind and a quest for experience. Her journey. the book's journey, is learning to accept who you are and accepting your strangest skills as opportunities. An interesting trip down Food Lane, but in no way is this a foodie novel. To sample another novel with a strange mix of the real and the mythical, try Lauren Groff's The Monsters of Templeton. Another recent novel with a food emphasis, but with a more traditional bent, is The Cookbook Collector by Allegro Goodman.

link.title: The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake

entry.title: 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature
entry.content:
The 2010 Nobel Prize for Literature was announced on Thursday and awarded to Peruvian author Mario Vargas Llosa, writer of fiction, essays, literary criticism and journalism. The Nobel Prize for Literature has been awarded 109 times since 1901 to an author from any country in recognition of an outstanding body of work. The prize usually isn't awarded to any particular title, but to the author's overall contribution to literature.
Vargas Llosa is most well known for his fiction, especially The Time of the Hero, The Green House, and Conversation in the Cathedral - a serious political work examining the failures and corruption of Peruvian politics. Some of Vargas Llosa's later works fall in the frequently uses humor, including Captain Pantoja and the Secret Service and Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter. More recently (2000), Vargas Llosa published The Feast of the Goat, an ambitious political thriller.
Well known in Latin America, Vargas Llosa isn't necessarily a household name in the United States, though the Monroe County Public Library owns many of his titles. Maybe its time to pick up a new - and internationally celebrated - author?

entry.title: Randa Abdel-Fattah
entry.content:
One of the things I love about novels is to read something that shows wildly different human perspectives but yet at it's core is still identifiable. I have recently discovered Young Adult author, Randa Abdel-Fattah. Her first two novels are about Muslim Australian teenagers, but also contain the universal theme of fitting in and standing up for what you believe in under the pressures of high school peers. Her books are written in a way that is realistic and extremely touching.
Does My Head Look Big in This tells the story of Amal, a smart fiery Palestinian Australian teenager who has decided to begin wearing the hijab full time - to her public high school, on the bus and even to the mall (one of her favorite activities). Amal worries (sometimes rightfully so) about the reactions from her peers, principal, and community to her covered head. Amal is also dealing with a relationship with a non-Muslim boy at her school and shows her true character and Abdel-Fattah's delicate touch.
Abdel-Fattah's follow up book, Ten Things I Hate About Me, is also about fitting in while remaining true to yourself. Lebanese-Australian Jamilah is known as Jamie at school where no one knows of her true roots. Jamilah is torn between her love for her culture, music and faith and being liked by her friends at school. Jamilah's choices are difficult and the path isn't always easy. However, Jamilah is extremely likable and I really enjoyed this book.
Both of these books contain a strong female teenage character and are easy to recommend to most teenagers who may be struggling to fit in. I am looking forward to additional books by Abdel-Fattah - looks like she has a new book coming out in November 2010!

entry.title: A Secret Kept
entry.content:
In Tatiana De Rosnay's new French thriller, Antoine decides to take his sister for a surprise trip on Melanie's fortieth birthday. They travel to the French island of Noirmoutier where they spent summers during their childhood. Noirmoutier Island has one amazing feature--its enormous tides roll back exceedingly fast and sometimes strand drivers on the mainland. This could be a metaphor for childhood memories, how quickly they are erased. During the birthday weekend both siblings are reminded of their mother who died the last summer they spent on the island.

On the way home, Melanie whose mood has darkened considerably as their holiday ends, tells her brother she remembers something important about the past. She becomes so affected by this memory that she skids off the road, nearly killing herself. This brings the family to her hospital bed, including their emotionally distant father.

This family secret like most family secrets, is subject to interpretation, and its truth can never be fully authenticated. Like the tidal channel between the mainland and Noirmouteir Island, its real foundation has been washed away by time. But the secret when finally shared makes Antoine call into question all his relationships, particularly those with his own three children, who have had to deal with his divorce.

This novel shows how hiding information from children can create a kind of poison that affects their relationships lifelong. It also examines the nature of parenting, and how to maintain a close sibling bond. It also offers a delightful love story, discovered in a very unusual place. Readers who like sibling stories with a secret at the core might also enjoy Lisa See's Shanghai Girls and Elizabeth Berg's The Art of Mending .

entry.title: Banned Books Week
entry.content:
Banned Books Week is an annual event held during the last week in September to celebrate the freedom of expression and to serve as a reminder of the harms of censorship and restricting the availability of books. The American Library Association's website remind us of the "benefits of free and open access to information". Interestingly enough, the Monroe County Public Library's Mission Statement echos this statement by our commitment to offer "equitable access to information".

Banned book lists are often misleading, and some circles have taken to calling them challenged books as not every book that is challenged ends up getting banned - often thanks to outspoken and dedicated teachers, educators and librarians.

View ALA's guide to banned or challenged books for 2010 and celebrate your freedom to choose!

entry.title: Books Plus October: Brooklyn by Colm Toibin
entry.content:
“Eilis had always presumed that she would live in the town all her life, as her mother had done, knowing everyone, having the same friends and neighbors, the same routines in the same streets, she had expected that she would find a job in the town, and then marry someone and give up the job and have children. Now, she felt that she was being singled out for something for which she was not in any way prepared.” - Brooklyn by Colm Toibin
Eilis Lacey, the character at the center of Toibin's beautiful novel is unprepared for her move from Enniscorthy, Ireland to New York in 1951. This character and her experiences will stay with you long after the book is finished. Join us to discuss this novel on Sunday at the Monroe County Public Library's book discussion, Books Plus.

For more details, see below. Hope you can make it.

entry.title: Remarkable Creatures by Tracy Chevalier
entry.content:
The early to mid 19th century marks the beginning of the modern science of geology. New observations and discoveries were challenging the then current accepted theories about the age of the Earth and God's creatures on it. One aspect of the book is how the scientists and the churchmen tried to rectify the evidence of an earth much older than that found in church idealogy, with God's teachings from the Bible, an issue which is still discussed in the 21st century.
Two little known British women were indirect players in the development of the new science through their years, even decades, of searching for, collecting and examining fossils.
In Southwestern England at Lyme Regis young Mary Anning had been collecting curies as she called them, or fossils from the cliffs along the beach since she was a small child. Her finds brought a little much needed money into the family coffers. Elizabeth Philpot was a spinster living with her brother and two sisters in the family home in London until he married and the three unwanted sisters had to leave. Elizabeth and her sisters chose Lyme Regis as their new home. Elizabeth met Mary on beach and also became interested in fossils, especially fish fossils.
Remarkable Creatures is a fictionalized account of their lives based on journal and newspaper articles of the time and biographies of the two women. Mary discovered the first ichthyosaur, which she called a crocodile, the first plesiosaurs, which she called a turtle and the first complete pterosaur. Elizabeth collected and labeled drawers full of fossil fish which are now housed at the Oxford University Museum of Natural History. Neither woman was ever given much recognition for her discoveries but they were instrumental in furthering the science of geology.
The book includes an extensive bibliography of sources used. An epilogue contains the story of what became of Mary and Elizabeth and their discoveries.
