entry.title: New Book Buzz
entry.content:
I don't often read very new books and therefore blog about new books. My reading list is long and rich and the hold list for popular new titles is often long, so I am content to wait. This fall though there are several new titles that are creating a buzz that I am anxious to read.

A post about book buzz isn't complete these days without mention of American literary darling, Jonathan Franzen. His new book has been garnering rave reviews and currently sits atop the New York Times Best Seller list. Freedom has been years in the making and follows the similar suburban tragedy route as The Corrections, his National Book Award winning title of 9 years ago.

I first read about John Vaillant's The Tiger: A True Story of Vengeance and Survival on NPR a week ago and promptly added it to my list. This non-fiction book is centered around the 1997 death of a Russian poacher by a tiger who he had previously wounded. Part natural history, part Russian history and chilling animal science appear together under the guise of a page-turning thriller.

Shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize, Room by Emma Donoghue is also making a bit of a buzz. The book looks disturbing, but praise from author Michael Cunningham confirms its merits too. "Room is that rarest of entities, an entirely original work of art. I mean it as the highest possible praise when I tell you that I can't compare it to any other book. Suffice to say that it's potent, darkly beautiful, and revelatory."

British literary darling, David Mitchell has a new book out that may be one of the more literary titles on the New York Times Best Seller list (though coming in at number 34). The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet is a typical historical romance, but described as rich and original. Mitchell's previous epic (and one of my all time favorites), The Cloud Atlas is being made into a movie with names like Hanks, Portman, McKellen and Halle Berry attached.

And last but not least is Conversations with Myself by Nelson Mandela. While it won't be released until October 11, I am really looking forward to this book. Mandela has pulls together a great library of his previous personal materials together and offers insight into one of the most inspirational figures of our time.

And speaking of book buzz, don't forget that Oprah will have one more title in her Book Club before her show goes off the air. The announcement will be made this Friday, September 17.

These books look like they are worth waiting for!

entry.title: Game Change
entry.content:
Well, I finally got around to reading John Heilemann and Mark Halperin's Game Change, or, more properly, Game Change: Obama and the Clintons, McCain and Palin and the Race of a Lifetime. Even though I am way behind the game on this one after having put it off for so long, I thoroughly enjoyed it. Even better, I actually ended up feeling like some distance from the events in question helped make the book more readable absent a journalistic environment saturated with the events and individuals profiled in the book.

I will, however, caution the potential reader against interpreting this book as a profile of the 2008 election from all viewpoints mentioned on the front cover. In the end, the bulk of the text is devoted to the protracted primary battle between Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. Even at almost 450 pages, McCain and Palin are scarcely mentioned until the halfway point. The authors don't really address this fact directly, and the reader is left to assume that the McCain campaign was either less interesting overall or that the author's had more access to the Democrats' campaigns. Whatever the reason, the McCain-Palin campaign is ultimately forced to share the second half of the book with the final general election battle between McCain and Obama, a contest which, oddly enough, gets even less discussion than either party's primary battle.

If this all seems somewhat at odds with the book's ostensible scope, well, it is and it isn't. I certainly expected to be presented with a more topically balanced picture of the 2008 election, or at least a greater focus on the general election fight. However, the book is ultimately less about the actual events than it is about the players in the game. Heilemann and Halperin spend most of their time profiling individuals - Barack Obama, Bill & Hillary Clinton, Sarah Palin and host of other major and minor actors - and doing their best to extrapolate thoughts from actions.

The political process behind the scenes is the real story here. Taking a look at the why behind what in the political arena makes up the meat of the book and helps to keep it relevant. For this reason, Game Change is an excellent book to read in advance of the 2010 midterm elections, as it puts into perspective the many silent (and not-so-silent) motives that underlie candidates' actions on the political stage. While the authors do very little in the way of critical analysis, the attentive reader will put this book down with a sharper eye turned toward the present political environment. To this end, the book is well worth a read, even if you're a little late in picking it up.

entry.title: The Postmistress
entry.content:
Sarah Blake's book is the best novel I've read in years. Compelling and passionate, it's grounded by strong, interesting, and predominantly female characters. In fact, three women's stories are braided together to form a thoroughly believable look at what people at home experienced during World War II.

One is the postmistress of Franklin, MA., a small town far out on Cape Cod--one of the first sites the Nazis might attack with U-boats. Iris James loves order, precision, and correctness, and although a newcomer to Franklin, she soon becomes a daily part of people's lives. Also new to town is Emma Fitch, recently married to Franklin's one doctor. Emma, an orphan, who lost all her family to influenza as a child, does not feel whole without someone looking out for her. And that someone is Dr. Fitch, who is trying desperately to revive his family's reputation after it was ruined by his alcoholic father. The third strong character and the one who almost steals the book is radio gal, Frankie Bard, who lives in London and through hard work, persistence, and sheer talent has become the first woman to broadcast about the Blitz. The London bomb scenes--both above and below ground--are so realistic that you almost feel the earth shudder and buildings shake.

What Blake does expertly is to capture the emotional resonance of living through a war through the small, myriad details: Lucky Strikes, gramophones, the feel of a letter inside a pocket, bucolic dune scenes, a cafe where customers grouse about the Nazis, the big bus rumbling in from Boston--all feel amazingly authentic. Edward R. Murrow is Frankie's boss. He reluctantly allows her to board trains in Europe and record the voices of displaced Jews--refugees racing to escape Germany and Eastern Europe to survive. Frankie thinks that one of the "impossible absurdity of war was that the trains between countries still ran."

There are love stories here, but what The Postmistress centers on is our need to pay attention, to not look the other way when horror, prejudice, and murder happen. Also, the novel teaches us to live each moment fully, passionately, and with honor. And it's not only soldiers that should do that but all of us.

Other books that focus on World War II at the home front are The Guernsey Literary Potato Peel Society and Helen Humphrey's Coventry.

entry.title: Abraham Lincoln: With Malice Towards None
entry.content:
by Stephen B. Oates


I had originally decided not to read a Lincoln bio since Lincoln is one president that I know something about but the Fillmore and Buchanan bios gave such a "peculiar" perspective towards Lincoln, Seward, Weed, and other so-called "black" or "radical" Republicans, that I needed to get their side of the story. Also this book popped off the shelf when I was idly looking at recently published history at the library.

There were a few surprises. Considering how the South reacted to Lincoln's election I definitely didn't realize how far Lincoln and his administration were willing to compromise. His line was drawn at the spread of slavery, not its existence. Yet he went farther than anyone except the Abolitionists in embracing the quintessential American ideal: "...all men are created equal..."

It's very much a lesson in how people shape reality to fit their expectations rather than the other way around. It didn't matter what Lincoln said, the South always took it the way modern political opponents twist the meaning of everything Obama says. It would be funny if it wasn't so unnecessary.

Lincoln, though, was incredible. He learned from his mistakes—which were plentiful—endured personal tragedy and inconstant support by his loved ones, and harnessed some of the premiere prima donnas of American history. Should he have bothered? I don't know. The North and South probably would have fought over expansion anyway. But he took a stand for what was right.

The Lincoln story is so huge that this book is at best a well-informed overview. It's well written and sympathetically evokes Lincoln the man, not the icon.

I've still got a few antebellum presidents to clean up—Zachery Taylor and the 2nd volume on Pierce, and maybe Madison. I'd like to know more about Thomas Hart Benton, Sam Houston, Seward and Weed, and the Abolitionists. I'm also heading South to read about the folks who started the whole shebang, maybe read a full bio of Jefferson Davis, Alexander Stephens, and a little more on Toombs, Rhett, Cobb, and their ilk. Sadly, I'm starting to think that conventional wisdom is right and that the issue was slavery all along. It takes hubris to be a slave owner, an autocratic, unyielding state of mind that can't admit mistake. I've gone a long way to come back to the beginning.

link.title: Abraham Lincoln: With Malice Towards None

entry.title: The Party: The Secret World of China's Communist Rulers
entry.content:
While I am generally skeptical about any book with a title that purports to expose the "secret history" or "secret world" of anything, Richard McGregor's The Party: The Secret World of China's Communist Rulers turned out to be an unnerving delight.

McGregor, an Australian journalist who has worked extensively in China, does his best to explain China's secrecy-laden political environment to a Western audience, and, despite how cliche I may find the title, it is definitely a secret world. He examines the Communist Party's role in economic and social matters, touching on everything from recent reforms permitting limited entrepreneurship on one hand to the strict media controls exercised by the Party's propaganda arm on the other.

McGregor has certainly done a comprehensive job of reporting on a state in which journalistic freedoms are often severly limited. Further, the book is written very well and the more complex aspects of the Chinese state and Party government aparatus are made much clearer by the author's judicious use of comparison to Western governments.

What stands to be particularly striking to the observant reader are the many reverse parallels to the U.S. system of government. As I read through the numerous examples McGregor presents to illustrate the extent to which business in China is beholden to the Party I kept thinking about the manner in which corporate interests are often entrenched in the U.S. government, just the reverse of the Chinese situation in some ways. The author does not make this comparison explicitly, though. In fact, one gets the sense that he is personally more critical of the Party than he expresses, perhaps as a result of experience gained over years of working in the country.

While slightly more academic at times than the similarly interesting and illuminating portrait of Iran painted by Hooman Majd in The Ayatollah Begs to Differ (also highly recommended), this is an excellent read for anyone interested in history, politics or economics, or anyone who just wants to know a little bit more about an often mysterious country in charge of a significant amount of U.S. government debt. If China's rise to the status of a global power is frequently confusing and/or seemingly contradictory, McGregors books should help clear up a lot of confusion.

link.title: The Party: The Secret World of China's Communist Rulers

entry.title: The Possessed: Adventures with Russian Books and the People Who Read Them
entry.content:
Anna Karenina is one of my favorite books, and as someone who has read many Russian novels and memoirs, I can relate to Elif Batuman's passion for Russian literature. This book is a love story, not to a particular person but to a whole culture and its prized books. Like many people, it took Batuman some time and many detours to find her life's calling. (Imagine explaining to your parents why you are studying Uzbek.) For anyone who has ever longed to travel to the birthplaces of famous authors and experience their homeland firsthand this is their book.

Batuman is passionate about Russian authors and incredibly knowledgeable. And she's the rare academic (she now teaches at Stanford), who can dig up funny, quirky, and amazingly interesting stories. Exhibit A: did you know there is a connection between Isaak Babel and King Kong?

One very amusing chapter describes her trip to a Tolstoy conference at his former estate, Yasnaya Polyana. Here, Batuman details the papers presented by other scholars all the while musing how Tolstoy may have been murdered. The author had to wear her flannel shirt and sweatpants (donned for sleeping on the overnight plane) for most of the week because her suitcase never arrived. This convinced the other researchers that she was a Tolstoyan, a follower of Tolstoy's beliefs about living simply with as few material possessions as possible.

I love books that inspire journeys, even if they are only arm-chair ones for the reader. The Possessed certainly fits that bill. Experience St. Petersburg's Ice Palace and wild, remote Samarkand. And if you love the great Russian authors, this book will only reinforce why you find that literature so appealing. Recommended for those who enjoyed accounts of reading in various cultures: Ann Fadiman's Ex Libris, Edmund White's Our Paris, Schlink's The Reader, and Nafisi's Reading Lolita in Tehran.

link.title: The Possessed: Adventures with Russian Books and the People Who Read Them

entry.title: "A Government of Our Own": The Making of the Confederacy
entry.content:
by William C. Davis

This book is about three months in the life of a small Alabama town when the Confederacy was born. I kept thinking it would make a moderately less violent television series ala Deadwood. Lots of compelling personalities with itchy trigger fingers.

I liked this author's book Three Roads to the Alamo, about William Travis, Jim Bowie, and Davy Crockett. This is a far denser read. Even with my interest in the subject I found myself lagging at times.

The Confederates liked to think they were statesmen on par with the Founding Fathers, but in fact they were more akin to the bootblacks who shined Ben Franklin's shoes. It's almost funny when it begins to dawn on a few of them that they can never fix what's wrong with government when the real problem is what's wrong with themselves.

I have two complaints with the book. The first is about Davis's use of "Little Aleck" to describe the Confederate vice-president and moderate Alexander Stephens. The similarity to the name of the Clockwork Orange protagonist is disconcerting enough, but it also diminishes a brilliant man who overcame cruel physical deformity. Stephens was one of the few people (besides Jefferson Davis) who saw clearly the danger they'd placed themselves in.

My second complaint is that Davis often uses Mary Chesnut's judgment about a character without seeming to consider that occasionally she may have been wrong. I'm not saying she was, just that I would have liked corroborating evidence.

That said, the book sets the scene very well and is a good introduction to a society at its peak, right before they drove their Cadillac off the cliff.

link.title: "A Government of Our Own": The Making of the Confederacy

entry.title: Bonobo Handshake: a Memoir of Love and Adventure in the Congo
entry.content:
Vanessa Woods, a journalist and primate researcher, spent her twenties trying out various jobs and travelling, especially around Africa. She volunteered at a chimp rescue center and discovered how much she enjoyed working with primates, particularly one young male, Baluka, whom she raised (mostly on her left hip) through infancy. On a return trip to the chimp center, she met a young American researcher and fell in love. This is the story of their odyssey together to a bonobo sanctuary in war-torn Congo.

Vanessa, an Aussie, is irreverent and saucy, and, at first, not scientifically minded. To help with her husband's research, she must learn to be exacting and follow protocols. And help she must. The bonobos at this sanctuary in the Congo, unlike chimps, will have almost nothing to do with male humans. They live in a French speaking country, and Vanessa must interpret for her husband. Vanessa, too, has other preoccupations. Her Dad was a Vietnam vet, divorced from her Mom, and for years, Vanessa has tried and failed to understand his interpersonal problems and fears. She decides that living in a war-zone will give her some insight into how the war affected her father and changed his life.

The bonobos themselves are endearing--smart, playful, cooperative, and highly sexual. The latter point is most striking. "Make love not war" has been used to describe bonobo culture. Sex is one way they deal with conflict and forge cooperative ties with other bonobos, making them the most peaceful of primates

Bonobos share 98.7% of their genes with humans. They are also endangered with only about 5,000 left in the world. Her account reminds one of the wildlife narratives of Jane Goodall and Dian Fossey, but has more of a personal and travelogue focus. Woods shows us why this loving and lovable species is so important to us. She believes that the work, that she, her husband, and the other scientists are doing might eventually help humans understand our own warlike nature.

link.title: Bonobo Handshake: a Memoir of Love and Adventure in the Congo

entry.title: Who Says Summer isn't a Good Time for Non-Fiction?
entry.content:
I was reading Soccernomics, which I am really enjoying and blogged about back in June, over lunch today when a coworker mentioned that a dense non-fiction book didn't seem like summer reading. To which I say, why not?

I love contemporary fiction and non-fiction with equal passion. And summer seems like a perfect time to dive into something dense, thought provoking, AND true! With the rare exception (one being River Town by Peter Hessler - a wonderful book about his 2 years spent teaching English at a teacher's college in rural China as a Peace Corps worker) memoirs and biographies aren't as interesting to me as historical non-fiction. Some of my all-time favorites include:

Zeitoun by Dave Eggers
This is the story of Abdulrahaman Zeitoun, a successful businessman and Syrian American, who stayed in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina. What happens is both beautiful and horrific. My esteem for Eggers as a writer and as a social agent for change increases with every work he does. This book is both interesting and an important chronicle the historical and contemporary failings of America.

The Devil's Highway by Luis Umberto Urrea
In 2001, a group of illegal Mexican immigrants attempted to cross the desert in Arizona to work in the United States for a year, a season, forever. 14 of them died in ways that are hard to imagine and terrifying to read about. They became known as the Yuma 14. This book was written with input from both survivors and border police. The economics of body movement, immigration and death of poor men from Veracruz is astonishing and heartbreaking, but important to chronicle.

The Worst Hard Time by Timothy Egan
The story of the Dust Bowl of the 1930s is expertly told by Egan and his efforts won him the National Book Award for Non-Fiction. Even non-history geeks like me will appreciate the parallels that Egan draws between current argi-politics and behaviors both then and now. This book is neglectfully left off lists about climate and environmental change.

The Great Influenza by John M. Barry
H1N1! Swine Flu! If you think that the media overplayed any hype of a health epidemic last winter, this book is for you. How epidemics begin, travel, kill, and end are expertly related here along with some general history of Western medicine. It just might make you break out the surgical masks and gloves.

The Professor and the Madman by Simon Winchester
10,000 of the early definitions for the Oxford English Dictionary were submitted by William C. Minor. Amazing? The story gets better - Minor was a patient at an insane asylum who was there because he was found not guilty of murder based on grounds of insanity. Winchester also has a geology background and his Krakatoa is equally amazing.

Next on my list to read are:
War by Sebastian Junger (author of the excellent Perfect Storm)
D-Day: Battle for Normandy by British historian Antony Beevor (author of 900 Days)
Fordlandia: The Rise and Fall of Henry Ford's Forgotten Jungle City by Greg Grandin

What are your favorite non-fiction reads?

link.title: Who Says Summer isn't a Good Time for Non-Fiction?

entry.title: Mary Chesnut's Civil War
entry.content:
Edited by C. Vann Woodward

I kept thinking of Scarlett O'Hara while reading this. It's the portrait of a hot-blooded, cocky, pugnacious society that was teetering on the brink of destruction, like Carthage during the Punic Wars.

It's hard to have much sympathy. Chesnut is snide, hard-nosed, delusional, insightful, and vulnerable all at the same time. Her view into the minds and actions of the Confederate upper crust as things crumble around them touched my heart even as their motivation escaped me.

The irony is that once the hotheads had their way they were shoved aside and spent the rest of the war kvetching on the sidelines, excreting the same poisonous grease onto their own side as they'd poured on Lincoln and the North a few scant months before.

Chesnut's book was originally published in a truncated edition after her death. Here Woodward has pieced together and deciphered her original text giving Chesnut's portraits of the Civil War's most compelling personalities a modern freshness that everyone can enjoy.

entry.title: Leaving Rock Harbor
entry.content:
Poughkeepsie girls are tough. This slogan applies to Frances (Frankie) Ross, but at age fourteen after her father attempts suicide, the family starts all over in the fictional mill town of Rock Harbor, Massachusetts. This complex coming of age novel details Frankie's flowering into womanhood and her friendship and later romances with two young men: Winslow Curtis, son of a senator and owner of the mill, and Joe Barros, poor and Portuguese, who is befriended by the Curtis family because he's star of the basketball team. Frankie loves the lifestyle of the Curtis's but intellectually and emotionally is more drawn to Joe. At first the boys simply befriend her, take her for drives in Winslow's Model T, invite her to swim in the ocean. It's just before the first world war, when young women's mothers squeezed thems into corsets, and when showing an ankle was highly provocative.

Joe and Frankie's dad both work for the cotton mill. And though cotton when finished feels very soft, unmilled cotton can be very sharp and often draws blood. The war comes and the managers force the mill workers to produce more and more, but also cut wages. Conditions are hellish: brutally hot, young children work the floor retrieving fallen spools and objects. Sometimes, there are horrible fires and accidents that make workers loose fingers or hands.

Joe joins the war effort. Curtis and Frankie become closer and marry. The roaring twenties arrive and Frankie bobs her hair. Joe returns and becomes a nationally-known organizer. And Frankie is still drawn to both men for different reasons.

With lyrical writing and in-depth characterization, Rebecca Chase creates a believable mill town of the last century. Similar to the works of Thomas Mallon and Howard Norman, Chase transports us to the past with characters as rich as people we know. A fine reader for both young adults and adult readers who want a fascinating story told from the heart.

entry.title: Amongst Women
entry.content:
Michael Moran, a widower and veteran who fought for the IRA in the Irish War of Independence, treats his family as though they were soldiers under his command. The oldest son, Luke, has broken with him, moved to England and not contacted his father in years. But the three daughters, Mona, Maggie, and Sheila, are very respectful of him and always obey him even when his commands make no sense. The baby of the family, Michael, does so also until he reaches his teen years.

When McGahern's novel opens, Rose meets the reclusive farmer at the post office and something about his demeanor, his quiet intelligence draws her to him. The villagers are shocked by her aggressive pursuit of him, even though that entails no more than waiting in line with him at the post office each evening. Finally, she tells him that "he may visit her at home." Several days pass until he does, but this is enough to signal to everyone that they are almost engaged.

Farm work is hard and Moran is miserly with his funds. Nevertheless, Rose marries him, and she soon finds allies in his three daughters. Whereas, before when he returned, all conversation would stop, and all joy sweep from the room, now there is laughter and talk. But when Moran's darkest moods come, not even Rose dares oppose him.

Amongst Women is a taut, lyrical novel about the pull of family. Although the book is under two hundred pages, you feel tightly drawn into the Moran circle and continuously compare their family to your own. At one point Moran says that all civilization is based upon the family, and you can't help but wish he would have created a happier one. For a view of another Irish family, this time a fatherless one, read Tóibín's Brooklyn. Jane Smiley has captured an American farm family with another stern dad in A Thousand Acres.

entry.title: President James Buchanan: A Biography
entry.content:
by Philip S. Klein

One thing that distinguishes the presidents of the 1850s is that they were all "Party" men. Each built and maintained major party apparatus in their home states. They were all very skilled at the art of compromise and yet they all failed miserably when it came to trying to broker a compromise between North and South over the spread of slavery.

Instead of building a bridge between the two sides Buchanan helped tear them asunder with some perfectly terrible decisions—the worst being to support the Lecompton Constitution. If there is a linchpin to the break of civility between the two sides Bleeding Kansas is it and Buchanan's misjudgment over the severity of the issue pretty much symbolizes the futility of his administration. When an underling is always to blame for every miscue what does that say about the boss?

I haven't read enough to judge whether or not Buchanan was guilty of helping the South near the end of his administration. I would guess not, although his actions do leave room to wonder. Did he really expect the Lincoln administration to tie itself to his failed policy? Did he really expect a constitutional convention to solve anything? It boggles the mind, like Stephen Douglas helping to destroy the Missouri Compromise.

This biography is definitely biased towards its subject, which gives it refreshing insight into Buchanan's mind and reasons for acting the way he did. I came into the book expecting to blame him for everything and left feeling that he was as much a victim as anyone, trying to solve a modern problem with an outdated strategy.

entry.title: Plenitude
entry.content:
If you're interested in contemporary economic issues, Juliet Schor's Plenitude: The New Economics of True Wealth is a good, quick read with just enough engagingly disconcerting subject matter to get you thinking about how your own personal habits fit into the broader economic process.

In the book Schor takes a look at the variety of facets in our current market economy and prescribes a system she calls "plenitude" as a way to remedy the ills of the business-as-usual economy. Plenitude is not really an entirely new term, but Schor attempt to take its surface definition and expand it into a way of thinking about consumption in new ways. I was initially frustrated with the vagueness of the term, but I ended up satisfied with how it functions as a catchall, tying together divergent topics under a heading that is ultimately less cliche than, say, "less is more" or what have you.

In many ways the book is similar to another title I reviewed here, Raj Patel's The Value of Nothing, in that it is left-leaning, but not ideological and covers a lot of ground in a fairly short text. In fact, minus the copious notes, the book clocks in at less than 200 pages overall. So, this is a quick read, and more of an introduction to the plenitude way of thinking than an in-depth analysis. That said, if you're looking for an intellectually stimulating book this summer, this would be a great pick.

entry.title: Books Plus July: Little Bee by Chris Cleave
entry.content:
Our next book discussion will transport us to Africa and England to tell the stories of a young British mother and a Nigerian refugee she who was recently released from jail on immigration charges. Can these two women from vastly different worlds share experiences and become friends? This novel about cultures sometimes clashing, sometimes meshing is inspiring and raises many important questions. At one point, Little Bee says, “We must see all scars as beauty. Okay? This will be our secret. Because take it from me, a scar does not form on the dying. A scar means, I survived.” (p. 9).

entry.title: 44 Scotland Street
entry.content:
I have become hooked on the 44 Scotland Street series by Alexander McCall Smith. I had heard positive comments about his work, and I wanted to check it out for myself. McCall Smith has several series out, including the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency and the Isabel Dalhousie series, but as I am not a big mystery fan, I decided to try the 44 Scotland Street series first. I wasn't quite sure what to expect, but I really enjoy his style and can hardly read them fast enough. The 44 Scotland Street books are written as a newspaper serial, so the chapters are short, only a few pages in length, and they usually end with a slight cliffhanger, which makes for a quick read, as the momentum of the story keeps moving forward.

This series follows the lives of several people who live in the city of Edinburgh, centering around an apartment building at 44 Scotland Street. The characters are very real and human. They all have their flaws and distinct personalities, and I found myself reacting to each character and their individual personalities, such as Bruce, the narcissistic surveyor, Bertie, a six year old prodigy, Matthew, the somewhat introverted art gallery manager, and many others.

This series is very character driven, and though there is not much action, per se, one quickly becomes interested in the lives of the different characters and their individual problems and quirks. Each character has their own story, but that story, though distinct, is also interwoven and interconnected with the other characters in the series providing continuity throughout the work as the storyline alternates between characters.
Titles in the series are:
44 Scotland Street

Espresso Tales

Love Over Scotland

The World According to Bertie

The Unbearable Lightness of Scones

entry.title: Rainbows End
entry.content:
by Vernor Vinge
This novel is about Web 3 or 4.0. Considering that Vinge places his story about 18 years in our future (god willing) it makes figuring out a blog, IM, or searching in Google look like absolute child's play. Get ready for a time when the world you see is the world you want to see; when memory and experience mean less than good searching skills; when real life is more like Second Life than the other way around.

Follow the adventures of a crotchety poet revived from the depths of Alzheimer's, his precocious granddaughter and her "Miri Gang," and a Wascilly Wabbit as they become key players in an international plot to create a weapon of mass deception.

Vinge is a five time Hugo winner for his stories A Fire Upon the Deep (1992), A Deepness in the Sky (1999), Rainbows End (2006), Fast Times at Fairmont High (2002) and The Cookie Monster (2004) and one of the proponents of the (quickly) coming Technological Singularity.

Rainbows End is marked down a notch because the ending was a bit disappointing and seemed as much a setup for a sequel as a resolution.

entry.title: Solar
entry.content:
Booker Prize winner Ian McEwan tackles two hot subjects here: global warming and marital conflict. Solar, his 13th novel, presents a rare fictional look at a physicist, though an all too-flawed one. British Nobel Prize winner Michael Beard has brought his reputation and clout to a scientific foundation that has been set up to find solutions to global warming. However, Beard, whose best scientific work was done over twenty years ago, can barely focus on this new challenge--his fifth wife is having an affair with a man, their builder. In fact, she may be having two affairs. Beard himself has not been known for monogamy. According to Patrice's record-keeping, he's had at least eleven dalliances in their five year marriage. This time the shoe is on the other foot, and Beard can barely take it.

As in all McEwan's books, the writing is compelling, and the author's understanding and capturing of scientific terms, in fact, a scientist's mindset is breathtaking. But I almost put the book aside several times. Michael Beard is not a good man. Despite the off-putting egotism of Beard and the sheer immensity of the climate change problem, McEwan imparts humor. One scene presents the physicist on an Arctic journey. During a snowmobile ride to a ship, the feckless scientist zips himself into far too many clothes. Plus he's wearing cracked goggles that are so fogged up he is driving blind. Plus he has an urgent need for a bathroom. This scene is funny, although I suspect, more funny to men than to women.

I kept reading to see if this smart man could redeem himself and in the process help solve one of the world's most vexing problems. Like the protagonist himself, this is a flawed but interesting novel. Another main character who looks back on his life is Philip Roth's Everyman. Readers who enjoy the literary novels of Paul Auster and Martin Amis might also like this read.

entry.title: Help Me, Jacques Cousteau
entry.content:
Do you have any unusual relatives? I mean truly peculiar ones? Or have they leaped far past the bizarre to the absolutely strange? If so and even if not, you will enjoy this quirky collection of interconnected stories set in Canada. Gil Adamson, whose family has lived in Canada for eight generations, captures some of the spunky, can-do spirit of our northern neighbors. Hazel-the girl who tells these stories--has a dad who loves to rewire the house to calm down; besides a few minor electrocutions don't affect children forever. Hazel's Mom manages to high-step over live wires because of her high heels. Hazel's uncle is one of the world's best liars, along with someone who introduces the family to a great quantity of aunties, both married and not. And the abnormal has become normal to Hazel. Waking up to her uncle asleep in the bathtub? Not that unusual. Watching a goose sailing past thrown by said uncle--happens often enough--in fact, animal lovers might want to read with caution.

Gil Adamson captures that fill-in-the-puzzle quality of childhood of watching and listening to adults to learn about the world and relationships. The writing is on the whole light and funny and at the same time memorable. She captures many ah-ah moments when a child suddenly recognizes a connection and even those moments of puzzlement when something complex and challenging becomes much more than it first seemed. And Hazel, even though born mistakenly in a girl's body--she should have been the boy not her beautiful brother--is smart and endearing. Adamson said that her writing heroes are Michael Ondaatje, Richard Ford, and Ray Carver. She also shares the whimsical touch of Richard Brautigan in In Watermelon Sugar. And no, Jacques Cousteau is not a prominent character in this book, merely an image flying off a blue television screen.

entry.title: Mongrels, Bastards, Orphans and Vagabonds
entry.content:
To the extent that this book is not about immigration policy issues, but rather the evolution of Mexican and Mexican American ethnic/racial identity it was not what I expected. The full title, Mongrels, Bastards, Orphans and Vagabonds: Mexican Immigration and the Future of Race in America, seems to suggest a more direct discussion of policy issues than the author, Gregory Rodriguez, actually presents. Nonetheless, this is a very worthy book that ultimately presents a number of salient points relevant to the ongoing immigration policy discussions highlighted by Arizona's recently passed and oft-discussed law, SB 1070.

In the book, Rodriguez traces the evolution of a distinct Mexican identity from the time of conquest to the present day, highlighting the different conceptions of race and ethnicity in Mexican vs. American society. Immigration is mentioned in a historical context as Rodriguez describes the reasons behind the ebb and flow of Mexican immigrants over time, but these observations do not ultimately build to any concrete suggestions for future action. In fact, the book lacks any concluding remarks whatsoever. For better or worse, the reader is left to digest the history Rodriguez presents on his or her own.

It seems to me that in abdicating the role of policy advisor Rodriguez is really doing his book a favor. By focusing on Mexican identity in an outside of the U.S. he is able to make indirect, subtle points about immigration policy without ever saying anything too specific at all. Sticking to a strictly historical discussion, he succeeds in drawing out the often tragicomic elements of the contemporary immigration issue thus allowing the reader some implicit perspective on the current debate without imposing his personal viewpoint. Approaching the issue in this way will help this book remain relevant a lot longer than it would have had Rodriguez pulled in policy discussions. The book would also have had to be at least twice as long to accommodate a policy-oriented narrative, anyway.

Another result of Rodriguez's limited ethno-racial focus is that Mongrels... is also pleasantly nonpartisan. Apart from the fact that he makes no explicit policy recommendations, Rodriguez also steers clear of economic issues (e.g. NAFTA) and, most notably, avoids any mention whatsoever of the drug war. The text is stronger for these topical limitations, however, and the book is ultimately a very timely discussion of topics directly and indirectly related to a perennial political issue. Of course, there are books about immigration that involve a lot of rhetorical flourish, but this is definitely not one of them. Pick it up and see for yourself. You might be surprised at how far we have come on immigration, and how far we haven't.

entry.title: The Lacuna
entry.content:
I have been putting off writing about Barbara Kingsolver's newest novel, The Lacuna since I finished it a few weeks ago. Not because I didn't like it - quite the opposite, I loved it! - but somehow I keep thinking that whatever I write won't do this complex novel justice. This novel follows the reserved Harrison Sheppard over three decades, includes Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera and Leon Trotsky as characters and navigates the tricky political waters in both the United States and Mexico in the 40s and 50s - all in a very non-gimmicky way.
This week Barbara Kingsolver was also awarded the prestigious Orange Prize for fiction. This prize is awarded annually to female authors of fiction, regardless of their country of origin. This prize was created in 1996 in response to the 1991 all-male short list for the Man Booker Prize.
The Lacuna is award winning, intelligent and has an ending (I don't think I am giving anything away here) that actually made me gasp out loud in sheer delight.
This book is a slight departure for Kingsolver, but I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys historical fiction.

entry.title: The White Garden
entry.content:
When I picked this novel, I was expecting something somber but instead found a fairly light-hearted account of a young American’s trip to Sissinghurst, Vita Sackville-West’s famed estate. The gardens there are justly famous and still popular with tourists. Jo Bellamy, a gardener from Delaware, has recently snagged a wonderful commission, designing a garden based on the White Garden that Vita Sackville West made for her friend Virginia. Not only is Sissinghurst a dream location for a gardener, but Jo has a personal connection there—her grandfather-mentor worked there briefly as a young man during World War ll.

A rich financier, Graydon funds Jo’s trip, but shortly after she arrives, he calls and asks if he can join her. Jo is both intrigued and put off. Gray is a connoisseur of both women and wine and on his third power marriage. Jo decides that he is taking more of an interest in her than in their project. “Should I fly from South America to join you?” he asks. Jo is very confused—he is after all very attractive, but is her boss. And to complicate matters, in her first few days at the garden, she has stumbled upon an old notebook with her grandfather’s name upon the cover, and a woman’s journal inside. Just before coming to England, Jo told her grandfather about her project and though he seemed very happy for her, he killed himself the next day. Coincidental or related? (OK, the book does have some dark elements. Virginia Woolf comes to a bad end also.)

The beginning of the book drops you into the world of gardening where Barron is very much at home. But it’s her knowledge of the literary world of Bloomsbury that really makes the book sail. A young man, Peter, from the auctioning firm, Sotheby’s, comes to check out the discovered notebook. The writing style is indeed Virginia Woolf’s, and yes, the notebook seems to be authentic from the time period but the journal dates are terribly wrong. It opens on the day that Virginia supposedly drowned herself in the River Ouse.

Now begins a merry chase. Instead of returning the valuable book to the head gardener, Imogen, and in her stead, the true owners, the National Trust, Jo and Peter decide that they must take it to a Woolf expert, the super-lovely, Margaux, who besides being a leading feminist Woolf expert, also happens to be Peter’s ex. Margaux insists that she must check the handwriting overnight. So, Jo remains AWOL from Sissinghurst and from Gray who has flown to London to join her. And the next morning, Margaux does not show at the coffee shop. Nor does she return the notebook in question.

The pace picks up. Margaux has in her illegal possession a super valuable object that could change the whole course of world scholarship on Woolf. Peter decides they must figure out where she is going and get there first. So they race off to Charleston, the home of Virginia’s sister, Vita, where there supposedly is a clue to the white garden.

It’s a merry chase. You don’t have to be a Bloomsbury fan to love the journey: there are pubs, elevators in underground libraries, even a gravedigging scene at an old house. Barron knows her history and though she plays with actual facts, the reader is drawn into all the twists and turns of plot. Lawrence Block once said that fiction is nothing more than “telling lies for fun and profit.” I don’t know how much profit there is here, but this is a lovely escapade of a book for those who like light English mysteries, gardening tales, and the wonders of Bloomsbury. Readers who enjoyed Toibin’s The Master, Sellers’s, Vanessa & Virginia and Sissinghurst: a Portrait of a Garden will identify with this book.

entry.title: The Name of the Wind by Patrick Rothfuss
entry.content:
This bestselling fantasy novel describes the maturing of a boy that is destined to be a great hero. The format of this novel is unlike most other fantasy novels with Rothfuss telling the story through two lenses, a hero's recollection of his past and also the present of a scribe recording the hero's story. In this way Rothfuss keeps the readers on their toes, unknowing of both the past and the present.

The story begins in an small town inn with a red haired innkeeper and a few locals. At the same time, a famous scribe called Chronicler is travelling nearby. A day after getting robbed Chronicler stumbles upon a cloaked figure and then is involved in a fight against huge spiders demons. After the fight he is a carried to a nearby inn and discovers that his rescuer, the cloaked figure and red haired innkeeper, is Kvothe, a one of the greatest heroes of the time. Chronicle is then granted permission by Kvothe to write down Kvothe’s life story. Thus begins the story of the past: an epic journey of an extremely intelligent boy finding his way to greatness. He first spent his childhood in a traveling performance troupe. After his family is killed by the evil Chandarion beings he must find his own way in the world.

I will not spoil the book for you, but will say the rest of the book brings admiration for Kvothe’s strength and determination. In addition it brings back memories of childhood and being a teenager trying to find a place in the world. A surprise ending in the present brings this “can’t put it down” book to a close and leaves you eager for the second book of the this trilogy (The Wise Man’s Fear coming out in March 2011).

link.title: The Name of the Wind by Patrick Rothfuss

entry.title: World Cup Fever
entry.content:
I admit it, I have World Cup fever. I fully realize that this isn't a statement you hear too often in the United States, but as every soccer fan likes to remind those who rather watch American football, basketball, even (*gasp*) hockey over a soccer game, like it or not - this is truly the World's Sport. The 2010 FIFA World Cup starts June 11 and runs through July 11, played by the top 32 country teams in South Africa. The excitement begins!

Anyway, back to books. MCPL owns several soccer related titles that will both introduce readers to the sport and remind them just how passionate and diverse its fans can be.

The Glorious World Cup: A Fanatic's Guide by Alan Black
Filled with strange trivia, humor, amazing facts and general insight about the world's most popular game and the World Cup, this book is a must read for this year's championship season.

Soccernomics: Why England Loses, Why Germany and Brazil Win, and Why the U.S., Japan, Australia, Turkey--and Even Iraq--Are Destined to Become the Kings of the World's Most Popular Sport by Simon Kuper.
This book breaks down common held assumptions about soccer (and professional sports in general). Kuper, a journalist, is teamed up with an economist to take a scientific look at the sport and possibly be grounds for important changes to the game.

Among the Thugs by Bill Buford
A story of the train wreck that can be English soccer hooliganism. Journalist Buford spends some time in the 80s investigating the source of rabid soccer fans and describes how passion and good-natured zeal can turn into something violent and horrible.

More Than Just a Game: Soccer vs. Apartheid: The Most Important Soccer Story Ever Told by Chuck Korr and Marvin Close
Did you know that the Makana Football Association played all its games behind closed — and locked — doors on South Africa’s infamous Robben Island during the middle of the dark apartheid years? Not always glorious and uplifting, this story is both important and timely in its South African setting.

The Beckham Experiment: How the World's Most Famous Athlete Tried to Conquer America by Grant Wahl
Love him or hate him, most Americans can name one current professional soccer star: David Beckham. Telling the story of how sports and celebrity collide, this book takes us through the business side of soccer and its impact on American sport and culture.

Soccer in a Football World: The Story of America's Forgotten Game by David Wangerin
A soccer mad Wisconsinite, Wangerin, investigates America's love and apathy for the game. Detailing history, American rules and language (why are we the only country that calls it soccer?) this humorous book might even predict where soccer in America goes from here!

entry.title: Lambda Literary Awards
entry.content:
The 2010 Lambda Literary Awards were announced last week for excellence in lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans literature available in the United States.

entry.title: City at the End of Time
entry.content:
by Greg Bear
One of the best of current science fiction writers, City at the End of Time is Bear's latest novel. It takes place well beyond the end of the universe as we know it at a time when the universe has decayed into almost total chaos. The humans that are left are reaching back to an earlier time (our time) to try and save something from the encroaching chaos. We follow several of these people as they prepare to enter this chaos where none has returned.

We also follow a myriad of contemporary characters in modern Seattle (Bear's hometown) as they get recruited into this cause, which has everything to do with books and ancient knowledge.

This book left me a bit flummoxed. The plot appears to be a mating of ancient religion and current cosmology. I was left with the constant feeling that I was either missing something or simply didn't have enough knowledge of either of these subjects to completely enjoy the book.

On the other hand I did like that housecats help resolve the plot's crisis and that a major theme is about the power of books and of the written word. One of the more perplexing notions of modern physics is how observation changes the observed and Bear has extrapolated this notion to suggest that the universe needs to be observed to exist. Of course he also posits that words in books can change when they're not being read but I'll leave that idea as one more thing I don't understand about this book.

Recommended if you're familiar with Bear and want a good puzzle, otherwise go for one of his earlier works.

Greg Bear is the author of the Forge of God series, as well as one of my favorites, Darwin's Radio, and Moving Mars, for which he won the 1994 Nebula Award.

link.title: City at the End of Time

entry.title: The Value of Nothing
entry.content:
Why do we make certain choices over others? Why do we give to charitable causes, help out friends, buy reusable grocery bags, or, alternately, choose not to do any of these things? According to some theorists, the answer is that humans are essentially Homo economicus - economic man - hardwired to maximize personal benefit and profit. Altruism out, selfishness in. Even generous actions can be cast as being rooted in a desire for personal gain, whether we acknowledge it or not.

However, in The Value of Nothing: How to Reshape Market Society and Redefine Democracy, academic and activist Raj Patel deconstructs and critiques the concept of Homo economicus and takes aim at the philosophers and economists, most notably Gary Becker, who have shaped and promoted this rather bleak view of human nature as it has evolved over time.

In case you are wondering about the title, the book is ostensibly about pricing and how we determine the value of things like raw materials, labor and consumer goods. While this is true, the author approaches these issues indirectly - through other, more interesting, discussions about a diverse set of related topcs including food sovereignty, civic engagement, political will and corporate personhood. The latter concept stands to be particularly interesting to anyone following the various political reactions to the recent Supreme Court ruling in the Citizens United case. Patel eventually settles on a definition of Homo economicus built on the behavior of corporate "persons." He discusses the implications of this definition at some length, with more than a few interesting anecdotes and examples to flesh out his thought process.

While Patel is rather obviously situated on the ideological left, he does a sufficient job of outlining the practical limitations of the ideas that he promotes, taking special care to emphasize that he does not advocate (or consider beneficial, anyway) the complete overthrow of market society. Instead, his primary purpose is to convince the reader of the limits of markets to provide sufficient food security, land rights, health care and other essentials at fair value to those that are without them. Patel is no moderate, but his exposition of various solutions to our current (and future) economic woes happily lacks the excessive rhetorical flourish present in the writing of other authors in his ideological cadre. Overall, the book presents challenging ideas relevant to the present economic environment in very smooth, readable prose. Whether you end up agreeing with Patel or not, The Value of Nothing is a fun and provocative read.

entry.title: The Singing Life of Birds
entry.content:
If you wake most mornings to the dawn chorus of birds, and wonder which creatures are heralding the day, this is the book for you. Ornithologist Donald Kroodsma spoke here last month, and this book introduces the fascinating world of birdsong to the layman as well as the scientist. Kroodsma has been studying bird vocalizations since the 1960s trying to answer such questions as: how do young birds learn birdsongs, when do they learn them, do they learn only from their fathers (it's mostly males that sing), or do they learn their specific calls after they disperse to their own new territories? He also looks at why certain birds like mockingbirds and bowerbirds mimic other birds while crows and blackbirds imitate even mechanical sounds such as car alarms.

The author emphasizes that he didn't become a song expert by listening but by seeing. Although that sounds like a conundrum, what he means is that he tapes the calls, songs, and cries of these creatures and creates sonograms of them that he takes out and studies in fields, forests, and even his own backyard. Kroodsma presents some fascinating asides. He uses Venn diagrams to show how nearby males share certain songs with their neighbors and also have their own unique songs. He reports how one mockingbird sang over 465 songs in just over 26 minutes (take that Bo Diddley). He discovered that one brown thrasher sang over 2,400 unique songs(Guinness avian records, anyone?) He also found out that baby wrens hatched early in the season far outstrip late hatchlings in their number of songs (early bird catches the song?).

What's also great about this book is that the author provides many sonograms along with a CD that you can take outside and really study the songs of birds in your area, and get both a visual and aural take on them. Other books for both neophyte and experienced birders on this subject are Lang Elliott's Music of the Birds: A Celebration of Bird Song and Noble Proctor's The Songbirds Bible.

So set your alarm, go outside, and be wowed by all these wonderful creatures and their myriad ways of greeting the day.

entry.title: Books Plus Book Discussion for June
entry.content:
It's almost June and nearly time for our next Books Plus meeting. Summer means savoring the cornucopia of fresh produce and flowers at the Farmers' Market, our gardens, and stores. On Sunday, June 6th, please join me at 2 p.m. in a discussion of Michael Pollan's well-received book The Botany of Desire. This intriguing book examines our relationship with four plants: tulips, apples, potatoes, and marijuana. It poses the question: did we domesticate plants or did they domesticate us?

For those who want to enjoy the lush beauty of plants, we will also be screening the PBS movie of The Botany of Desire on Thursday evening June 3 at 6:30p.m. In travels around the world, Pollan documents how we humans don't stand apart from nature, but are intricately part of its web.

Books Plus meets the first Sunday of each month. All are welcome. Join the discussion or simply come to listen. No registration necessary. Drop in.

Join us for our upcoming programs!

June 3, Thursday. Botany of Desire Documentary Movie
6:30p.m., Library Auditorium
Join us for a screening of The Botany of Desire, a PBS documentary based on the best-selling book by Michael Pollan. Linking our fundamental desires for sweetness, beauty, intoxication and control with the plants that gratify them – the apple, the tulip, marijuana, and the potato – The Botany of Desire shows that we humans are intricately woven into the web of nature, not standing outside it. This beautiful documentary - shot in high definition - roams the world to examine our relationships with plants. Drop In.

2 p.m. Program Room 2B

"This book is as crisp as an October apple, as juicy as an August tomato, as long-awaited as the first flower of spring. Michael Pollan has conceived a new and powerful understanding of who we are, and how we stand in relation to everything else..." -- Bill McKibben

entry.title: My Name is Falon by Kim Wiese
entry.content:
Early Texas history is not closely studied in the Indiana public school system. The most I knew about Texas was Davy Crockett, the Alamo and that Texans were the last people to find out that the Civil War was over.

My Name is Falon by Kim Wiese follows a young Scottish lass, Falon, and her family from their home in Scotland to Texas in 1822. Crofters were being forced off the land in Scotland at that time with many immigrating to the young United States or the new country of Mexican Texas. When the family finally docks in Galveston, many of their group have perished including Falon's mother leaving her to make a home for her father, older brother, baby brother and brand new stepmother and her family. Falon is a wee lass but strong who marries a slave trader, starts her own family and survives the turmoil of the war for Texas independence from Mexico. Along the way she meets people she would never have encountered in Scotland, African slaves, native Americans, Mexicans and Catholics.
This is a good book for readers who enjoy stories about pioneer women and Texas. This title is also suitable for young adult readers. For other books about pioneer women west of the Mississippi try:
These Is My Words: the Diary of Sarah Agnes Prine, 1881-1901: Arizona Territories: a novel by Nancy Turner and
The All-True Travels and Adventures of Lidie Newton: a novel by Jane Smiley.

link.title: My Name is Falon by Kim Wiese

entry.title: The Forgotten Garden by Kate Morton
entry.content:
A colleague of mine once told me that she does not watch reality TV shows. She wants something with a story, that has characters with which she can become engaged. I must confess, much to my Indiana University literature professor's chagrin, that I also have found that I am drawn to books that have great plotlines and characters. Theme, tone, and setting are all well and good, but give me a plot that keeps moving and keeps me turning the pages.
The Forgotten Garden by Kate Morton fullfills all my requirements. Set between the years 1900 and 2005, it takes place in Australia and Cornwall. The plot follows three generations of women who kept their secrets, secrets about their families. It begins with young Nell in 1913, abandonded by her care giver, whom she knows only as The Authoress, on a ship from Cornwall bound for Australia. Later the story covers the women of the previous generation and the tragic sacrifices they made for love. Cassandra, representing the current generation, leaves Australia for Cornwall to see the cottage there that she has inherited from Grandmother Nell and to try to find answers to Nell's mysterious life story. Along with the cottage is a wonderful, overgrown walled garden. The entrances have been blocked , but by crawling under the wall, Cassandra finds a magical garden. Cassandra never learns the entire truth about Nell's past, but the reader does, and what a story it is.
This is another book that I can describe as sad, but in the end, I was left with hope for Cassandra.

link.title: The Forgotten Garden by Kate Morton

entry.title: 2010 Nebula Winners
entry.content:
The Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America announced the winners of the Nebula Awards last weekend celebrate excellence in science fiction and fantasy writing for books published in 2009.

Winner for the best novel is The Windup Girl by Paolo Bacigalupi. This is Bacigalupi's first novel and is set ina futuristic Bangkok amid mass genetic mutations, widespread food shortages and rising sea levels. Called grim, complex, literary and highly nuanced, this was one of the most talked about sci-fi books of the year.

The Women of Nell Gwynne’s by Kage Baker won the Nebula for the best Novella. This steampunk story is set in 1844 London. The women of Nell Gwynne's aren't ordinary harlots, they are part of an underground secret society. Mystery and intrigue help define Baker's The Company series.

entry.title: Social Networking Sites for Book Readers
entry.content:
I read a lot of books. That probably isn’t all that surprising given I work in a library, but I also like to keep track of the books I read, not only for personal reference but also to make recommendations to friends, family and people who come into the library. Talking about books and sharing books is one of my favorite parts of my job.

I started blogging about the books I read 4 years ago, but my list has recently gotten long and unwieldy. It was hard to keep a chronological list, but also group like things together. The solution? Social networking sites strictly for serious book readers!

Shelfari, Goodreads and Librarything are three of the most well known of these types of social networking sites. All are free to sign up and then you start adding books you’ve read, are reading or want to read and share them with friends that you can add. Rate the books you’ve read and even add reviews. The best feature for me was creating groups (called “shelves” in Goodreads) by adding tags. I can create different books lists instantly by clicking on my Young Adult Fiction or World War I shelf. Books can be tagged by more than one topic, so you can add books to multiple shelves.

When I signed up for Goodreads, I was happy with how easy it was to create these shelves and keep my reading lists organized. The added bonus is that through friends I’ve added, I am discovering new titles to add to my “want to read” shelf.

My current Goodreads status in a nutshell:
Just read: The Disreputable History of Frankie Landau-Banks by E. Lockhart (four stars!)
Currently reading: The Lacuna by Barbara Kingsolver
Want to read: The Eastern Stars: How Baseball Changed the Dominican Town of San Pedro de Macoris by Mark Kurlansky

entry.title: The Unnamed
entry.content:
I love to walk. In fact, when I had a foot injury several weeks ago, I felt unmoored and rather lost. Ferris's excellent novel takes walking to the extreme, to the aberrant, to the diseased. Tim Farnsworth, a partner in a prestigious law firm has started wandering again, walking through New York City by day and circumnavigating its suburban villages in the wee hours of the morning. His long suffering wife, Jane, knows exactly what to do: pack his backpack with extra layers of clothes, snack food, water; chain him to the bed if he allows it; lather his legs with vaseline to protect against chaffing; throw open all the bedroom windows to the January air and zip him into his parka in case he strikes out into the snowy, icy world after she has fallen asleep. Dread and fear descend upon her because this is not his first attack. She knows what to do, but wonders if she can be as giving as before she had a career of her own. Their daughter Becka thinks it's all some bizarre act on her father's part, afterall, no one else has described it on the internet. Either that or her dad's totally bonkers. Doctors, including neurologists and shrinks, argue whether his body is amiss or his mind. MRIs reveal nothing out of the ordinary.

Josua Ferris's prose is extraordinary. Artfully constructed sentences flow into each other. The dialogue--whether it's that of self-important law partner, a security guard, a homeless guy in the stairwell, or a crusty New York City D.A.--is always exactly on target. Tension in the book is palpable. There's the conflict between husband and wife--how much is a partner expected to bear especially when her husband doesn't do everything the doctors and other practioners demand? There's the parents' relationships with Becka. How much can they tell her? Or how often can they ignore her because of the disease? Comfort her? There's the tension between law partners over a big case--an important client has been accused of murder and Tim is supposed to represent him. And most especially, Tim must fight against himself--how much of his life can he cede to this unnamed and bizarre disease? The ruthless and brutal other who rules his body, his very limbs?

Luckily, Ferris lightens this somewhat dark tale with his quirky humor including kooky descriptions of the "cures" he has tried. In one scene, Jane yells instructions into the phone in front of her unknowing office colleagues, "call 911, walk into the development and knock on the first door--why didn't you wear your GPS?"

This book makes you ponder about many things: the nature of illness, how isolating any human difference can be, the partnership of marriage, the nature of trust and duty, the importance of work and responsibility. It's an utterly unique novel that will take you outside yourself for several hours and focus you on an interesting, if flawed life. Recommended for those who liked Oliver Sachs's nonfiction tales of medical and brain abnormalities, such as The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat and Musicophilia: Tales of Music and the Brain. It also reminds one of the psychological problems of characters in Ian McEwan's Saturday and Virginia Woolf's Mrs. Dalloway.

entry.title: John Muir and The National Parks
entry.content:
April 21st is the anniversary of John Muir's birthday. A few months ago I only had sort of a vague notion of Muir and then I watched Ken Burn's PBS Series The National Parks: America's Best Idea. This series was both enlightening and entertaining -- not to mention absolutely gorgeous to watch. The figure I found most intriguing of the series was Scottish born naturalist John Muir. His writings and efforts helped save Yosemite Valley, Sequoia National Park and was the founder of the major conservationist organization, The Sierra Club. Muir's influence on US forest and park conservation is unparalleled and his life unique.
In addition to the PBS series DVD and corresponding book, the library also has both book about and written by Muir. A selection includes:

My First Summer in the Sierra by John Muir

Sacred Summits by John Muir

To Yosemite and Beyond : Writings from the years 1863-1875 by John Muir

A Passion for Nature: The Life of John Muir by Donald Worster

John Muir: Nature's Visionary by Gretel Ehrlich

Son of the Wilderness: The Life of John Muir by Linnie Marsh Wolfe

entry.title: Celebrate Poetry in April
entry.content:
April is National Poetry Month. To celebrate, here are a few quotes about poetry along with some suggested reading. Former Poet Laureate Billy Collins said,“A poem for me displaces the silence the way your body displaces water.” Joseph Brodsky called poetry, “a highly economical form of mental acceleration.” “Like a traveler in an uncertain land, it (the poem) needs to carry with it all that it must have to sustain its own life—and not a lot of extra weight, either” is how Mary Oliver described poetry. And Marianne Moore nailed poetry with this definition, “Poems are imaginary gardens with real toads in them.” And this April, those toads are singing their little hearts out.

National Poetry Month began in 1996 when a group of literary organizations, poets, publishers, teachers, and librarians all met and decided to select a time of year to celebrate and promote poetry. They decided to emulate Black History Month and Women’s History Month and to promote the art of poetry by focusing on it in schools, libraries, booksstores and other venues. This year is the 15th annual celebration.

If you’ve been away from the art for a while, I’d recommend checking out an anthology. A poetry collection lets you sample familiar older poems or discover new ones. The library has many excellent anthologies. Here’s a sampling to enjoy:

--Essential Pleasures edited by Robert Pinsky. This anthology focuses on poems that are best read aloud.

--A Reasonable Affliction: 1001 Love Poems to Read to Each Other edited by Sally Berk and James Wakeman. Another collection to be shared out loud but this time spoken to someone special.

--The Oxford Anthology of African-American Poetry edited by Arnold Rampersad. This book contains work from over two centuries of poets celebrating, describing, and sharing the African-American experience including work from such greats as Paul Laurence Dunbar, Countee Cullen, Langston Hughes, and Gwendolyn Brooks among others.

--The Art of Losing: Poems of Grief and Healing edited by Kevin Young. This excellent anthology serves as a great resource for memorial services. All poetry lovers will find much to ponder here.

--The Best Loved Poems of the American People, selected by Hazel Felleman. A very classic collection of primarily English and American poetry.

--Against Forgetting: Twentieth Century Poetry of Witness edited and with an introduction by Carolyn Forché. This book includes poems of protest and poems that give social witness to lives lost and harmed by tyranny, terrorism, and oppression.

--Poetry 180: a Turning Back to Poetry selected by Billy Collins. The premise of this book is that contemporary poetry should be accessible & understandable—poems that people “get” on the first reading yet still engender thought and provide sustenance. A small anthology that celebrates both the everyday and the extraordinary.

--A Book of Women Poets from Antiquity to Now edited by Aliki Barnstone and Willis Barnstone. “Someone I tell you will remember us,” Greek poet Sappho once said. This collection is replete with work by women poets from many countries and time periods.

--The Oxford Book of Light Verse chosen by W. H. Auden. This collection shows poetry's humorous side from the nonsense poetry of Edgar Allen Lear to limericks by Houseman and Belloc. This collection will make you chuckle as it ferries you to the land where the bong trees grow.

--The Essential Haiku: Versions of Basho, Buson, & Issa edited by Robert Hass. These three masters of the traditional Japanese art give us beauty, pathos, love, longing, all in seventeen syllables.

entry.title: Franklin Pierce: New Hampshire's Favorite Son
entry.content:
by Peter Wallner

He might be New Hampshire's favorite son but not history's. It has a lot to do with the fragmented, clique-like nature of politics in his day. His vision was very parochial, he did not see the bigger picture.

The year is 1853. Southern politicians are bent on getting their way and many northern politicians were willing to let them in the name of Union. Men like Pierce, Fillmore, and Douglas became the South's enablers, helping walk the nation to the precipice. They stopped listening to their own constituents when the message became strident and unwelcome.

This is part one of Peter Wallner's biography of one of our most forgotten presidents. Forgotten because his presidency was an epic fail when the country most needed a great statesman to lead them home. He wasn't a bad man, or a corrupt man, or an incompetent man, but a man out of his depth. Since this volume ends just as Pierce is elected president it leaves all the important questions unanswered but Wallner's portrait of the man makes it very easy to imagine how it all happened.

He was a very successful man with what was probably a not very happy home life. He was a political wunderkind who ran the Democratic Party in New Hampshire. He was an extremely competent trial lawyer, an elegant speaker, with abundant courage, as he proved in the war with Mexico.

What he did not have was the capacity to see that agitation about slavery and the south's agenda was not a few malcontents stirring up the pot but a serious problem that needed to addressed immediately.

Wallner has done a very fine job setting the table and I'm looking forward to feasting on his description of the events surrounding the Kansas-Nebraska Act and final slide towards disunion or civil war.

link.title: Franklin Pierce: New Hampshire's Favorite Son

entry.title: The Irresistible Henry House
entry.content:
Imagine having seven mothers. Seven women, all but one young and pretty, carrying your baby picture around and bragging about what her little darling can do. Wonderful, confusing, overwhelming, enough already! So thinks Henry House even as a toddler. Lisa Grunwald's fifth novel centers on the unique subject of "raising practice babies." Wilton College, a small women's college in northwestern Pennsylvania is nationally renowned for its home ed program. Under the tutelage of Martha Gaines--strict but caring--babies are brought to the Wilton practice house for their first year or two so that students--all female, of course--can intern and practice motherhood. It's the 1950s and one of the wonderful things that Grunwald does is transport you back to those days of sweater sets, elegant French twists, and the era of, leave the baby cry, you will spoil him if you pick him up. Dr. Spock has just published his first baby care book and though the winds of change are brewing outside, Martha Gaines firmly slams the window shut on them, demanding that her girls follow her precepts that have worked for so many years.

The year before, the Wilton administration had forced Gaines to take a leave, and she has come back this fall changed. Baby Henry is so much younger than the other orphans she has cared for, only ten weeks instead of the usual six to nine months. She finds herself sneaking him out of the crib at night and rocking him, caressing his face, something she has long denied herself. This class session also has the president's daughter in the class, and with a sense of entitlement, she merely strides into the nursery and picks up Henry House and cuddles him whenever she wants.

As in the best novels, life gets complicated. Henry's real mother has been around the whole while, and when it's the standard time to give him up to a lucky couple for adoption, Martha devises an alternate plan. She will keep him at the practice house until the biological mother decides what she wants to do. New practice babies come through the years: Harry, Heloise, Hannah, Harvey, Hope, Hugh, and Harriet but for Martha Gaines, they are all secondary to Henry or Hanky as she calls him. Martha had been married and lost both a baby and a husband, so buried deep inside of her is a long-standing grief.

Though, at first, the book's focus centers primarily on Martha and her exacting way of teaching and raising children, Henry's story soon becomes paramount. It becomes a coming of age story, but with a twist. Henry is in search of his real family. When he discovers that many of the adults around him have lied to him, he becomes mute and is sent to a boarding school for insane children in Connecticut. For the first time in his life he finds a "perfect" family or one that seems perfect to him. The husband is an artist, and by this time Henry has discovered his own talent for drawing. Now it's the 60s and the world is changing fast: drugs, sex, tie-die, bell bottoms, and rock and roll. Unfortunately, Henry's favorite teachers decide to have their own child.

This novel examines the chains and expectations of love, and how one person can never meet all the needs of another. It's about what makes a good parent. It's also about discovering one's self. Most especially it's about forgiveness, and how for some, it takes a half of lifetime of learning to see ourselves in an other's shoes. Grunwald's ability to make us care for complex characters against the sweep of history makes this novel a compelling read. For readers who enjoyed Tobias Wolff's books, especially This Boy's Life and Old School. A related read (but set halfway around the world in Shanghai) is Kazuo Ishiguro's When We Were Orphans.

The gem of the book for the author was seeing an art show of images from a "practice motherhood program" at Cornell University. Here's the link if you want to see it: http://rmc.library.cornell.edu/homeEc/cases/apartments.html.
