entry.title: Dog On It
entry.content:
I'm a fan of hardboiled detective novels. I'm also a fan of dogs. Dog On It happily provided me with a hardboiled detective/dog mash-up (anyone a fan of Glee?). This is the first Chet (the dog) and Bernie (the detective) mystery by Spencer Quinn. I hope he has many more to come. The story is told from Chet's point of view and makes me think of how Robert Parker would sound if he were a dog . Smart as a whip, brave and loyal, Chet works alongside Bernie, a down on his luck private investigator with money troubles, an ex-wife and a young son. They are called upon to investigate the disappearance of a teenager, who may be a runaway or may be kidnapped. As the duo delve deeper into the case all sorts of trouble comes their way, including a close call Chet has at the dog pound.

Both Chet and Bernie are well-meaning and likeable, if flawed, characters. Chet failed out of K-9 school ("I'd been the best leaper in K-9 class, which had led to all the trouble in a way I couldn't remember exactly, although blood was involved.") but is undaunted by his past and proves a resourceful partner to Bernie. While books told from an animal's viewpoint are sometimes cloying, this one is fun and the dog's voice hits the mark. Chet is sometimes puzzled by the human world, but manages to shake things off and focus on what is important (sometimes this means food). The book is fun and suspenseful, a perfect quick read for the summer.

entry.title: Girl Trouble
entry.content:
The eight stories in this debut collection are tight, tense, and full of emotion. Unlike many women writers, Holly Goddard Jones does not veer away from violence. The threat of it hangs over all of these stories, propelling them forward. Each story embodies whole worlds alive with the past and detailed with the present, and like the fiction of master story-teller, Alice Munro, they veer back and forth in time, giving the actions deeper perspectives as the characters think about them and make changes in their lives based upon what happened then.

“Retrospective" follows the main character Libby from her life as a young mother living in a shack in the country that her mom dreads to enter, to her life some twenty-five years later when her sons are grown and her husband has brought a new young wife back to this hardscrabble land. With news that she will become a grandmother, Libby decides she must see the new house that her ex is building. In doing so, she confronts a tragedy from their past.

The stories feature mostly working-class Kentuckians in the imaginary town of Roma in the southwest part of the state which abuts Tennessee. The closest large city that people visit for special occasions is Nashville, Tennessee. Just a generation ago, Roma was remote from the citified world but now with the Internet it is more connected, but in many ways, still left behind. Roma's young people want more than their parents or grandparents had; therefore, only the dead-end kids remain there. The rest can't wait to move on and up in the world.

“Parts” begins with the simple declarative sentence, “I had a daughter.” From Jones's use of the past tense, you know that something really bad has happened. Soon you find out how terribly bad. This story is about a mother’s love, but also about her wish for revenge, and how such an immense loss can unravel a marriage. In a later story, Jones takes the huge chance of retelling this story from another character's point of view. The tension in this second story is almost overwhelming despite the fact that the reader already knows the outcome.

“Good Girl” is a dog story, and also a story about parenting, about a son gone bad, and a father, a widower too broken up by his own loss to discipline his son. You feel for the dog certainly and especially the widower father who is trying to raise the boy alone, but so empathetic is the narration that you even feel sorry for the kid who is too dumb and too impetuous to curb his instincts.

About her work, Jones said that she chose to write short stories because of “my discovery that short fiction could be generous and soulful in the manner of Andre Dubus, and not just a brief glimpse at some moment or idea.” She also said that she liked to write stories because hers are somewhat dark and that this is harder to sustain in a novel. Although the stories are not happy-go-lucky, they are deep, complicated and messy in the way life is, and offer as life does, many small perfect moments of grace.

Readers who enjoy the Kentucky fiction of Bobbie Ann Mason and Silas House will like these stories, as well fans of the classic southern writer, Flannery O'Connor.

entry.title: Dreaming in French
entry.content:
For an American girl growing up in Paris in the 1970s with a wise and popular sister, a statuesque and intelligent Mom, and a rich Dad withdrawn into his operas and reading, life is hard enough, but when your best friend summers in America and comes back with boy lust and babbling unintelligible slang and wants to run (and do worse) with an older crowd, well, life gets complicated.

Voice and characterization are paramount in Megan McAndrew's first novel. She was an expat herself and grew up in France, Spain, and Belgium, plus worked in Poland after college. Dreaming in French is a strong coming of age novel that lets you experience Paris firsthand: cafes, art, parks, and salons in people's elegant apartments. Charlotte's older sister Lea, an equestrian, understands how society works, but Charlotte herself is more like her mother--somewhat impetuous and always searching. She falls in love at age fifteen, and for the first time in her life ignores her Aunt Maybelle, a nurse from Kentucky, who has just come for a visit. Maybelle warns Astrid, Charlotte's Mom, that the young couple is spending too much time without supervision in Charlotte's bedroom, but Astrid ignores her.

One day Astrid suddenly disappears. She ends up in jail in Poland. It's the beginning of the Solidarity Movement, and her latest project is helping the Poles achieve independence from Russia. Because Astrid has fallen for a handsome Polish activist, her father refuses to help, so the two girls take a train to cold, inhospitable Warsaw in winter. They interact with an indifferent U.S. State Department official and an even less interested Polish bureaucrat. Neither care that the girls' mother is in jail. Each responds that she will be released in time.

Lea is horrified by her mother's betrayal of her husband, and embarrassed by the shame she has brought to the family. Only Charlotte desperately wants to help her mother without judgement.

After the Polish incident, the family breaks apart. Charlotte moves to New York with their mother; Lea stays in France with their father. There are lots of trips in between but the day-to-day streaming of Paris life is gone: the flowering horse chestnuts, the smell of delicious pastry, and the reader misses them.

French novels, particularly those of Balzac, are vital to Charlotte's sense of self. In America, she detours by studying Feminist Semiotics, but on a trip to Paris, she decides that it is totally inconsequential to her. She switches to a career in journalism and returns to Warsaw to record that country's break with Russia. Readers who enjoyed French Lessons, the novels of Diane Johnson and, for an early twentieth century take on expat life, those of Edith Wharton will be drawn to this book. Dreaming in French will take you on a welcome journey abroad without the cost of airfare.

entry.title: Winter World
entry.content:
Despite some possibilities for cool weather, signs of the beginning of Spring are surely noticeable in southern Indiana. Even the first official day of Spring happened on March 20th. But a recent hike in the woods nearby gave me pause to think about what the animals do over the winter. This led me to the library's copy of Winter World: The Ingenuity of Animal Survival by biologist and University of Vermont professor Bernd Heinrich.
Science reading isn't usually anywhere near the top of my list (though I do enjoy historical non-fiction), and I wasn't sure I wanted to go back and think about the cold gray days of winter when bright yellow daffodils were finally blooming outside. But I am so glad I did. Heinrich is a quintessential observer, outdoorsman, naturalist and big picture thinker who happens to be a trained biologist.
Animals, birds and insects that do not migrate during the winter approach survival in many different ways. How a frog survives is vastly different than how a squirrel, a bear, honeybees or a tiny Golden-crowned Kinglet braves a winter in the northern parts of the United States. Heinrich describes these different processes in an accessible narrative, complete with his own delicate illustrations.
Heinrich has recently followed up this 2003 book with Summer World: A Season of Bounty. The library owns several of Heinrich's titles. So if science and nature writing brings back bad school memories, you owe it to yourself to try again. I'm glad I did!

entry.title: Stone's Fall by Iain Pears
entry.content:
You can almost say that the main character of Stone's Fall is money or the manipulation of money and finances. The beginning of international finance plays a large role in the lives of the characters. Late 19th century European history and politics are also an important motivator for many of the people's actions in the story.

This long and complex tale is told backwards through time using three differents memoirs. It begins in 1953, when soon-to-retire journalist, Matthew Braddock, is given a packet that has been held by a British law firm for many years. From there the story jumps back to 1909 when Braddock was hired by the widow of an important industrialist, John Stone, to research Stone's life and write a biography of her late husband. Stone had mysteriously fallen out of an upstairs window in his home and died. Braddock finds many discrepancies in his research and many people with conflicting stories about John Stone. The story ends badly with Braddock and the widow, Elizabeth, parting with hard feelings and accusations.

The next section is written by Henry Cort starting in Paris in 1890. He is a journalist and also a part-time spy for England. He is especially interested in the flow of money and international finance. John Stone was a master at manipulating money and assetts and thus falls under Cort's scrutiny. Cort is ruthless and will do anything, even betraying his close friend Elizabeth, to achieve his goals. His story also ends badly with heartbreak and the guilt that goes with it.

The third section is written by Stone himself in 1909. It is his memoir starting in Venice in 1867. His narrative ties the other two sections together. Stone's motives are made clear and many misunderstandings are explained. It is the beginning of Stone's career as an arms merchant and industrialist. It is also a tale of madness, a wicked woman and the power of place in a person's life. This story also ends badly with lives ruined, modern warfare's beginnings and the loss of lives.

The book addresses one of my favorite tools in fiction, the use of irony. The current generation rarely is aware of what went on before they were born. The world starts over with every new generation. If Braddock had just known what questions to ask of what people, if he could have seen past himself and his own desires and problems, if the people he interviewed about Stone had not been too afraid to tell the truth, then much heartache could probably have been averted or made worse as the case may be.

This is a big book, 594 pages. I read the large print which is 856 pages, but well worth the effort. As my colleagues on the Reader's Advisory team can tell you, I can usually sum up a book by either "It was sad." or "It was not sad." This book is definitely sad but that's OK. I needed to be shaken out of my Jane Austen prequels, sequels, and knockoffs kick I have been on for the past year. Trying new types of books is good.

Iain Pears is the author of An Instance of the Fingerpost and the Jonathan Argyll, art dealer mysteries.

entry.title: The Boy with the Cuckoo-Clock Heart
entry.content:
This quirky unusual novel is an adult fairy tale, translated from the French, about a boy who was born with a bad heart. In 1874, Dr. Madeleine, a midwife in Edinburgh, Scotland, brings Little Jack into the world. And though the midwife's home and clinic is high above downtown, most of the citizens look down on Madeleine because she works with prostitutes. Little Jack was born on the coldest day in the world. As his mother walked up the hill her frozen tears "bounced off the ground, like beads from a broken necklace." When Jack was first delivered the doctor thought his heart was frozen, so she looked around her clinic and found the only thing that could keep him alive--a wind-up cuckoo clock. Most of the other children in the clinic/orphanage were adopted but whenever prospective parents checked out Little Jack they discovered the sharp hands that stuck out from his chest, so they never took him home.

Madeleine warns Little Jack repeatedly never to touch the hands of his clock, never to get angry, and most especially never to fall in love because if he does his heart will shatter. When he is ten, he convinces the midwife to take him downtown for the first time, where he notices a myopic child dancer with immense blue eyes named Miss Acacia. He falls madly, hopelessly in love. The next year he begs to enroll in school so he can see her again but learns from another student, Joe, that she has probably gone back to Andalusia. Joe torments him, throws eggs at him, calls him names, makes fun of his beating heart. One day, a few years later, he even tries to yank out Jack's heart. Little Jack finally fights back.

Thus begins the traveling part of the novel where Jack leaves town with the cops in mad pursuit. On the train, he has an eery encounter with Jack the Ripper who warns him that he will make his living from scaring people. Little Jack meets a clockmaker and illusionist who travels across France and Spain with him. They communicate with the folks back home via passenger pigeon. They find Miss Acacia again in the Extraordinarium, a bizarre show of freaks, singers, dancers and other entertainers.

Mathias Malzieu, lead singer of the French band Dionysos, scribed this clever and amusing tale about life and love. Although it's idiosyncratic, it does recall the fabulist fiction of García Márquez, Calvino, and Cortázar.

link.title: The Boy with the Cuckoo-Clock Heart

entry.title: Henry Clay: Statesman for the Union by Robert V. Remini
entry.content:
Clay was the man who might have been President of the United States if fate had been kinder and he hadn't made a few critical errors of judgment. Born in a hollar in Virginia, Clay made his fame as a Kentucky lawyer and politician. He was a persuasive orator, often compared to Patrick Henry of the previous generation. He was charismatic, personable, a notorious gambler, a ladies' man, with a wicked and corrosive wit. His failing was due to hubris and a willingness to follow his own vision without regard to reality.

In Washington he was quickly made Speaker of the House. He helped negotiate the Treaty of Ghent ending the War of 1812. He became the first powerful Speaker of the House before a term as Secretary of State, where he became a powerful advocate for Latin American independence, and then as a US Senator. He gained much of his reputation by engineering the Missouri Compromise of 1820 as well as the Compromise of 1850—both major deals between the states that allowed them to continue working together while leaving the issue of slavery for another day; and the Compromise of 1833, which helped mitigate the crises between Andy Jackson and the southern Nullifiers over tariffs. All of these were nearly intractable issues that Clay somehow found a middle path for. Each one of these dilemmas would reemerge in the guise of the Civil War once he had passed from the scene.

Clay's great mistake was to make Andrew Jackson his lifelong enemy by helping deny him the presidency in 1824 and throwing it to John Quincy Adams instead. Whether he sincerely believed Jackson was unqualified, or his ambition and lack of scruples caused him to overreach, is a matter of opinion but the results were the same—a damaged reputation that was never regained despite his profound triumphs.

Robert Remini is a well respected biographer of the era between the War of 1812 and the Civil War. His work includes the definitive three volume Andrew Jackson bio, as well as biographies of Martin Van Buren, Daniel Webster, and John Quincy Adams. This work never dragged despite the great depth of information Remini included. Henry Clay: Statesman for the Union is recommended for all history buffs.

link.title: Henry Clay: Statesman for the Union by Robert V. Remini

entry.title: The Burning Land by Bernard Cornwell
entry.content:
In some cases, it's wise to be suspicious of an author with multiple series in progress who seems to churn out handfuls of new titles every year. Such is emphatically not the case with Bernard Cornwell, master storyteller of the historical novel. The Burning Land is the fifth installment of Cornwell's Saxon Chronicles set in slowly-coalescing 9th century England. King Alfred of Wessex has the dream of uniting his domain with the kingdoms of Mercia, East Anglia, and Northumbria in a unified England, but is reaching the end of his life. Time and again he has relied on the pagan Northumbrian Uhtred, a fearsome military leader trained by the invading Danes, to fend off attacks to his kingdom. Now, Uhtred has grown tired of Alfred's machinations and attachment to the Christian church, and leaves his service to join the resurgent Vikings and Danes. This book covers two decisive historical battles in Wessex - Farnham and Beamfleet.

Like the book itself, Uhtred is a fascinating mix of historical detail and expert storytelling. Cornwell has an amazing ability to bring history to life through Uhtred's cynical, blunt, and coarse words. The reality of late-9th century life is on full display in the stench, gore, and fatalistic acceptance of murder, rape, and war. Yet like Uhtred, Cornwell's books are accurate depictions of historical military engagements and everyday life, and the crude exterior cannot hide a shrewd and highly entertaining tale. Especially interesting for readers who enjoy court intrigue are the continual manipulations of Alfred, who plays kingdom against kingdom and faction against faction (all the while managing to adhere to his fervent devotion to Christianity). The clash of custom and belief between the Danes, Vikings, and the Christians is another highlight of this series.

Cornwell writes a handful of other series, mostly concerning pivotal moments in British and American history. His long running Sharpe series focuses on the British army's battles during the Peninsular Wars of the 18th and 19th centuries, while he explores the Arthurian period in the Warlord Chronicles, the Hundred Years War in the Grail Quest series, and the American Civil War in the Starbuck Chronicles. For one of Cornwell's inspirations for his Sharpe series, try C. S. Forester's Hornblower novels (which deal with nautical engagements as opposed to Cornwell's land warfare). Simon Scarrow's Cato series goes back to the Roman invasion of Britain, far before the setting for Cornwell's books but frequently mentioned in them. For intrepid readers not fearful of fantasy sagas with strong historical details, try David Gemmell's Troy series, which features similarly brutal and realistic battle scenes (in the Troy of the Aeneas) or George R. R. Martin's epic of warfare and court intrigue A Song of Ice and Fire. All of these series have strong action elements and make for simply excellent storytelling entertainment.

link.title: The Burning Land by Bernard Cornwell

entry.title: Diary of a Young Girl
entry.content:
For her 13th birthday, Anne Frank received a diary from her father and began writing in it almost immediately. One month later, Anne and her family moved into back rooms at her father's office in Amsterdam to avoid arrest under Nazi occupation. What follows is horrifying on both a global level and, in the case of Anne Frank's surviving diary, painfully intimate and personal.

This March marks the 65th anniversary of the death of Anne Frank at Bergen-Belsen, almost a year after her family's arrest and about a month before Allied forces liberated the concentration camp.

Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl is often required reading in schools, but truly does deserve attention from all ages. Writer Roger Rosenblatt wrote about the enduring legacy of the diary several years ago when Time magazine honored Anne Frank as one of the most important figures of the century and states that "the reason for her immortality was basically literary. She was an extraordinarily good writer, for any age, and the quality of her work seemed a direct result of a ruthlessly honest disposition."

entry.title: The Late, Lamented Molly Marx
entry.content:
In her second novel, Sally Koslow scores with this light yet serious look at life from the hereafter. Molly Marx, wife for seven years, mother for three, has died mysteriously in a bike wreck in New York City's Riverside Park. Did she take a nasty tumble in the big wind before the year's first thunderstorm? Did she kill herself after writing a long emotional letter for her daughter Annabel, not to be read until she grows up? Did her dermatologist husband's lover--pushy, ambitious Stephanie--grind her into the rocks either accidentally or on purpose? Or did sweet Luke, her photographer heartthrob totally lose it when she told him she had to break off their relationship? What happened the day Molly died is not the most important part of this book, instead it's the message to enjoy each day no matter how imperfect. How incredibly rich, sensual, interesting life looks when it's suddenly closed off to you.

Molly's voice, earnest, searching, and often riotously funny keeps you turning the pages. You learn about her family: her Mom and Dad, Claire and Daniel Divine, with their perfect marriage, one Molly aspires to but knows she can never achieve. Her twin, Lucy (Moosey), passionate and impetuous who careens through life, sometimes risking too much; Molly's husband, Barry, maddeningly flawed, but who perhaps cares for her more than Molly knows or even wants. Koslow also includes a cast of other interesting characters: the best friend, Brie, and Brie's Latin love, Isadora, her mother-in-law, brittle, ambitious, and totally impossible, Delfina, the incredibly kind nanny who holds their household together, and, finally, Hiawatha Hicks the detective assigned to her murder case. Molly loves fashion and food, both perhaps too much. Koslow spins fashion labels like a Vogue writer, but she has the empathy to really understand people and the connections among them. On one level you can read this book as a frothy take on a rich New Yorker's life; but on other level, it's an optimistic rendering of what it means to be human and confused, a state that lasts even after death. Other books where the deceased speak are The Lovely Bones and the much lighter That Old Cape Magic by Richard Russo.

entry.title: Fiesty Female Friendships
entry.content:
March is Women's History Month, and in honor I dug up an article from The New York Times from last year that reports on evidence that having female friendships is actually good for your mental and physical health. As mentioned in this article, The Girls from Ames: A Story of Women and a Forty-Year Friendship by Jeffrey Zaslow came out about this time last year too. This non-fiction book reports on a group of friends from Ames, Iowa whose remarkable friendships have remained close despite geographic distances and have supported each other through family deaths, divorces, children, career pitfalls and life's general ups and downs.

A quick catalog search for female friendships in fiction brings up hundreds of results. Titles in this genre range from fun fiction including titles like Angry Housewives Eating Bon Bons by Lorna Landvik and The Friday Night Knitting Club by Kate Jacobs to giggly good times for teens as typified by Ann Brashares' popular series Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (my own personal guilty friendship favorite). Interested friendships of a little more serious nature? Try Sula by Toni Morrison, Snow Flower and the Secret Fan by Lisa See or even the classic Vanity Fair by William Thackery.

During this Women's History Month, I'd like to thank all my women friends for making that hill seem not so steep. Celebrate with some fantastic female fiction today!

entry.title: Books Plus Book Discussion for March
entry.content:
Please join us on Sunday, March 7th, to discuss the One Book One Bloomington title for the year.

The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay is part family history, part homage to comic books, and all character-based following two Jewish cousins from the age of 19 to 32. Set in Czechoslovakia, New York, and even Antarctica, this novel is epic in scope. Come tell us what you think of the Pulitzer Prize winner. If you haven't had time yet to finish it yet, come to discover information about the author and this very modern book. Kyle Knight, an Indiana University School of Library Science's student and a MCPL intern will lead the interesting discussion. For more details, see below. Hope to see you there.

Books Plus meets the first Sunday of each month from 2:00-3:00 in Program Room 2B at the Main Library. All are welcome. Join the discussion or simply come to listen.
No registration necessary. Drop in.

link.title: Books Plus Book Discussion for March

entry.title: Vampire Books
entry.content:
What is the deal anyway with all the vampire books? They are everywhere - from sparkly titles for teens to darker reads from the Swedes and everything in between. Like it or not, vampire books have become part of our pop culture fabric - both in print and on the screen. I admit to a love/hate relationship with this particular sub-genre, but was fascinated by a recent article from NPR corespondent Margo Adler, who recently read a whopping 75 vampire books! Adler argues that vampire books are a bit more nuanced and morally complex than in the past. I don't think I could read with such focus, but the article did pique my interest in at least one new title.

Do you have a favorite vampire book?

entry.title: Novelist and The Great War
entry.content:
Recently a friend suggested I re-read All Quiet on the Western Front by Erich Maria Remarque. This World War I classic is told from the perspective of a front line German solider and is heart wrenching in its detail and emotion.
World War II features heavily in movies and fiction, but there are many fewer titles that focus on World War I. Curious to see what else was out there, I turned to Novelist Plus. Novelist Plus is a database that you can access at the library or from home with your library card from our Research Tools page. This database can help you find books that are similar to a title or author that you've read and liked. We use it at the reference desk frequently, so if you haven't used it before, check it out.
Using Novelist and the subject of World War I as my starting point, I was led to discover and read A Very Long Engagement by Sébastien Japrisot (also a movie starring the lovely Audrey Tautou from Amélie). This novel is complicated, purposely misleading, and is loaded with lots of unique characters who all happen to have confusing nicknames. With that said, it is completely worth the effort in the end. Novelist Plus also pointed me to Deafening by Frances Itani. This gem of a book starts with Grania, a deaf girl living in rural Canada before the war. As a young woman she meets Jim, a hearing man, who is sent overseas to war. Itani's novel has a sharp instinct for both language and sound. Good World War I books aren't impossible to find, but sometimes it does take a little digging. Both of these titles were well worth the discovery.

entry.title: Notes from No Man's Land: American Essays by Eula Biss
entry.content:
The cover of Notes from No Man's Land sums up it's appeal nicely. At first you totally ignore the photo. Then you perhaps wonder what a splintered plank of wood has to do with anything (a book of essays is daunting enough for many - one having to do with mundane, inanimate objects more so). Having read the first essay, however, you might find yourself closing the book for a break and noticing the telephone pole on the cover and, for a second, be made to understand that forgotten legacy Biss has just reminded you of. That while they are omnipresent in our lives, and rather ugly and most often disregarded, telephone poles with their history of violent opposition in the early days and frequent use in lynchings later, are disturbingly like the way we approach race relations in America. Unless we literally run into one in a car, we're likely to dismiss the pole as something not needing our attention anymore.

These are essays that are stronger for their focus on the details of everyday life. Children's dolls, discarded sofas at the end of a college semester, palm trees and graffiti - each serves as a focal point for Biss as she chronicles her time in New York City, San Diego, Iowa City, and Chicago, tempering the author's fascination and anxiety with her relation as a white woman to the mostly minority neighborhoods she lives in. In "Relations," Biss uses sociological studies of children's preferences for white or black dolls as counterpoint in describing her time in Harlem, sharing a room with her cousin, a Jamaican-American. "Babylon" explores the concept of non-native plants (particularly the palm tree in California, slowly dying off) in contrast with the phenomenon of white suburban migration. Even when she is living in Iowa City, by far a mostly white, liberal university community, she is struck by her students' reaction to media reports of looting and murder in New Orleans following Katrina - at once dismissive of the continued existence of racism and ready to accept the cultural inheritance of viewing African-Americans as "victims or villains - children or savages." Never condescending, idealistic but grounded in reality, persuasive without resorting to preaching, Biss writes personal essays in the best manner, allowing the reader to identify, relate, and carry the unease and hope far past the book's final pages in their own narrative of life.

If you enjoy Biss' writing and would like to read one of her influences (and a similar voice), try Joan Didion's Slouching Towards Bethlehem. June Jordan's Affirmative Acts: Political Essays presents essays on race relations in the United States from the African-American woman's perspective, while Gemini by Nikki Giovanni examines race through the lens of the poet's early career. If you are interested in reading some of the better selections of more contemporary American essays, try the Best American Essays series, published yearly.

link.title: Notes from No Man's Land: American Essays by Eula Biss

entry.title: Village of the Ghost Bears
entry.content:
This is the fourth book in the Nathan Active mystery series. Nathan is a half-Inupiaq, half-Caucasian trooper in the bush village of Chukchi, Alaska. If you're just discovering Stan Jones' well-written arctic mysteries, you can start anywhere. Each book can stand alone. Ghost Bears tells the story of the village's Rec Center fire, which may or may not be arson. This mystery strikes close to home because Chukchi's chief of police, Jim Silver, dies in the fire.

The book has everything from illegal polar bear hunting to wild bush pilot flights to a couple of naked troopers taking a frigid swim out to a plane in an arctic lake--if they wait even a day or two, freeze-up will occur and they will have to wait months to continue their investigation of a downed plane. Jones, a native Alaskan and former bush pilot, knows the Arctic landscape and Inupiaq culture well. He's excellent at plotting, and even more so, at writing prose that makes you feel as though you are on the scene: in the cockpit of a little Cessna as Cowboy (what an authentic name for a bush pilot who loves to takes risks) barrels through ice fog through a pass in the mountains with a crazed possibly gun-toting criminal waiting on the ridge beneath. Clues from the fire point to the village of Cape Goodwin, even further north than Chukchi, an Inupiaq village famous for twins, schizophrenia, and polar bear hunting. Two of the characters of interest are in fact twins, Pingo and Eve Kivalina, and one seems very crazy. Is he or not? Crazy enough to start a fire that kills eight people?

Jones knows how to make his main character complex and very human. Nathan's in love with Grace who was raped by her own father and has issues about sex. He also is close to his birth mother who gave him up for adoption and loves to feed him native dishes while trying to coax him not to accept a big promotion in Anchorage.

The title comes from an Eskimo myth that when polar bears die they come to a village on the sea ice, full of seals and walrus and their own kind, where hunting is good, and they are finally safe and content.

Other Alaskan mystery writers include Dana Stabenow, Sue Henry, and John Straley. Stabenow writes mysteries set in a fictitious national park modeled upon Denali while Sue Henry writes mysteries featuring female sleuths set in Homer and other central Alaskan places, some featuring woman musher Jessie Arnold. If it's the beauty of southeast Alaska you prefer, John Straley writes investigator mysteries set there. But--for my money--Stan Jones captures Alaska best, especially the modern Arctic culture and lifestyle. These Nathan Active mysteries will seat you on your very own snowgo and let you roar across the snow-covered tundra experiencing the glorious scenery, the bitter cold, and the great warmth of the native people.

entry.title: Humor for Your Heart
entry.content:
Studies show that laughter is actually good for your heart, and come middle of February I find myself naturally not looking for a good romance novel, but for a healthy dose of humor as a prescription for the cold gray days.
One of my favorite funny writers, Nick Hornby, is back again with his newest, Juliet, Naked. Hornby has written several laugh-out-loud books and his newest is no exception. Annie clashes with her partner over a new release of an aging American song writer - Tucker Crowe - she hates it, he loves it. Their differences of opinion prove too much for their already precarious relationship. Then through a series of complicated (and hilarious) events, Annie ends up embarking on a friendship of sorts with Crowe himself.
While Hornby excels at using both music and relationships as humor, Roddy Doyle examines what is so funny about families (plenty). Try The Commitments, The Van or Paddy Clarke, ha-ha-ha. Looking for some Office Space type humor? Try Joshua Ferris' debut novel, Then We Came to the End.
Funny isn't limited to fiction either, Danny Wallace's memoir, Yes Man is hilarious and far superior to the movie based off of it starring Jim Carrey. Bill Bryson writes humorous travel books and In a Sunburned Country is by far my favorite. Just thinking about his experiences in Alice Springs and later describing a cricket match in Melbourne is enough to make me smile.
What are your favorite funny reads?

entry.title: How Beautiful the Ordinary: Twelve Stories of Identity
entry.content:
How Beautiful the Ordinary, edited by Michael Cart, is a welcome addition to the small but growing collection of young adult fiction exploring gender identity and sexual orientation. Being a young person is difficult, what with all the changes physical, emotional, and social. Most of us spend our whole lives getting to know ourselves, and those initial explorations in our youth are some of the most confusing and painful (and exhilarating and profound) because they are so new. All of this can be overwhelming, and when you throw in societal condemnation of some of these identities and/or lifestyles it is especially hard. This collection of short fiction by well-respected young adult authors takes a loving and unrelenting look at the struggle not only to discover what we are as young women and men, but to accept and own that identity as well.

"My Virtual World" by Francesca Lia Block chronicles the ways in which online connections can serve to safely hide or reveal one's true self. Through a series of increasingly open instant messages, two young people struggling with depression find acceptance and in turn learn to accept themselves. Ariel Schrag and Eric Shanower contribute a humorous look at gay pride events and the pangs of a secret high school love, respectively, in graphic novel format. Poetic verse (Julie Anne Peters' intimate "The First Time") and screenplay (Ron Koertge's experimental story of a gay son's coming out to his father) also add variety to the collection. One of the most powerful stories, however, uses the old folktale "The Highwayman" to explore how dangerous trying to suppress things like love and desire can be, regardless of sexual orientation - Margo Lanagan's "A Dark Red Love Knot" is a bloody and grim tale of tragedy, and a flat-out devastating piece of writing. Finally, Gregory Macguire, author of the Wicked series, offers proof that knowing what we are is a process that never ends in "The Silk Road Runs Through Tupperneck, N. H.," a melancholy revisit of first love after twenty years' absence.

For more short fiction dealing with teen identity and sexual orientation, try Am I Blue? Coming Out from the Silence, edited by Marion Dane Bauer and featuring writers such as Bruce Coville, M. E. Kerr, and Jane Yolen. Ariel Schrag has published several "high school comic chronicles" in graphic format - try Awkward and Definition. Transgender and transitions of all kinds are explored in Julie Anne Peters' Luna, and identity is literally taken and rebuilt in Nicola Griffith's science fiction tale Slow River. For real-life accounts of young people's search for their sexual identities, try I'm Looking Through You: Growing Up Haunted, Jennifer Finney Boylan's memoir of growing up as a girl in a boy's body in a haunted house. Resources, first-hand accounts, and practical information and advice can be found in Kelly Huegel's GLBTQ: The Survival Guide for Queer and Questioning Teens. All of these and many more similar titles are excellent choices not only for those questioning their sexual identity, but for anyone (and that's really everyone) who has tried to truly understand themselves.

link.title: How Beautiful the Ordinary: Twelve Stories of Identity

entry.title: Do Polar Bears Get Lonely? : and Answers to 100 Other Weird and Wacky Questions about How the World Works
entry.content:
This book is for the smarty-pants, know-it-all generalist in all of us. It's not a read end-to-end book, but one to be savored in sections. The format consists of 100 questions and answers divided by topic--Plants and Animals, Our Bodies, Food and Drink, and Troublesome Transport among others. Some of the questions you've probably wondered yourself: why are some people right-handed and others, left-handed? Why do pears and apples have such different shapes? Others are so bizarre you wouldn't have thought of them on Mars. Here's one of the best in the latter category: "In a worst-case scenario, if one had to eat parts of oneself which non-organs would be most nutritious? Nails? Hair? Earwax?"

Do Polar Bear's Get Lonely is full of fascinating facts about the world. Amaze your next dinner party guests by mentioning offhandedly how they put stripes in toothpaste, or why red wine lightens with age while white wine darkens. Explain that yes, indeedy, spiders do drink water and watch your guests race over to the dessert table. Find them there and explain how chocolate candies get their smooth, round finish.

This collection of science Q and A is a fun book that will appeal to the kid in all of us. Teens will love topics that are quirky and sometimes describe the utterly gross. For those who enjoyed similar compendiums such as Why You Never Get to the End of the Rainbow and How Can You Tell if a Spider is Dead, it's another treat in the pursuit knowledge (both useful and not). Both of these were edited by IU's own Don Glass and derive from the locally-produced radio show A Moment of Science.

link.title: Do Polar Bears Get Lonely? : and Answers to 100 Other Weird and Wacky Questions about How the World Works

entry.title: February Books Plus
entry.content:
Feeling some cabin fever? Why not visit coastal Maine? At least vicariously through the covers of a book. Leave the cold and snow behind and come to our next Books Plus program on Sunday, Feb. 7th. entry.title: It's Beginning to Hurt by James Lasdun
entry.content:
London-born New Yorker James Lasdun writes poetry and full-length novels, but is perhaps best known for his short fiction. With his new collection It's Beginning to Hurt, Lasdun showcases his ability to clearly depict the emotional lives of his characters without resorting to the third person. Whether he is using short bursts of dialogue between characters, or internal monologue, Lasdun is able to quickly and entirely successfully
realize the people populating his stories and strip away their facades at the precise moments that their emotions clash and overtake them in the process. Rage, paranoia, lust, terror are all well represented in these stories, but relief, hope, and even love make appearances as well. What makes these stories so interesting goes beyond Lasdun's skillful exactness in depicting these crisis points - it is his ability to clearly depict the effects these emotions have on people, and how their lives are or are not changed by them.

In "An Anxious Man" (winner of the National Short Story Prize) a loser at the stock market finds himself fearing a much greater loss when his daughter disappears from a sleep-over at the house of a family he has just met. Rage threatens to destroy more than one new life in "Totty," when June's countryside escape from roaring, adulterous 1990s London is threatened by blackmail. A widowed father's wedding following the loss of a first wife paradoxically relieves a son's feelings of apprehension and self-disgust in "Cleanness," a clever twist on the prodigal son chestnut, and in the delightfully (and physically revolting) atmospheric piece "Annals of the Honorary Secretary," Lasdun examines fear of and fascination with the ultimate unknown. In "Oh, Death," the collection's tour de force, Lasdun takes a neighbor's simple recounting of an unhappy man's life and literally brings him face to face with his mortality, in the form of the story's reader herself.

If you enjoy this collection, you may want to try one of Lasdun's longer works, such as his novel The Horned Man. Lasdun is frequently compared to Nabokov for his powers of observation, and a collection of the latter's short fiction might satisfy those looking for like-minded stories. Kafka and Updike are other writers of short works with whom Lasdun shares similarities. Finally, for a masterful graphic depiction of the short form that also powerfully depicts the push and pull of human emotion, try Adrian Tomine's Shortcomings, a collection in graphic novel format from his long running Optic Nerve comic.

link.title: It's Beginning to Hurt by James Lasdun

entry.title: Everything Ravaged, Everything Burned
entry.content:
In this first collection, Pushcart Prize winner Wells Tower presents realistic though slightly bizarre stories with dark comic twists. In the first story “Brown Coast” a man destroys his marriage by having an affair; he also gets fired from his building job—steps must be cut an even six inches apart. Economic realities force him into a kind of exile in downstate Florida at his uncle’s house (once owned jointly by his dead father). His job is to clean and repair it. The town has no decent beach, but to unwind, Bob takes buckets and pots down to the stink grass by the sea and captures beautiful fish and other sea life from the tidal pool. While trying to turn his life around, he meets kooky neighbors who spontaneously skinny dip with him. Tower writes about expected masculine exploits such as drinking, hunting, and building cabins, but also surprises the reader with close and sensitive looks (despite cursing and name-calling) at a sibling relationship in the story “Retreat” and a father and son relationship conflicted by his dad’s dementia in “Executors of Important Energies.” This is a man’s world depicted from a man’s point of view, but captured so vividly that anyone will relate to the protagonists and their conflicts. In Tower’s stories the world is messy and awful and incomplete but occasionally blessed with fleeting moments of beauty and connection to others.

What’s fun about Everything Ravaged, Everything Burned is the author’s wide knowledge of the world. He writes about carpentry, chess, carnivals and invention with the ease of someone who has gotten his facts from long experience. Tower’s writing is muscular and vivid. He has an eye for details and describes location and characters so that you feel as though you are in the room with him. Every page offers surprises. For those who love the stories of Richard Ford and Tobias Wolff, this collection will not only entertain, but will pull you into vastly different worlds than you experience daily, and let you know them from the inside.

entry.title: No Such Thing as the Real World: Stories About Growing Up and Getting a Life
entry.content:
I remember my initial reaction to short stories in middle school was along the lines of "But nothing happened!" Alright, something happened, but it wasn't really anything I cared about. Usually these stories involved one character having an Incident, then ended. I think the problem was that so many of the "classic" short stories I encountered in English class were set too far in the past or featured characters older than me - not that I couldn't identify with what was going on (I've come to appreciate many of these stories over time), I just... couldn't be bothered to put in that much effort. Hey, throw me a bone, I'm struggling through hours of Algebra homework and I've got to read about a Victorian garden party next?! So first off, let me say that No Such Thing as the Real World isn't a collection of stories like that.

Each of these six stories are narrated by people high-school age or slightly older, searching for or fighting through those moments when you realize that "growing up" isn't anything like what anyone (even yourself) told you it would be. And unlike growing taller, it doesn't stop in your early 20s. These stories often feature explicit language and situations, but if you can handle that it's well worth the effort of checking out. An Na's "Complication" features a young prostitute whose world makes sense until she is confronted with a proposition of love from a client. Two sisters and one boyfriend lead to trouble on the brink of high-school graduation in K. L. Going's "Survival," and a term paper can't distract Hannah from classmates' interest in her best friend's suicide in Beth Kephart's "The Longest Distance."

A of the highlight of the collection, M. T. Anderson's "The Projection: A Two-Part Invention" is one of those stories where you're not sure what's really going on - but in a good way. Two teens are rehearsing lines for a school play (maybe) when things get really uncomfortable and reality really breaks down. This story is written completely in dialogue from a dramatic scene for two actors, and would make a really shocking (and amazing) performance. Speaking of which, a young man describes what it's like to be young, gay, and a talented dancer in New York in Jacqueline Woodson's "The Company." Chris Lynch's "Arrangements" rounds out the collection with a son's first day at work in a pawn shop left to him by his father, who may be dead, but lives on in the stories and strange forms of payment that reveal themselves through his customers.

Most of these stories are firmly ground in the here-and-now, and you might also enjoy Tales from Outer Suburbia by Shaun Tan. If fantasy is your thing, try Lips Touch: Three Times by Laini Taylor, a trio of magical and macabre tales, or Troll's-Eye View for shorter stories by many of today's best fantasists. Those who've read and liked the Twilight series should find something to get their veins pumping in By Blood We Live, while A Banquet for Hungry Ghosts by Ying Chang Compestine offers twisted tales of horror from a very different tradition. If you like to mix it up with creepy and magical, and don't mind a bit of science fiction, try Kelly Link's Pretty Monsters. The great thing about short stories is you don't have to waste too much time deciding whether to keep reading or not, and especially with the collections, you always have a different author to try out if you don't like the first. Any of these books are good starting places, but feel free to ask us about other genres or themes you might be interested in!

link.title: No Such Thing as the Real World: Stories About Growing Up and Getting a Life

entry.title: That Old Cape Magic
entry.content:
Two weddings and one unraveling marriage form the backdrop for That Old Cape Magic. One of our best contemporary novelists, Richard Russo, departs from his usual gritty upstate New York settings for the upscale vacation haven of Cape Cod. The title comes from a variant of "That Old Black Magic," the song Griffin and his parents sang each time they headed across the bridge to the Cape. But now some forty years later, Griffin, a screenwriter and professor, son of two English profs, a man who has been taught to use language carefully and grammatically, has a lot on his plate: his father has died, his mother calls him long distance several times a day with demands along with stories that reorder their family's past, and he discovers his supposedly happy wife in the shower, weeping. When he and his wife can't agree on when to leave for the Cape for the wedding of their daughter's best friend, he takes Joy up on her suggestion that they should drive separately. This is good, Griffin thinks, he has his father's ashes to release, and he needs to call Sid, his long-time agent in LA who might, just might, have a new screenwriting gig for him. Despite the fact that Griffin is incredibly unhappy throughout the book, the novel is knock-out funny. Griffin's Mom who is only heard on the phone or seen in flashbacks is crusty, intelligent, sarcastic, shrewd and amazingly bitchy. And even after she dies, Griffin can still hear her voice.

Yet the book is wise with humanity, awash in Tolstoy's maxim from Anna Karenina that "Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Throughout the book, Griffin compares Joy's raucous, materialistic (not a book in the house) family with his elitist, impractical, financially insolvent own. One section recounts all the homes they leased or borrowed from other faculty on sabbatical, and how they all ended up damaged: plates broken, floors flooded, even the ceilings stained. He takes his phone calls from his parents privately in his study so as not to inflict his wife with their bile. But for those interested in academic novels, this one will strike home--it's quite caustic on academia. In fact, the college both Griffin's parents work for is a "large university in Indiana" and they spend years hoping to escaping from the Midwest. (They use a more vulgar term to describe it.) Also, for those who have suffered through weddings where things have gone terribly askew, the second wedding rehearsal will bring back memories. In fact, if you are planning a wedding in the near future, it 's probably best to skip this scene even though it's one of the comedic highlights of the book. Readers who enjoyed Jane Smiley's Moo or David Lodge's Small World --from across the pond--will enjoy this immensely readable book.
