entry.title: The Bigness of the World
entry.content: Lori Ostlund's first book won the 2009 Flannery O'Connor Award for Short Fiction. It's easy to see why: many of these eleven stories involve a journey to a foreign country--including Hong Kong, Belize, Indonesia, and Malaysia. Lori Ostlund is one of those rare writers who can help you experience a place by providing a few carefully-chosen details. In "Idyllic Little Bali" it's the need for expats in a Yogyakarta hotel bar to connect with their own culture by playing silly drinking games together ("my closest brush with fame"). But Ostlund is also a sly, complex writer and overlaid with this story retelling stories is a failed marriage, a pair of lesbians remembering an important past event far too differently, and a Canadian pretending to be a fellow American "largely by keeping track of her vowels." In fact, each of these stories takes off in one direction then veers sharply several times to finally turn back in on itself. Characters are well drawn, and continuously reveal themselves in unexpected ways. Surprise is a key element in this collection. Ostlund is also laugh-aloud funny--imagine your gay girlfriend returning from a short trip to Hong Kong and being absolutely bald. What's even weirder, neither partner even mentions it. Imagine Dr. Deneau (called Dr. Dunno by the kids) poking fun at his principal's wife's handstitched embroidery featuring foreign proverbs, "Your wife seems quite enamored of the ant." These are intelligent stories, many with lesbian relationships at their core, but all are about our human failure to really communicate what we are thinking and feeling to our closest loved ones. Ostlund shows how living with someone can become the most dangerous of battlefields where the skirmishes feature silence, avoidance, and not reaching out to each other. As an added bonus these stories open our eyes to other cultures and the "big world" around us. Recommended for readers who enjoy the work of Dorothy Allison and Jeanette Winterson. For another recent story collection with an international setting, check out Anne Sanow's Triple Time.

entry.title: Threshold: The Collected Stories of Roger Zelazny
entry.content:
A dying Martian race, gargantuan sea-monster fishing, and a cryogenic party set that only thaws itself out for exotic gatherings a day or two every few years are some of the plot lines in this first of six volumes collecting Roger Zelazny's more than 150 short works, all of his poetry, and a number of essays. Each volume also contains a part of a critical biography written by project co-editor Christopher S. Kovacs. Part of the so-called New Wave in science fiction writing of the 1960s that focused on experimental techniques, psychological themes, and treatment of the genre as serious literature, Zelazny (1937-1995) wrote novels and shorter works in a number of genres including science fiction, fantasy, and horror, as well as essays and quite a bit of poetry (his first love). His work is characterized by the incorporation of a wide cultural variety of myth and folklore into modern settings, Freudian and Jungian psychological themes, and lively, somewhat hard-boiled dialogue reminiscent of Hammett and Chandler.

Threshold contains shorter works from 1962 through early 1965, and includes four of Zelazny's best-loved tales. In "A Rose for Ecclesiastes" (#3 all-time novelette in the 1999 Locus Poll) an arrogant poet is sent as part of an expedition to Mars to record the culture of a dying race and finds himself at the center of an ancient messiah myth. In "The Graveyard Heart," a deadly love triangle forms among a select group of individuals accepted into the Set, who slumber for years at a time in stasis only to wake briefly for outlandish parties. Altered experience of time, aesthetics and humanity, and media saturation are the themes explored in this story. A tough facade hides a haunting obsession and broken heart in "The Doors of His Face, the Lamps of His Mouth," the story of one man's fatalistic quest to catch the unimaginable Leviathan of Venus (winner of a Nebula Award). "He Who Shapes" also won a Nebula, and is the longest piece in the book. It seemingly tells the tale of a Shaper, a psychiatrist who is able to help patients explore and cope with neuroses through shared dream states produced by advanced technology. Things begin to go wrong when he treats a lovely blind woman who aspires to be a Shaper herself and whose condition threatens to wrest away his psychological control. Other less-known highlights include a meditation on academic censorship ("The Malatesta Collection") and several humorous short pieces ("The Great Slow Kings," "Circe Has Her Problems") as well as Zelazny's oft-quoted poem "The Agnostic's Prayer."

Zelazny is probably best known for his Amber Chronicles, a widely popular fantasy series mixing mythology and political intrigue; and his award-winning novel Lord of Light, set on a planet colonized by the last Earthmen who interact with Hindu/Buddhist-like gods. For insight into Zelazny's life and work, check out the Lilly Library at IU's collection of Zelazny manuscripts. If you're interested in similar authors, try Ursula K. LeGuin's The Lathe of Heaven for an exploration of psychology in the science fiction and fantasy genres, or the more recent American Gods by Neil Gaiman for a modern fantasy populated with mythological characters and set in the kitschy and bizarre corners of the United States.

link.title: Threshold: The Collected Stories of Roger Zelazny

entry.title: Mennonite in a Little Black Dress: a Memoir of Going Home
entry.content: You can tell from the title that this is no ordinary Mennonite memoir. Rhoda Janzen, a college professor who has recently turned forty, has suffered injuries from a major car accident. Her husband of thirteen years left her for a man. Because Rhoda lives far out in the snowy Michigan country (her bipolar husband's idea), she retreats home to California for some TLC and to rethink her priorities in life. This is both a history of growing up in a conservative community, and how one woman managed to both break away from and respect her past. The writing is snappy and extremely funny. In one scene, Rhoda is standing in line at a store with her Mom and being grilled about why she won't marry her first cousin, Waldemar. "That's both incestuous and illegal," Rhoda says. Her mother responds, "Well, I think it would be fine. You can't have kids anyway. Maybe you can adopt." In thirteen chapters including ones titled "The Raisin Bombshell," "Touch My Tooth" and "The Therapeutic Value of Lavender," Janzen shows how she has learned to keep the values her church has taught her: thrift, hard work, the importance of family, and how to reject others--a woman should cook and sew and not aspire to higher education. Luckily for Rhoda, her parents supported her quest for a PhD, but that was highly unusual. Her family and even the broader Mennonite community tries hard to matchmake for Rhoda. One elderly friend of her mother's notices Rhoda's good looks and sets her up with a much younger nephew. This light memoir touches on issues of love, materialism, sisterly bonds, why women stay in toxic relationships, yet it still keep you laughing. If you're in a rush, just check out the Appendix where Janzen gives irreverent answers to the following questions: "Whaaa--? Mennonites? Don't they drive around in horse-drawn buggies and wear doilies on their heads? Hey, yeah, don't Mennonite chicks dress up as semisexy French maids, in black dresses with aprons? What are they wearing under all those layers anyway?" and finally, "Aren't Mennonites the folks who make collectible quilts, many of which are now unaffordable on eBay?" Readers who enjoyed Anne Lamott's Traveling Mercies and Lauren Winner's Girl Meets God will love this book.

link.title: Mennonite in a Little Black Dress: a Memoir of Going Home

entry.title: The Windup Girl
entry.content:
This science fiction novel by Paolo Bacigalupi has received rave reviews. I'm not a huge science fiction fan, but I read so many positive things about it that I decided to give it a try. The Windup Girl did not disappoint. Be forewarned that this is a bleak story with few happy endings. The first two chapters are especially difficult to read depicting graphic brutality. But Bacigalupi's original view of a future with no electric or gas power and no naturally grown food provides a complex and intriguing read. Set in Thailand and filled with multi-dimensional characters and wonders from the author's imagination this novel tells the interweaving stories of a military man, a factory manager, a Chinese immigrant, and the title character- a genetically designed woman who is both hated and lusted after and accidentally sets off a war. Each character is fully realized, with both good and bad traits and motivations. One of my favorites, Jaidee, the leader of the environmental army, is charming and charismatic, but basically a thug in a uniform.
Bacigalupi has imagined some interesting genetic creations, like the megodonts, sort of elephant/wooly mammoths crosses whose strength provides power to run machines. There are also Cheshires, created on a whim as a child's party favor, which are exactly what they sound like- cats who blend into their backgrounds. They quickly thrived and caused the extinction of domestic cats. He also introduces the ever-present "New People"- the windups created for the convenience of humans and callously discarded at will.
This novel looks unflinchingly at the evil inherent in humanity and the environmental destruction man creates in his own environment. There are no easy answers in this book, no single morality. Even the most well-intentioned characters carry out questionable actions. Literate and original, this is a thought-provoking novel well worth your time.

entry.title: Zachary Taylor: Soldier, Planter, Statesman of the Old Southwest
entry.content:
When you start looking for books about the more obscure presidents they get hard to find. Fortunately, my public library has been open to acquiring these books when I ask. I also have a university library I can access nearby when things get tough—say, for Thomas Hart Benton or Stephen Douglas.

Anyway, Taylor was the ultimate outsider, a wild-card president, who barely had a party when elected. A military hero, Taylor was nominated by a Whig Party desperate for anyone and, like their experience with William Henry Harrison and John Tyler, it turned into a disaster for them. Simply put, Taylor had his own ideas about how to run things and was ready to lance the boil of Secession right then and there—1850—but fate intervened in a probable bout of cholera that took him away and gave Millard Fillmore a chance to miss the opportunity.

Bauer's biography is as well written and well researched as any book could be after the devastating loss of Taylor's personal papers during the Civil War. Bauer is a bit skeptical of his subject, which was refreshing after reading several bios that were a little too supportive of their subject's POV, especially in the hindsite of 150 years. Those presidents are forgotten for a good reason—we're ashamed of them.

But not in this case. The tragedy of Zachary Taylor is that he didn't get to complete his term in office because he was the kind of figure who can change history.

link.title: Zachary Taylor: Soldier, Planter, Statesman of the Old Southwest

entry.title: City of Thieves and 900 Days
entry.content:
The longest siege of any city in modern times started in the fall of 1941 when the Germans encircled Leningrad, cutting off all supply routes. Close to 3 million people stayed in the encricled city and faced almost 900 days of inhumane circumstances and starvation. Less than half survived.
David Benioff, author of 25th Hour, sets his newest novel, City of Thieves, against this horrific and historic back drop. Jailed and set to be executed for looting a dead German paratrooper, brooding teenage Lev finds himself overnight in a cell with with the gregarious Kolya who is imprisoned for deserting the Red Army. The next day they learn they can earn their freedom in exchange for completing a dangerous and possibly impossible mission. Their task? To find a dozen eggs for an army captain's daughter's wedding cake in the middle of winter in a city where people are starving. Their week long hunt sends them through the streets of Leningrad and into German occupied countryside. The twist at the end is heartbreaking, but fitting. I really enjoyed this book - both as a coming of age read and for the friendship between Lev and Kolya, which is often humorous despite the circumstances.
Want to know more? Harrison Salisbury is a Pulitzer Prize winning journalist from the New York Times who was stationed in Moscow after World War II. Benioff cites Salisbury's master work, The 900 Days: The Siege of Leningrad in his notes at the end. The heavy non-fiction book is considered to be the best in the English language, but also manages to be readable while still meticulous in detail.

entry.title: On Thin Ice: the Changing World of the Polar Bear
entry.content:
The polar bear has long served as the poster animal for climate change. On Thin Ice shows why. If you are fascinated by these great creatures, or merely want to know more about them, this book is for you. Richard Ellis begins by recording his first encounter with a polar bear near the North Pole in 1994, and then goes on to summarize man’s history with polar bears dating back to the 16th century. He proves that the conception of this bear as being a horrific man-eater is wildly off-course, and shows how people’s fears have caused countless bears to be shot. Polar bears are extremely curious and often come close to humans (several sniffed an atomic submarine), but even today, are often rewarded by a shot to the brain. And the polar bear brain is extremely intelligent.

The science and stories about these magnificent animals are very intriguing. Ellis does a country by country inventory of their present numbers and government policies concerning them. Unfortunately, our country and many others, including Canada where the world’s largest numbers live, do not protect them enough. I skimmed over some of the geographical and historical details, and some of the polar bear deaths. Most fascinating were the asides, references to Darwin’s account of specialization, and a chapter on bears in zoos and circuses, including a brief history of the modern zoo using natural environments pioneered by Carl Hagenbeck.

Ellis includes a section on how climate change will affect these bruins, and another on their future, titled “Is the Polar Bear Doomed?” The main problem is that they have adapted extremely well to the cold north, and now that ice sheets are melting, they have become one of the most endangered mammals on earth.

The author has gathered many interesting photos of the bears including art and posters about them, but unfortunately not enough are in color. For a more stunning photo odyssey, see The World of the Polar Bear by Norbert Rosing. Together these books will convince you that this incredible animal must be saved.

link.title: On Thin Ice: the Changing World of the Polar Bear

entry.title: The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair that Changed America by Erik Larson
entry.content:
After hearing about this book in a class I put it on my to-read list and waited patiently to get my hands on it. I knew it was non-fiction but other than that had no idea what I was getting myself into.
Based on title alone the reader may be getting a murder mystery or a tale of horror, but with this book you get all that and much, much more. With this true tale of industry, architecture, and murder most foul the city of Chicago takes face and shape like never before. Documenting the preparation and occurrence of the World's Columbian Exposition in 1893, a combination of novelistic style and detailed historic and architectural information make this book shine.
Two main figures dominate the story: Daniel Burnham and H.H. Holmes. Burnham was the architectural mastermind behind the Exposition (also called the White City), and Holmes was one of America's first serial killers.
The Paris Exposition of 1889 set the world on fire with its innovative feats in technology and architecture. During the Exposition the Eiffel Tower was unveiled, a modern marvel of steel and structural design. Determined to maintain its place as a leader of industry and progress, the United States knew it must answer Paris's challenge with an even better exposition. Eventually and uneasily designating Chicago as the chosen spot, the work of constructing and planning came next.
Framed in the backdrop of the burgeoning city of Chicago, we meet H.H. Holmes, aka Herman Webster Mudgett. A con-artist of the most cunning persuasion, Holmes used his good looks and charm to commit acts of fraud and murder. Realizing the boom of tourists and job-seekers the Exposition would bring to Chicago, Holmes quickly had a hotel and business center built and set up shop. With an in-house gas chamber, dissection table, and crematorium he was perfectly positioned to lure and dispose of his prey of young, newly independent women. Capitalizing on their small-town wonder and wooing them with presents and flowery promises, Holmes murdered and disappeared dozens, often selling their skeletons for medical study.
Larson tells these intertwining tales beautifully, rich with historical detail and flourish. Within its pages the city of Chicago comes alive, its own dark character and resilience revealed. The role that the city plays in this story is essential to its telling, and readers will enjoy the close attention paid to architectural and geographic descriptions. The discovery of such an intriguing and shocking piece of history will surely have readers wondering why they didn't know all of this before. Whether new or old to the story of Chicago's Columbian Exposition this book is sure to engage readers throughout, reminding them that fact is indeed often stranger than fiction.
Check the status in our catalog for The Devil in the White City.

link.title: The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair that Changed America by Erik Larson

entry.title: Strangers
entry.content: Brookner presents a rare take on a person preparing himself psychologically for death, or rather for the last months of life. Strangers is Brookner's 24th, and as she hints, probably her last novel. In it Paul Sturgis, a seventy-two year old retired banker, still in good health, has seen his social world shrink to Sunday visits to a widowed cousin-in-law. He has been "lightening" his Sundays (the worst day of the weak to be alone) this way for years, but he and Helena aren't close. They share tea and elegant sandwiches on her expensive couches, but she blathers on about her bridge club and lunches with old friends, but asks for no information about his life. Each time he leaves and enters the rainy London streets, he feels charged by feelings of both escape and freedom. But at night childhood memories nag. He remembers the old family house, the stairwell, every piece of furniture, his parents' unhappy marriage, their dissatisfaction with life. On a whim, he takes a trip to Venice and meets a divorcee, Vicky, who is twenty years his junior. Her life is the opposite of his: unplanned, scattered, no home, jaunting here and there. He doesn't want a romance only company. But she never listens to him either, only wants a place to store her extra luggage. While visiting an art gallery, Paul's meets one of the two loves of his life; she left him because he was "too nice." And now she too relies on him for company, but old age has taken away her robust personality and impetuous spirit. She gives in to infirmity rather than adapting to it. This is a very interior novel, one not brimming with action. But the character of Paul is very appealing--he's always questioning and wanting to learn more about other people--the strangers of the title--despite his stiff British upbringing when he was always chastised for prying. The prose is beautiful and clarified, and it really flows. I can't imagine most young people being drawn to this book, but for the middle-aged and those older, it's an examination of what's important in life, a blue highway roadmap (not direct at all), of how to go on despite adversity. It's similar to novels by Barbara Pym but without the religion and jumble sales. At one point, Paul Sturgis says, "That's the way to leave, with nothing of value left behind." A book that makes you think long after you read the last page.

entry.title: Best Nonfiction from 2009
entry.content:
2009 "best of" lists keep popping up in different places covering different genres and subjects. I browse the non-fiction lists both for ideas to read and gift ideas for my family. Three very different non-fiction books this year made both Time magazine's top list and the New York Times Book Review's best of 2009, and might be worth a shot.

Age of Wonder: How the Romantic Generation Discovered the Beauty and Terror of Science by Richard Holmes. Learn about Romantic scientists who were born out of an age when the academic worlds of science and art collided, including botanists, astronomers, and chemists. This title is also on Publisher's Weekly best non-fiction list.

Lit: A Memoir by Mary Karr is the third memoir following her highly acclaimed and well loved Liar's Club and Cherry. This newest book follows Karr's slide into alcoholism and finally recovery.

Lords of Finance: The Bankers who Broke the World by Liaquat Ahamed chronicles four bankers who make a disastrous decision after World War I impacting the fate of economies today around the world.

Lastly, two biographies of similar, yet also different, short story authors also came out in 2009 and made a few lists too. Cheever: A Life by Blake Bailey is listed on both Publisher's Weekly and Time magazine's lists while Raymond Carver: A Writer's Life by Carol Sklenicka made the New York Times Book Review best of list.

A diverse list of really great non-fiction means there is something for everyone. What was your favorite non-fiction read this year?

entry.title: A Gate at the Stairs
entry.content:
Midwestern farm-girl goes to college is the theme of A Gate at the Stairs. This coming of age novel is set in fictional Troy, Wisconsin (a stand-in for Madison). Tassie Keltjin, daughter of a famous potato grower applies for a job as a nanny. Her weird humor and slightly bizarrre conversation interest Sarah, owner of a trendy restaurant and her husband Ed, so much so that they don't check her references. The odd part of this babysitting interview is that so far there is no child and Sarah's belly is as flat as a Kansas field. Tassie and Sarah immediately hit it off, sharing quirky—though in different ways—worldviews.

Oddly, it's Tassie rather than Ed who accompanies Sarah to her meeting with an adoption agency worker and a pregnant birth mother. (At one point Moore quips about the strange vocabulary of adoption.) But Sarah flunks this first test after insisting that the young woman must stay clear of drugs. On the trip home Sarah hints that she and Ed share a criminal past, but this is so far beyond belief that Tassie thinks she’s joking. But later, the couple's past history does affect all their life trajectories. Ed manages to make the second interview, and this time they succeed in bringing baby Mary-Emma home. But Tassie is too involved in her own life to give her employers' problems much mind: her Brazilian boyfriend, Reynaldo, turns out not to be Brazilian and his yoga mat is really a prayer mat, her brother debates enlisting in the army for Afghanistan, and she continues her odd mix of courses everything from wine-tasting (illegal since she is not yet 21) to the Soundtracks of War Movies to the The Perverse Body: the Neutral Pelvis (both humanities and PE credits.) When life gets too complex for her she escapes into the poetry of Rumi and composes songs on bass and guitar. Sarah and Ed start a discussion group about raising biracial children, and Tassie finds herself eavesdropping on the comments of the parents. The adult world is new to her and very confusing. Murph, Tassie’s roommate abandons her for a boyfriend, and Tassie lives on her own; her bond with little Mary-Emma grows daily. And as tension mounts in the Brink-Thornwood household, Tassie seeks solace in her music.

More than anything, the language of the novel, especially its puns and humor make it memorable. But it’s also a post 9-11 novel, a novel about first love and new parenthood--all complex subjects. Lorrie Moore is skilled at combining humor with tragedy and in posing questions that we all should consider deeply. Nothing gets tied into a pretty bow at the end, but the reader feels she has travelled on a fascinating journey. Writers who like Kingsolver and Atwood will enjoy this novel.

entry.title: Shantaram-A Novel
entry.content:
Don't be thrown off by the weight of this book (1,000 pages or so!) in your hands. You won't be sorry.

Gregory David Roberts's tome Shantaram is chock full of everything that makes a great story: adventure, romance, friendship, betrayal, loss, heartache, redemption, and a strong sense of place. This fascinating tale, based on true events from the author's life, begins in an Australian prison where our protagonist, Lindsay, is serving time on several robbery convictions. Managing to escape from prison, Lindsay flees to Bombay, India with a group of New Zealand tourists and a forged passport. It is in India that the adventure truly begins, and where Lindsay meets two characters central to the story.


Lindsay first meets Prabakar, a warmhearted and always smiling tour guide, who introduces him to the living, breathing city of Bombay. Managing to find a temporary home in Prabakar's slum village, Lindsay is amazed at the resilience and dignity of its people as he experiences true poverty firsthand. Through Prabakar, Lindsay (now called Linbaba and Lin for short by his new friends) also learns the Marathi language, rare knowledge for a foreigner, and is even able to start a back-alley medical clinic for the slum's residents.


Next is Karla, the beautiful green-eyed expatriate, with a mysterious charm about her and a host of colorful friends. Lin finds himself head over heels in love with Karla, and though it seems that they would have an uncomplicated romance, her unwillingness or inability to return his affection is a tense thread woven throughout the story.


In an unfortunate chain of events Lin finds himself arrested and thrown into the notorious Arthur Road Prison, a hellhole more grotesque than anything he has ever experienced. After languishing in misery at Arthur Road, Lin is finally released. Deciding not to return to the slum, he takes a job laundering money and making counterfeit visas and passports for Bombay crime boss Abdel Khader Khan. Regarded as a guru sage of sorts, Khader is intrigued by the Marathi-speaking foreigner and decides to take Lin under his wing. Soon Lin finds himself plunged headfirst into the criminal underworld of Bombay, though completely protected by his association with Khader. Out of a sense of loyalty Lin even follows Khader to his native Aghanistan to fight as a guerrilla in the war against the Russians. There he learns the details surrounding his arrest, and is shocked to discover a connection between Khader and his beloved Karla.


First written while serving out his sentence in prison, Roberts relies on richly detailed prose and a steady narrative style to carry his story along. Readers will be enthralled by the descriptions of the city of Bombay, through which it almost becomes a character in its own right, as well as the city's people-realistically characterized without being overly sentimental or prejudiced. Though some parts of the story might seem too incredible to be true, and in fact the book never claims to be a work of non-fiction and is merely based on true events, they are forgiven by the lyrical style and believable emotions and actions of the characters.


You don't want to miss this riveting tale of adventure and personal growth, complete with fascinating characters and an exotic locale. Fans will want to keep an eye out for a movie in the near future, as the rights to the book were bought by actor Johnny Depp's production company.

entry.title: Fiction that Rocks
entry.content:
I knew I had to read The Alternative Hero by Tim Thornton after spotting it in Details magazine (sometimes you can get the best recommendations in the strangest places). Thornton's debut follows Clive Beresford as he tries to piece together his past and plans for the future after seeing his music idol, the fictitious Lance Webster of the Thieving Magpies, come out of a dry cleaners in his neighborhood. 90's music references, both real and imagined make the book, but in the end it is the characters you really care about.

Most of the reviews I read about The Alternative Hero also mention fellow rock novelist, Nick Hornby. Like The Alternative Hero, High Fidelity follows a 30-something music loving Londoner who is struggling to find his way into adulthood. Hornby shows a true gift for writing some seriously funny fiction as his protagonist Rob requires a soundtrack to help define his life as he works in a record store.

A quick search shows that rock fiction isn't that obscure of a genre, titles like A&R: A Novel, The Exes, and Roddy Doyle's The Commitments can also be included. Marc Spitz, a former senior writer at Spin Magazine has also taken his turn at rock fiction with Too Much, Too Late: A Novel. A young blogger creates a buzz about her boyfriend's father's reuniting 90's band with disasterous results. Music insider insight blended with just the right mix of humor make this a worth while read.

entry.title: NPR's Best Cook Books 2009
entry.content:
'Tis the time of year for year end (or this time around, decade end) best-of lists. While every list might not be everybody's cup of tea, book lists do often make for a nice review of what has been published in the past year. I use these lists to make sure that I didn't miss any fiction or non-fiction that looks truly great, but also enjoy some of the more specialized lists. For example, NPR recently put out their Best Cook Books of 2009 list and I will certainly be checking some of them out. Looking to add some spice to your routine holiday menus? Or maybe you are still shopping for a favorite cook in your family. Either way, these titles include both cooking and baking and are sure to provide tasty treats. Titles from our collection include:

Asian Dumplings: Mastering Gyoza, Spring Rolls, Samosas, and More by Andrea Nguyen

Clean Food: A Seasonal Guide to Eating Close to the Source with More Than 200 Recipes for a Healthy and Sustainable You by Terry Walters

Gourmet Today: More than 1000 All-New Recipes for the Contemporary Kitchen, by Ruth Reichl

Savory Baking by Mary Cech

Peter Reinhart's Artisan Breads Every Day by Peter Reinhart

The Craft of Baking by Karen DeMasco and Mindy Fox

Rose's Heavenly Cakes by Rose Levy Beranbaum

entry.title: Benny and Shrimp
entry.content:
This odd, quirky novel tugs at your heart. It's the story of Benny, a cow farmer and a librarian Desiree (AKA Shrimp because she is so pale and curls into Benny's side). These 30-somethings meet in the graveyard where Benny's mother and Shrimp's husband are neighbors. Although Shrimp is a widow, her marriage was not at all passionate, and earthy Benny stirs her in ways she did not think possible. But after a passionate beginning, Shrimp pulls back. She visited Benny's farm and there is only so much needlepoint, Swedish meatballs (it's set in Scandinavia), and farm journals that she can take. Her work life is complicated by the fact that another librarian is spying on her--cataloging people's lives rather than book records. And love has made Shrimp so confused that she does not get angry at this strange older librarian but instead asks her for relationship help. "I don't do advice," the woman snaps.

Despite their differences, the reader roots for this romance to blossom, and at the same time wonders how it possibly can. Can the cultured librarian give up her job and become the farm wife? Can Benny give up his dream of having a wife as skilled in the kitchen and with cows as his mother? Will Benny and Shrimp ever be able to squeeze in a vacation together with Benny's tight milking schedule?

Chapters are short and snazzy, full of both humor and a deep understanding of human psychology. Most chapters begin with some poetry, written by the author. The lines set the mood of the chapter and give the reader a heads-up what the coming section will be about. Although translated, the vocabulary is so colloquial and up-to-date that it seems natural, and it is fun to view libraries and farms in Sweden. Readers who like Anne Tyler, Cathleen Schine, and Alice Hoffman will enjoy this read.

entry.title: National Book Awards 2009
entry.content:
Last week, the National Book Awards announced their winners for 2009. Winning for best fiction title is Let the Great World Spin by Colum McCann. This book is set in 1974 and follows the lives of several New Yorkers after Philippe Petit's high wire walk between the Twin Towers. Earlier this year, Frank McCourt described McCann's work as a "groundbreaking heartbreaking symphony of a novel...no novelist writing of New York has climbed higher, dived deeper."

The First Tycoon: The Epic Life of Cornelius Vanderbilt by T. J. Stiles was awarded the best non-fiction prize. Born to humble beginnings, this book follows Vanderbilt as he works his way up and comes to symbolize the American Dream. Stiles makes a case that the economy we live in today was first formed by this important businessman.

The winner for best poetry was awarded to Transcendental Studies: A Trilogy by Keith Waldrop. This highly acclaimed avant-garde poet brings together a collection of three related poem sequences—“Shipwreck in Haven,” “Falling in Love through a Description” and “The Plummet of Vitruvius” with a powerful effect.

Finally the award for Young Person's literature this year went to a biography, Claudette Colvin: Twice Toward Justice by Phillip Hoose. Claudette Colvin was a teenager who was a central, but often forgotten, figure in the Civil Rights Movement. Nine months before Rosa Parks, Colvin was arrested and jailed for refusing to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, AL.

To see all the finalists check out the National Book Award Website.

entry.title: Chibi Vampire Manga
entry.content:
Chibi Vampire is a manga series written and illustrated by Yuna Kagesaki. The series follows Karin, a middle child of a very old vampire family who has settled in modern day Japan. Karin isn't like her other family in that she can be outside in the sun, attends school, has a part-time job. Most interestingly of all, Karin gives blood instead of sucking blood like the rest of her vampire family. Normal days of school and work are still complicated for Karin, and they become even more so with the appearance of a transfer student, Kenta Usui. The characters are fun and interesting and the story is generally light. While I still mostly enjoy non-illustrated novels, I can certainly see the appeal of manga, especially for reluctant readers.

Manga refers to Japanese comics. The term was coined by renowned Japanese artist Katsushika Hokusai (1760-1849). Originally satirical caricatures, the popularity of Japanese comics soared following World War II. Today manga is increasingly popular in the United States. Over 95% of all manga titles published in English are actually translations of Japanese manga, usually originally serialized in magazines marketed to a specific demographic. The tone and subject matter of manga runs the gamut from saccharin children’s manga to gritty noir to romance titles and chick lit.

Even though it has comedy elements, Chibi Vampire may fall into the horror or fantasty-character category of manga, but so does Death Note, a darker manga about a young man's plan to rule the world using his power to kill by simply writing a name into his notebook. Other popular horror manga titles include Vampire Knight, Hellsing and Inuyasha.

entry.title: The Savage Detectives
entry.content:
In recent years, books by the Chilean novelist/poet Roberto Bolaño have achieved a kind of cult status in the U.S. Last February. Picador signed a deal to publish seven more of his works into English including a reissue of this novel. Reading The Savage Detectives it's easy to see why: Bolaño's humor, his encyclopedic knowledge of several fields (in this case, poetry and politics), his sense of play, his ear for dialogue, and his ability to orchestrate many stories into a unified whole is without comparison. And you don't have to like poetry to enjoy this madcap ride: a cross between a Jack Kerouac road-trip and a García Márquez magical adventure. The book is divided into three sections, the first and third are told from the viewpoint of a young poet, Juan García Madero, who is trying to make a name for himself in poet-rich Mexico City of the 1970s. There he stumbles across a group of nearly anarchist poets, the Visceral Realists. The second section is a symphony of forty-six voices sharing their impressions of the Visceral Realist leaders Arturo Belano and Ulises Lima.

The third section details a wild ride (including a prostitute in tow--don't worry their protecting her from a dangerous pimp) where the poets are trying to discover what happened to the very first Visceral Realist, a woman poet named Cesárea Tinajero who disappeared into the wilds of the Sonoran desert. If all this sounds terribly confusing, it’s not. The writer’s sense of joie de vivre and madcap storytelling ability hurtle you along. The second section comprises the bulk of the book, and the stories country hop from Mexico to Israel to Chile to France to Poland to Liberia to the United States. It's amazing to see how differently the other characters view the two leaders of the movement, revealing everything from hate to love to awe to disappointment to confusion. These stories are set in campgrounds, caves next to the sea, city streets with thugs in sight, in bars, in crowded apartments, on Mexico City roofs, in brothels, and in bookstores. And if you have trouble remembering names, an enthusiastic fan created a spreadsheet to keep track of the various characters. Check it out at: http://literateneroids.blogspot.com/2009/06/savage-detectives-roberto-bolano.html.

What I liked best about the book were the jokes and puns that managed to cross cultures. Also, the sense of ebullience and sheer joy leap from the page. This excellent read will appeal to young adults, those interested in literature, and people interested in Mexican and South American culture. Some parts are bawdy; others earnestly political, but the vast range and viewpoints present a world-view not to be missed.

entry.title: The Millstone
entry.content: Margaret Drabble, the British author, dame, and sister of A.S. Byatt, has written seventeen novels. Before tackling her latest book, The Pattern in the Carpet: a Personal History of Jigsaws (half memoir, half tribute to puzzles), I decided to try one of her earlier novels that I had skipped. The Millstone, her third, with its evocative cover appealed to me. It’s the story of Rosamund Stacey, a young academic who is working on a PhD about the romantic poets. She’s living in her liberal parents’ posh apartment sans rent while they are off performing good works in Africa. Rosamund balances her academic work with tutoring her three mostly inept students and her social life: two boyfriends, who each assume that she’s sleeping with the other. Surprisingly—at least to her--she gets pregnant during her first sexual encounter--a romantic night with a suave BBC announcer. Rosamund decides to keep the child. “Decides” is perhaps too strong a word. She chooses it as more or less as the least egregious possibility. This is decidedly a character novel, and mainly a one-character novel, but the protagonist is so smart, interesting, and observant of the world that you happily stay involved during her journey from a mainly solitary woman to one interconnected in a web of relationships. It’s primarily an interior novel. Drabble presents Rosamund‘s visits to the prenatal clinic, including the first time in her life when she holds an infant in her arms. Drabble draws a vivid scene of the birth itself as four or five young nurses chat about their boyfriends in the hall leaving the hapless mother to give birth alone. Drabble shows the miraculous bonding that occurs with her child during her twelve (yes,I did say twelve days in the hospital, postpartum). This book will appeal mainly to women. Readers who enjoy the work of Penelope Fitzgerald, Jane Gardam, and Margaret Atwood will enjoy this read.

entry.title: Cirque du Freak: Living Nightmare
entry.content:
Out of their group of friends Darren and Steve are the lucky ones who get to see a sideshow that has come to their town: Cirque du Freak. The two best friends have no idea what they are in for. When one of the acts turns out to be a real life vampire/spider-wranger, the boys get caught up in a series of events that will change their lives.
Rich with great descriptions and interesting characters, including a huge spider named Madam Octa, Living Nightmare will appeal to those looking for an alternative to the overly romantic, super popular vampire series, Twilight. I would recommend this to younger teens who enjoy lots of action.
While originally published in 2001, there has been some renewed interest in this series as the movie was just released this fall. It stars John C. Reilly as the vampire and is based on the first three of Shan's books. The film is (confusingingly) called Vampire's Assistant rather than the name of the first book in the series.

entry.title: French Milk and Travel Journals as Graphic Novels
entry.content:
Lucy Knisley was about to turn 22 when she spent five weeks in Paris staying at an apartment with her mom. Knisley is worried about her upcoming birthday and the adult responsibilities of job, school and money, while her mother is about to turn 50. Together they tour the city in search of art, souvenirs and good food. While there Lucy keeps a travel journal complete with sketches of things she observes about the city. French Milk, a light and fun graphic novel is the result.
I have not had much experience reading graphic novels, but this one appealed to me as someone who always keeps a journal on my travels. In the case of French Milk, the book would appeal to fellow travelers, without going in to too much detail beyond what they are doing on a daily basis.

Interested but not quite sure of the graphic novel format? There are a few other travelogue graphic novels for those who have either spent time traveling or just like to read travel books, including Carnet de Voyage by Craig Thompson or Shenzhen: A Travelogue from China and Pyongyang: A Journey in North Korea by Guy Delisle.

entry.title: Zeitoun by Dave Eggers
entry.content:
Dave Eggers has written short stories, a heartbreaking memoir, essays, and fiction. Most recently he wrote What is the What, the fictionalized tale of real-life Lost Boy of Sudan, Valentine Achak Deng. What is the What is one of those books that garnered both passionate readers and high acclaim, being named one of New York Times Notable Books of 2007.

Egger’s new book takes a similar shocking and tragic story of one person, but this time Eggers writes a fairly straightforward non-fiction book. The result is no less absorbing. Zeitoun recounts the story of Abdulrahman Zeitoun, a successful businessman and Syrian American, who stayed in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, while his family fled to stay with friends and relatives. What happens is both beautiful and horrific. Zeitoun ends up arrested and held without medical care or a phone call for three weeks without having been charged with any crime. The journalistic detail that went into the recreation of Zeitoun’s experiences after the hurricane are precise and fascinating. This book would be well received by anyone who is interested in current events and recent American history.

Dave Eggers continues to stretch his writing with this book, but more importantly he appears committed to chronicling events and stories that show the courageous human spirit under crushing injustices and situations.

entry.title: City of Ember by Jeanne DuPrau
entry.content:
A self supporting, totally enclosed city where there isn’t any crime and everyone gets along sounds like it might be an easy life.
But 12 year olds, Lina and Doon, start recognizing that not only are food and supplies in short order, but the mayor appears to be in on a small group of people who are hoarding supplies. In addition to this injustice, they realize that the city’s generator is closer to total and complete failure than the city authorities make it out to be.
Lina discovers a note that appears to be instructions for escaping the city, and with security hot on their heels, Lina and Doon make a run for the boats down in the Pipeworks.
City of Ember is action packed and filled with interesting descriptions of the city and how it operates. This would be a great book to recommend to young teens, both boys and girls!

entry.title: Man Booker Prize for Fiction 2009
entry.content:

Wolf Hall is set in the 16th century and tells the story of the rise of Thomas Cromwell. Mantel is from the United Kingdom and is currently working ona sequel.

The Man Booker Prize is awarded every year for a work of fiction written by a citizen of the Commonwealth or the Republic of Ireland.

Previous winners include:
2008 - The White Tiger by Aravind Adiga (India)
2007 - The Gathering by Anne Enright (Ireland)
2006 - The Inheritance of Loss by Kiran Desai (India)

entry.title: Banana: The Fate of the Fruit that Changed the World
entry.content:
Dan Koeppel was driven to write this book after reading an article in a journal describing diseases that the banana is facing, such as Panama Disease, Bunchy Top and Black Sigatoka. Upon his world wide research quest, Koeppel discovers not only the banana empire’s ugly past but also a possibly more despairing future.
Did you know that Americans consume more bananas than apples and oranges combined? And that bananas are the world’s 4th leading crop behind wheat, corn and rice? And we pretty much eat only one type of banana, the Cavendish, and it is threatened by diseases that can wipe out entire plantations.
But to understand where the banana is going, we must understand where its been. And that history of United Fruit and Standard Fruit in Central America is ugly, violent and embarrassing. Backed by the US government, these companies were not only allowed to violate labor agreements, but take down unfriendly governments. It would be nice to say that this doesn’t happen today , but these companies are driven to continue to offer cheap bananas at your local supermarket, damn the labor, political and environmental impacts.
On the other hand, the health of bananas isn’t always about whether or not we in middle America can eat a banana with our breakfast. Bananas are a crucial factor in the diet of many areas in Africa. If a solution isn’t found for the diseases the Cavendish banana faces, we could be looking a humanitarian disaster.
Fans of micro-histories like Salt, Cod and Curry, will enjoy Banana too. I would also recommend this to anyone interested in the history of food or thinking about where food comes from may enjoy this book too, as well as anyone interested in the history of Banana Republics or Latin American history.

link.title: Banana: The Fate of the Fruit that Changed the World

entry.title: Run by Ann Patchett
entry.content:
Ann Patchett says in an interview that Run is about politics. It isn’t. It’s really about family.
This book is the first novel to follow the uber-hit Bel Canto, and follows a wide array of Doyle family members during a 24 hour period leading up to and following a snow storm in present day Boston. Bernard Doyle is the ex-mayor of Boston, whose beloved wife, Bernadette has died many years ago. He has raised both his biological son, Sullivan, but also two adopted African-American boys, Tip and Teddy. Sullivan has secrets (everyone in Run has secrets) and has returned under suspect conditions from Africa. Doyle is making a last ditch effort to entice Tip and Teddy into politics by inviting them to a Jesse Jackson lecture at Harvard. They go, but would rather be elsewhere. After the lecture, Tip’s life is saved by Tennessee, who pushes him out of the way of a car in the snow. Why was Tennessee so close? And what should the Doyle family do with her daughter, Kenya?
This book starts off telling the story of a statue of the Virgin Mary. The story of how the family comes into possession of the beautiful statue is one of secrets, lies and ultimately how deceit can ruin a family. Race, family, Catholicism, lies, loyalty provide the twists and turns in this novel. Underneath it all is a good family, and interesting story and solid characters. Patchett bites off a lot, sometimes too much, but this would be a good recommendation for anyone who enjoys contemporary literature.

entry.title:
Hi there,
I saw that your book club has previous...
entry.content:
Hi there,

I saw that your book club has previously read Tóibín's Brooklyn, and wondered whether any of your members might like to put a question to Colm Tóibín himself about this book? BBC World Book Club on the World Service is interviewing him on 6th July and would love to hear from you. We’re always keen to get questions from readers around the world with both positive and negative criticism of the books. If you could email me at World.Bookclub@bbc.co.uk as soon as you can with a question about the book (anything - doesn't have to be particularly clever!), we can either arrange for you to talk to Colm Tóibín himself, or have our presenter put your question to him for you. Then you get to hear your question on BBC World Service Radio. The programme will air on 6th August at 11.00hrs on the BBC World Service. Please do get in touch.

Best wishes,
BBC World Book Club

entry.title: I may have to have another go at this book. I foun...
entry.content: I may have to have another go at this book. I found the second section to be a bit of a slog and had to put it down (diary entries from various characters). But if the third section is a continuation of the first I definitely would like to finish that. I will also check out the character spreadsheet since the plot can be a bit unwieldy. I thoroughly reccommend "2666" and "Distant Star." Nazi Literature seemed a bit insidey for my taste and therefore not very funny, but someone who is better versed in literature may find it enjoyable.
